LEAD: The icicles dripping off frozen Florida oranges on Christmas weekend warmed hearts in Brazil, the world's largest producer of frozen orange juice.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
INTERNATIONAL
Brazil's orange producers stand to profit handsomely from frost damage in Florida.
Bolstered by a record crop, 1990 exports are expected to surge by as much as 36 percent, to a record $1.5 billion.
To Brazilians, the orange has become a symbol of easy wealth; a popular soap opera centers on the industry.

Nicaragua Devaluation
LEAD: The Government has devalued Nicaragua's currency for the 40th time this year and raised the price of gasoline and public transportation.
The move by the Nicaraguan central bank brought the official exchange rate to 38,150 cordobas to a dollar.
The previous rate was 36,330 cordobas.
Friday's action raised urban and inter-city bus fares by 30 percent.

Question Box
LEAD:
Bear and Big Bowls
Q.
How many times did Bear Bryant coach Alabama in the four major bowls and how did his teams do?
A.
In an Alabama coaching career of 25 years from 1958 through 1982, in which his Crimson Tide appeared in bowl games all but the first of those years, Bryant had a 10-7 record in major bowls: Cotton, Orange and Sugar.

How to Rewire America
LEAD: Dial a number and the video screen in your wall becomes a window into the place you are calling.
You can see and converse with people on the other side, even slide documents through the window, via fax machine.
All this could be possible once the country is wired with fiber-optic cable.
But that will cost some $250 billion and won't happen for decades unless Washington decides it should be done sooner.

LEAD: Today is New Year's Day. Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Government offices: Federal and state offices closed.
Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only.

Banks: Closed.
Parking: Sunday rules in effect.

Designers Unite to Indulge Every Fashion Whim
LEAD: At the dawn of a new season it is apparent that fashion choices have probably never been more diversified.
From classic calm tailored clothes to frivolous glittery ones, the vast range of styles for spring offers something for every woman's taste.
Fashion has been globalized to the point where identical trends turn up in all the major fashion centers, a sign not necessarily of designers' copying one another but of their being on the same wavelength, no matter where they live and work.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Jumping Beans
Q. What makes Mexican jumping beans jump?
A.
Mexican jumping beans, actually seeds of plants in the Croton family, are invaded by larvae of a moth, Cydia saltitans, and it is the larvae that make the beans move, said Dave Mills, an entomologist with the Arizona Commission of Agriculture and Horticulture.

LEAD: An American Airlines DC-10 bound for New York City with 257 people aboard made an emergency landing early today at Baltimore-Washington International Airport after the pilot reported smoke in the cockpit, an airline spokeswoman said.
Several passengers suffered scrapes or bruises using emergency chutes, but no serious injuries were reported.

The Editorial Notebook;   Checking Out the 1990's
LEAD: Programmed dreams.
Individual flight platforms.
Human hibernation.
These are some of the innovations cited by Herman Kahn and Anthony Wiener as likely to occur before the year 2000.
Their predictions, offered in 1967, were not at all bad.
But even with 10 years to run they veer toward excessive optimism about technology and its blessings.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
Wall Street Outlook
For many people, investing in 1989 was like having a miserable time at what should have been a great party.
Whether 1990 is any better may depend on whether interest rates fall fast enough to offset declining profits.
Last year, the popular market indexes posted their second best gain of the decade, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 27 percent.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Life Offers Discount For Running Old Ads
LEAD: In its latest effort to tap the nostalgia boom, Life magazine is offering a discount to advertisers who run old ads next to new ones.
Advertisers who pay the current price for a full-page ad get the adjacent page for an old ad at the rate in effect when the ad first ran.
The vintage ad must be at least 10 years old, and advertisers are promised at least a 24.1 percent discount over a standard two-page spread.


Treasury Securities Down Slightly
LEAD: The credit markets opened the new year on a somewhat sour note yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading.


A Deficit of $65 Million Is Seen in Connecticut
LEAD: Budget officials said today that falling sales-tax revenues and rising welfare costs will leave Connecticut with a budget deficit of $65 million for the fiscal year ending June 30.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: EVERYONE in the food industry is talking about a return to homey cooking in the 1990's - call it bistro, traditional American, unfussy Italian, whatever - which started me thinking about offal, something I associate with home cooking in France.
Offal, or variety meats, includes liver, kidney, tripe, tongue, brain, sweetbreads and other internal organs.

LEAD: A 23-year-old construction worker survived a fall of 150 feet from the Queensboro Bridge yesterday, landing in a pile of soft rubbish, the police said.
Kenneth Wolf, an ironworker from Patchogue, L.I., was in critical condition last night at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, with two broken legs, broken ankles and hip injuries, the police said.

Poland's Brave Plunge
LEAD: The Polish celebration of the new year has already ended.
The crash program to propel the economy into capitalism has gone abruptly into effect, and that means pain.
The price of heating fuel may jump by seven times.
Other necessities will also cost much more.
And hundreds of thousands of workers will soon be unemployed.

Index for Jakarta Stocks
LEAD: A new daily index to measure the Jakarta stock market will be issued starting Wednesday by BT Brokerage Asia, a unit of Bankers Trust New York.
The Jakarta Stock Exchange's own index has been criticized as being imprecise.
The base of the BT Jakarta index will be Jan. 4, 1988, and will use the adjusted weighted capital of all issued shares of listed companies, BT said today.

Bruce Crawford, president and chief executive of Omnicom, will take over as chief executive of Diversified Agency Services.

Group members pronounce anti-authoritarian slogans like the ambiguous ''fight the power'' while keeping a squad of stone-faced guards -dressed in military outfits, and the image of power - onstage.

The answer emerged 15 minutes later: he had heard about the book as a film student at New York University.
But first his conversation took a revealing detour through his childhood in Little Italy, where he was an asthmatic boy who spent endless hours at movie theaters watching biblical epics in Cinemascope and even more time rooted in front of the family television set watching black-and-white reruns of ''The Red Shoes.

LEAD:
PRO BASKETBALL
Technicals and Foul Shots Abound
There were 10 technical fouls in this game, which visiting Detroit won, 115-113, by scoring 15 of its last 17 points from the free-throw line.
Orlando's Sidney Green was ejected after picking up his second technical.
Bill Laimbeer scored 14 points in the second half and had the Pistons' only field goal in the last six minutes, a 15-foot jumper that gave Detroit a 111-104 lead with three minutes left.


The Mosaic Thing
LEAD: First there was the melting pot, but that seemed overly romantic.
Then came patchwork quilt, a down-home image that Jesse Jackson has used over the years.
Now the metaphor of the moment is gorgeous mosaic, Mayor David Dinkins's favorite description of New York City. ''I see New York as a gorgeous mosaic of race and religious faith, of national origin and sexual orientation,'' he said in his Inaugural Address on Monday, turning his oft-used campaign slogan into - a trademark, the equivalent of George Bush's ''kinder, gentler nation.

LEAD: ''The state wants to keep every community it can.
But when you have a declining population and tax base and have to keep the schools going and the highways going and the medical services and the nursing homes, it's going to be almost impossible to keep these communities alive.''
-Gov. George Sinner of North Dakota.


Montana Is M.V.P.
LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers' Joe Montana, who finished 1989 with the best all-round passing year in National Football League history, has been named the league's most valuable player by The Associated Press in balloting by sportswriters.


In Spain, It's Grand Ham Time
LEAD: If anything unites the European continent it is the ubiquitous pig in all its culinary renderings.
But it is hard to imagine the pig being more deeply rooted in folklore, tradition and gastronomy than it is in Spain.


Governor O'Neill's Commuter War
LEAD: Fares for Metro-North commuters went up 15 percent on New Year's Day - except for riders to and from Connecticut.
At the last minute, Gov.
William O'Neill vetoed any increase within Connecticut's boundaries.
By blocking needed funds, he pandered to affluent Fairfield County commuters.
In a gubernatorial election year, that's good politics but weak leadership.


Inflation Up in Sri Lanka
LEAD: Sri Lanka's annual inflation rate rose marginally, to 15.1 percent, in December, from 15 percent in the period a year ago.
The index rose 3.8 percent in December alone, up from a rise of 2.3 percent in November and 2 percent in December 1988.

LEAD: In their first major attacks of the year, leftist guerrillas ambushed and killed six policemen on patrol and burned a city bus, killing three passengers and wounding 20, the police said today.

LEAD: The move away from Communism and toward market economies in Eastern Europe may be good news for the Europeans, but some Western bankers are getting nervous.


Review/Cabaret;   Songs for Grown-Ups, by Cy Coleman
LEAD: In the literature of pop songs that celebrate sophisticated flirtation, the collaborations of the composer Cy Coleman and the lyricist Carolyn Leigh rank just below those of Cole Porter in their wit and mischievous eroticism.
Songs like ''The Best Is Yet to Come,'' ''You Fascinate Me So,'' ''Witchcraft,'' and ''When in Rome'' combine slinky syncopated melodies and tongue-twisting double-entendres to portray a game of romantic hide-and-seek that almost always ends in a passionate embrace.

LEAD: THE archeologists have unearthed the foundation of a long-lost addition, an afterthought grafted on by an owner who just could not stop tinkering with his original design.
The historians have read through reams of letters, uncovering a telling paragraph here, a helpful sentence there.

LEAD: Joseph H. Magruder, a retired businessman, died of lung cancer on Saturday at his home in Venice, Fla.
He was 76 years old and had lived for many years in Fairfield, Conn.


Peru, in Switch, Plans to Attend Drug Talks
LEAD: Peru, which said it would boycott a drug summit meeting in Colombia next month to protest the United States attack on Panama, has reversed itself and will attend the conference, American and Peruvian officials said today.


INSIDE
LEAD:
Federal AIDS Estimate Is Being Revised
Scientists say that while AIDS continues to rise sharply, there will be at least 10 percent fewer cases over the next three years than previously predicted.
Experts are debating why the rate seems to be changing.
Page D20.
Treatment for First Lady
Barbara Bush began the first of 10 daily radiation treatments to relieve the double vision, eye discomfort and tears caused by Graves' disease, a thyroid affliction.

LEAD: Salvatore J. Licata, an AIDS educator with the New York City Health Department, died of AIDS-related illnesss on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 50 years old.
In 1985, Mr.
Licata helped found People With AIDS Newsline, a monthly newspaper written by and for people with AIDS.

Green Thumbs in Winter
LEAD: WHEN green thumbs are blue with winter cold, the indoor sill is the garden location of choice.
Take the scene at George and Virginie Elbert's Manhattan apartment, which is landscaped with more than 500 plants, give or take a pot or two.
Windowsill space has been extended by tiers of shelves and movable tables, and every cranny is covered with vegetation.

LEAD: More than 250 pounds of cocaine was stashed in two waterproof tubes attached to the underside of a Colombian ship, said police officers who seized the drug on Sunday and arrested four men who showed up in diving gear, apparently to retrieve the cache.
The men were arrested on drug trafficking charges.

LEAD: Tonight's Nets game would have been even more bizarre had the Nets won.
As it was, New Jersey's 110-96 loss to the Milwaukee Bucks was loaded with unusual events.
How weird was it?
The Nets played a horrendous second quarter in which they scored only 10 points, committed 13 turnovers, and did not score for the first 4 minutes 56 seconds.

LEAD: Takeover speculation sent Paramount Communications Inc. stock sharply higher and CBS Inc. shares lower as unconfirmed rumors appeared that CBS was about to bid for the entertainment and publishing giant.
Paramount shares rose $1.50, to $52.375, on the New York Stock Exchange, while CBS tumbled $2.75, to $184 a share.

LEAD: A $400 million offer to buy various real estate assets of the financially distressed L. J. Hooker Corporation has been withdrawn, according to an executive of the Shidler Investment Corporation, a Honolulu company that is part of the investment group involved in the deal.

LEAD: Low levels of cooling water entering the intake canal at the Oyster Creek nuclear station today forced the power plant to go into the first stage of its four-step emergency plan.

Home Improvement
LEAD: WHEN water freezes and expands inside pipes, itcan cause major damage requiring expensive repairs.
Frequently, the pressure causes the pipes to burst or, at the least, to leak at the seams.
And, because pipes usually freeze when and where coping with them is most difficult, preventing the problem is as important, if not more so, than knowing what to do if it occurs.

Topics of The Times;   Usage, Decimated
LEAD: People irritated by the use of the verb ''aggravate'' to mean ''irritate'' had better prepare to have their irritation aggravated.
The Manchester Guardian Weekly reports that a panel of language experts regularly consulted by the Random House Dictionary gives this usage its blessing.
In 1969, a majority of the panel regarded it as a solecism.

Highway 61, one of America's most beautiful and treacherous highways.

LEAD: When a pro football defense faces a passing situation, it usually puts in a nickel defense with five defensive backs or a dime defense with six.
It usually has three or four defensive linemen rush the passer (one may be a linebacker), and in addition one or more linebackers or defensive backs may blitz.


I.C.I. Markets Drug
LEAD: Imperial Chemical Industries of London said its Stuart Pharmaceuticals unit had started marketing the anti-depressant drug Elavil.
I.C.I. bought Elavil from a joint venture of Johnson &amp; Johnson and Merck &amp; Company on Tuesday in exchange for I.C.I.'s over-the-counter pharmaceutical business.
Elavil has annual sales of at least $25 million, said I.C.I., which valued the deal at more than $450 million.

LEAD: Despite Ronald Reagan's pledge to shrink the bureaucracy, Federal employment rose in five of his eight years in the White House.

So much for that promise.

LEAD: Generations of children have delighted in the scary lore that Tyrannosaurus rex was the largest and fiercest predator ever to walk the earth.

Review/Film;   Burning Books and Burying Scholars Alive
LEAD: More than 2,000 years ago, a crafty Chinese feudal king put down a rebellion in his province, went on to conquer six neighboring kingdoms, and then gave himself the name Qin Shihuang, meaning First Emperor.
Having established peace, the first Chinese Emperor maintained it ruthlessly, burning books that challenged his laws and burying alive 460 scholars who disagreed with him.

Corrections
LEAD: A table yesterday showing corrected figures for population shifts in the United States misstated the census region for Pennsylvania in some copies.
It is the Middle Atlantic region.
In addition the 1980 population total and percentage change for the Midwest were incorrect in some copies.
The 1980 total was 58,868,000 and the increase was 2.2 percent.


Pope Sees Thirst for Religion
LEAD: Pope John Paul II said today that the current collapse of atheist systems in Eastern Europe showed the error of trying to exclude God from human life.
He told a group of Italian pilgrims that mankind was living through ''exceptional times'' as the 20th century drew to a close. ''On one hand we are seeing the collapse of projects constructed by men with the explicit exclusion of all references to God, while on the other hand we are seeing a new hunger for the word of God,'' the Pope said.

LEAD: The New York State special prosecutor's office yesterday asked the state's highest court to review a ruling that threw out the riot convictions of three of the defendants in the 1986 racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens.


Punished by Bucharest, City's Choice Was Revolt
LEAD: The man described his day.
He wakes.
He goes to buy milk for his children.
For the babies, there is no formula to buy.
He goes to work.
The bus line is long and slow.
It is cold at work.
There is no heat, no equipment for proper work.
He finishes work and goes to buy something to eat.
But there is no food to buy.

LEAD: One of three engines on a Northwest Airlines jet fell off the plane yesterday as it flew over northern Florida, but the pilots were able to land safely.


Real Estate Sales Lure Investors
LEAD: Attracted by the hope of bargains, real estate investors and prospective home buyers are jamming the phone lines of the Government agency that this week began selling billions of dollars' worth of properties owned by failed savings institutions.

LEAD: It is not so much a matter of taste as a taste of matter that creates problems for the chubby housewife whose name gives the title to ''Beth,'' one of the three plays in Steven Sater's ''Carbondale Dreams'' package of one-acters at the Judith Anderson Theater.
The plays, presented two at a time, explore the tensions between family togetherness and individual yearnings.

Panama in Disorder: The 1980's
LEAD:
March 1982: After the death in 1981 of the armed forces chief, Gen.
Omar Torrijos Herrera, three senior officers - Col.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, Col.
Ruben Darlo Paredes and Col.
Roberto Diaz Herrera - cut a deal to resolve ja power struggle.
Paredes is promoted to general, takes over as armed forces chief and agrees to retire in August 1983, leaving Noriega to take over, with Diaz Herrera as second-in-command.

LEAD: A motorist who pleaded guilty to charges stemming from a rampage along a crowded downtown street last year was sentenced Wednesday to a minimum of 13 years in prison.

LEAD: Last year was a tough one for both investment advisers and mutual funds, with most of them failing to match the Standard &amp; Poor's 500-stock index.
But the investment advisers seem to have done better than the stock mutual funds, according to figures released yesterday.

He is 52 years old.

LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins filled two more major positions in his administration yesterday, selecting as his director of operations a New York City school official whom he credited with helping to reduce the bureaucracy at the Board of Education.
The Mayor also named an investment banker to head the city's economic-development effort.

LEAD: The Pacific Telesis Group, the regional telephone and communications company based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it plans to eliminate 11,000 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, in the next five years to cut costs.

LEAD: Children, it was once held, should be seen and not heard.
The Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street, takes a different tack: children should be heard but not seen.
This is the stuff a new workshop, starting this weekend, is made of.

Manuel Antonio Noriega in American custody and out of the country, relieved Panamanians turned their attention today to the arduous process of repairing the damage he inflicted on the political, social and economic fabric of this nation of 2.3 million people during his six-year rule.

LEAD: American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, said it would cut prices to match a move by Eastern Airlines and join most of the industry in offering lower fares.
American, a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, Fort Worth, said it would match Eastern's fares in the 600 markets in which the both compete.

LEAD: For 40 years, the Portuguese community in Naugatuck has celebrated St.
Paio, a patron saint, and the celebration has evolved into the biggest social event of the year for the 6,000 Portuguese and Portuguese-Americans who make up 20 percent of the town's population.

LEAD: Many of the nation's big retailers yesterday reported that sales were moderately higher in December, bolstered by a buying pickup in the final days before Christmas.

LEAD: Delta Air Lines said today that it had received a general threat against its trans-Atlantic operations but believed the warning was a hoax.


F.D.A. Begins Testing Milk
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration says it has begun testing retail milk supplies in 13 cities after an independent survey found samples in several areas tainted with potentially harmful drugs.
The agency said Tuesday that while it was concerned that these unconfirmed findings might indicate ''violative drug residues in milk,'' it saw ''no public health threat associated with animal drug residues in milk'' at the levels reported by The Wall Street Journal last Friday.

LEAD: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, depressed by caution before the Government's report today of employment data for December.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 13.65 points to close at 2,796.08, just below the important 2,800 technical level.

LEAD: Less dramatically than in Berlin and less bloodily than in Bucharest, the winds of Communist change have swept across the Gobi Desert to stir up political life in the sparsely populated nation of Mongolia.

China's Coal Output Up
LEAD: China announced today that its coal output for 1989 had exceeded a target of one billion tons, but said industries still remained short of the fuel.
Output rose to 1.04 billion tons last year from 970 million tons in 1988, the official Economic Daily said.

LEAD: A woman extradited from Austria will remain in jail without bond to face charges that she operated an international marijuana-smuggling ring, a Federal district judge has ruled.

Zenith Ends Claim
LEAD: The Zenith Data Systems Corporation, a unit of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, agreed to drop its protest against the award of a $706 million Air Force contract to the Unisys Corporation for desktop computer equipment, both companies said.
The contract calls for Unisys, a computer manufacturer based here, to make equipment that combines two of the most widely used desktop operating systems - Unix and MS-DOS.


Litton Seeks Sale Of 3 Divisions
LEAD: Litton Industries put up for sale three divisions that supply electrical and electronic interconnection products.
The three divisions, which have combined annual sales of about $170 million and employ about 2,200 people, are: Advanced Circuitry and Inter-Pak Electronics, based in Springfield, Mo.; VEAM, based in Milan, Italy, with domestic operations in Watertown, Conn., and Winchester Electronics, based in Watertown.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about new year's observances in Japan referred incorrectly to the calendar used in the West.
It is the Gregorian calendar, based on the solar year.

There have been no arrests.

LEAD: From the first, the story seized the attention of the nation: a pregnant young woman dying of gunshot wounds while her husband, also shot, frantically called for help over his car phone; then the 17-day fight for life of their baby boy, delivered eight weeks premature.


Restaurants
LEAD: Distinguished Mexican food is not something that leaps to mind when describing the New York dining scene.
It may have something to do with immigration patterns, or maybe the weather, but it just seems that Mexican cooks don't settle here in significant numbers to nurture a culinary community that could adequately demonstrate their diverse cuisine.

LEAD: Continuing to move aggressively in his first days in office, Joseph A. Fernandez, the New York City Schools Chancellor, said yesterday that he would take command of schools and school boards that do not measure up to his academic standards.


Elsa Andresen Bledsoe, Contralto, 92
LEAD: Elsa Andresen Bledsoe, a charter member of the Oratorio Society of New Jersey, died Tuesday at the Arnold Walter Nursing Home in Holmdel, N.J.
She was 92 years old.
Surviving are two daughters, Margery Owen Bostrom of Red Bank, N.J., and Elizabeth Owen Greene of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; two stepdaughters, Dorothy Barber of Bridgewater, N.J., and Geraldine Slattery, of Bryn Mawr, Pa.; two stepsons, Harry Bledsoe of Avoca, Iowa, and George Bledsoe of Council Bluffs, Iowa; 11 grandchildren; 13 great-grandchildren, and 2 great-great-grandsons.

LEAD: For the first time since his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association was taken over by Federal regulators in April, Charles H. Keating Jr. took the stand in a crowded courtroom here today.
He denied any wrongdoing and answered questions about his involvement in the institution.

Economic Scene;   Business Cycle's New Stability
LEAD: IS the business cycle dead?
The United States economy has now completed seven straight years of expansion, the longest in its peacetime history.
Most economists foresee no recession in 1990 or 1991, and 1992 will be another Presidential election year, when the odds tip strongly against recession.
Japan, West Germany and most of the other capitalist countries of Europe and Asia are also on a long upward roll, with no end in sight.


Michaels to Coach
LEAD: The eight-team International League of Football, which begins play in eight cities in Europe in April, began assigning head coaches to teams yesterday and Walt Michaels wound up as coach of the Helsinki team in Finland and Jack Elway as coach in London.

LEAD: When Lionel Simmons stops running so gracefully on the basketball court, perhaps he should run for political office.

LEAD: Leonard Elliott, an actor and comedian who performed on the Broadway stage and in Manhattan nightclubs, died of cardiac arrest on Sunday in St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: New York's ''new'' City Council, given real power in the just-approved City Charter, is off to a disappointing start.
At its very first meeting under the new Charter this week, the Council sent the message that it likes the perks of power, but isn't yet too interested in the responsibility.

LEAD: Soldiers with acetylene torches cut into crushed railroad cars today searching for victims of Pakistan's worst train wreck, which officials said killed at least 210 people and injured 700.

Christie's Appointment
LEAD: Emmanuel de Margerie, the Ambassador of France to the United States for five years through December and director general of the Museums of France from 1975 to 1977, has been appointed to the board of Christie's International and chairman of Christie's in Europe, a new position.
Mr. de Margerie, who is 65 years old, will be based in Paris.


Quaker State Plan
LEAD: The Quaker State Corporation is offering a free warranty on engine parts of new cars lubricated by its oil for 10 years or 250,000 miles.
Car owners must meet strict rules, including having an oil and filter change every four months or 4,000 miles using Quaker State oil.
The warranty does not cover claims already covered by auto manufacturers' warranties, but it will pay for deductibles not covered by the auto makers' extended service contracts.

Treasury Security Prices Mixed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities ended narrowly mixed in fairly light trading yesterday, as market participants largely shrugged off developments in the foreign exchange, energy and equity markets.


Business May Look Down, but Racing Fans Can Look Up
LEAD: Thoroughbred racing begins a new season amid a mixed forecast: a year of poor business but wonderful racing.


HBO's Pact Is Extended
LEAD: Home Box Office and the music syndicate BMI have extended a licensing agreement for one month, sidestepping a court order that could have temporarily barred HBO from broadcasting films with BMI songs.


Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $955.0 million, to $365.04 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 144 institutional funds increased by $625.7 million, to $88.23 billion.
The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were down $112.1 million, to $119.87 billion.


Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame
LEAD: FOR performers and visual artists, recognition can be immediate -as a newcomer makes a striking first impression in a debut.
Or, after a period of anonymity, a more experienced professional may attract attention after finally having the opportunity to demonstrate originality.
In a theater or concert hall, there can be an audible certification of that newness, with the sound of an audience rustling programs to find the name of a previously unknown and soon-to-be-memorable performer.


Workers Say Moroccan Oil Spill Could Have Been Halted Sooner
LEAD: Dutch salvage workers trying to clean up a huge Atlantic oil spill said today that the accident could have been controlled much faster if the Spanish or Moroccan authorities had allowed a crippled Iranian oil tanker into their coastal waters for repairs.


A U.S.-Soviet Venture of a Gentler Kind


Right to Bear Arms
LEAD: To the Editor:


Patents;   New Flea Repellant
LEAD: Two researchers at the Elexis Corporation, a company in Miami that makes pulse monitors, have patented an electronic flea repelling device for household pets.
The heart of the device, which is mounted on a pet's collar, is a transducer that sends out periodic ultrasonic pulses that do not bother a dog or cat but apparently are intolerable to fleas.


Prosecutor Quits; Tale of Attack Was Hoax
LEAD: New Jersey's most flamboyant prosecutor resigned today after his tale of a high-speed chase and shoot-out between him and men he described as drug dealers, terrorists or members of the Ku Klux Klan turned out to be a hoax.


Patents;   A Tape Measure With Digital Readout
LEAD: The Kyoto Measuring Instruments Corporation, based in Kyoto, Japan, has invented a retractable tape measure with a digital readout.
The device is said to be easier to use and to read than the standard tool, in which measurements are marked on the tape itself.


The Noriega Case: Panama City;   Papal Envoy Asserts Psychology, Not Ultimatum, Swayed Noriega
LEAD: The papal envoy to Panama, the pivotal figure in 10 days of tense negotiations that ended in Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega's surrender, insisted today that the general's departure from the Vatican mission resulted not from an ultimatum but from a precisely calibrated psychological campaign.


13 FACE CHARGES IN FAMILY KILLINGS
LEAD: Thirteen former members of a religious commune were charged with murder or conspiracy yesterday after the bodies of a family of five were found buried at an Ohio farm in what a prosecutor called a human sacrifice.


Travelers' Security Precautions
LEAD: The holiday travel rush is over, but passenger security precautions know no season.
Here is some advice for travelers from Christopher Grose, president of Control Risks Limited, an international security consultant whose United States headquarters is in Bethesda, Md.

LEAD:

Anheuser-Busch
LEAD: Anheuser-Busch Inc. said it plans to begin selling its new non-alcoholic brew, O'Doul's, around the country starting on Monday.
The brewery said it has had strong initial sales in selected cities where the beer has been on shelves since March.
Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewery, said O'Doul's would meet the desires of a growing segment of consumers who like the taste of beer but do not want the alcohol.


Japanese Insurance Concern Invests in American Express
LEAD: The Nippon Life Insurance Company, the large Japanese insurer that already has a sizable stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton, the brokerage unit affiliated with the American Express Company, has agreed to make a $200 million investment in American Express itself.


Eased Verdict Sought
LEAD: Aaron Pryor, the former world junior welterweight champion, said in a motion filed Thursday in Hamilton County Municipal Court in Cincinnati that he should receive treatment for drug dependency instead of a conviction for possession of drug items.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''What kind of crazy way is this to run a place?
If they treat me this way and I'm the Chancellor, what is going on here?''
-Joseph A. Fernandez, New York City Schools Chancellor. [1:4.]


Bridge
LEAD: Happy players at the end of a pairs contest often report that they had a ''big game,'' meaning that they did very well.
But to deserve the title ''Big Game'' with capital letters, one needs a score of 75% or better, which is very rare.

LEAD: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:
OPENING STATEMENT


'Legs Diamond' Suit Is Settled Out of Court
LEAD: The choreographer Michael Shawn will receive $175,000 from the producers of the 1988 musical ''Legs Diamond'' in an out-of-court settlement of a suit in which he charged that the producers had dismissed him because he had tested positive for the AIDS virus.


Minnesota Senator Denies New Charges of Impropriety
LEAD: Senator Dave Durenberger, who is already facing a Senate investigation of his financial dealings, today strongly denied new accusations of impropriety regarding the Government's reimbursement for his rental of a Minneapolis condiminum.


Vacancy For A Czar
LEAD: There is talk of creating a ''homeless czar.'' The position was mentioned to me by a well-connected Republican.
He knows of my ambition to replace Dan Quayle on the ticket in 1992. ''Get yourself a czardom,'' he counseled. ''Like Bennett.''


Upheaval in the East;   Poland to Cut Army Strength
LEAD: Poland will reduce required military service from 2 years to 18 months this year and also cut manpower, Defense Minister Florian Siwicki said today.


About New York;   For Paraplegic, Acting in a Film Is the Easy Part
LEAD: Kenneth Osborne has known grave disappointment.
When he was 19 years old and a carefree college football player, his spine was severed in a car crash, leaving him paralyzed from the chest down.
It was hell to adjust.
But he did. ''That took some serious time,'' Mr.
Osborne said.


Dakin Accord With Hallmark
LEAD: Hallmark Cards Inc. and Dakin Inc. said today that they had reached an agreement in principle for Hallmark to acquire Dakin, a leading marketer of plush stuffed toys, for an undisclosed amount.


Robert Sivard, 75, Former Art Director For the Government
LEAD: Robert Sivard, a painter and illustrator whose sprightly canvases range from urban street scenes to the lives of famous painters and literary figures, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Washington.
He was 75 years old.


OPEC's Output at 1989 High
LEAD: OPEC's oil output reached a 1989 high of 23.6 million barrels a day throughout December and will probably remain strong in early 1990 despite a new production-cutting accord, oil industry, government and shipping sources said this week.


Citgo Stake May Be Resold
LEAD: Venezuela, which recently agreed to buy the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it did not already own, will probably resell the stake, the Energy Minister, Celestino Armas, said today.


Ian Horvath, Dancer, Dies at 46; A Founder of the Cleveland Ballet
LEAD: Ian (Ernie) Horvath, producing director of the Jose Limon Dance Foundation, a founder of the Cleveland Ballet and a former soloist with the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater, died of AIDS yesterday at St.
Vincent's Hospital in New York.
Mr.
Horvath was 46 years old.


Treasury Securities Move Lower
LEAD: Most Treasury securities prices declined yesterday as the fixed-income market shrugged off the smaller-than-expected rise in employment that the Government reported for December.
The bond market also paid little notice to the strong rise in December factory orders.

LEAD: The medieval squares and coffee houses of this city have come alive again with politics.
But the heady talk has been more about what may have been President Vaclav Havel's first mistake than about the crimes and abuses of the Communists.

LEAD: Jeffrey Barbakow, chairman of the MGM/UA Communications Company, has told company executives that efforts to sell the entertainment company are on hold, the trade publication Variety has reported, quoting unidentified sources.

LEAD: Gen.

LEAD: *

LEAD: The Maine Attorney General asked a state judge today to block on antitrust grounds the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's $3.8 billion hostile bid for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation.

LEAD: Carmen Hill, a former National League pitcher who compiled a 49-33 record in 10 major league seasons over 16 years, died on Monday in Indianapolis.
He was 94 years old.

LEAD: Strikes and large protests by members of Bulgaria's Slavic majority opposed to religious and cultural freedom for ethnic Turks paralyzed towns and cities across the country today.

N.B.A.
Bird Injured in Loss to Clippers

Bird sprained his left ankle with 42 seconds left in the first quarter and played just 19 minutes, 4 in the second half.

He was 76 years old.
Mr.
Wels, an expert on family law, helped to modernize the state's matrimonial laws.
For nearly 40 years, he was a leader of the New York State Bar Association and the American Bar


Gertrude Simon Kosting, Health-Care Worker, 84
LEAD: Gertrude Simon Kosting, a health-care worker and the president of the Huxley Institute of Connecticut, died of an embolism on Tuesday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.
She was 84 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.


Ernest T. Brainard, 99, Broker in Connecticut
LEAD: Ernest T. Brainard, who apparently was the nation's oldest active stockbroker, died on Wednesday as he was getting ready to go work.
He was 99 years old and lived in West Hartford.


COURT OVERTURNS AWARD TO FAMILY IN SMOKING DEATH
LEAD: A Federal appeals court yesterday threw out the first verdict ever requiring an American cigarette manufacturer to compensate the family of a smoker who died of cancer.
But at the same time, the court, may have made it easier for smokers and their families to prevail in future lawsuits against tobacco companies.


Katmandu Journal;   Some Room at the Top of the World
LEAD: On Wednesday, when Dipendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev, a young man of 18, rode a fine carriage from temple to temple to mark his coming of age as Crown Prince, a lot else was going on in this city transformed almost beyond recognition in less than a decade.

LEAD: New York City's new Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, said yesterday that he would file a charge of incompetence against the principal of a Brooklyn high school whom he removed from office over her handling of two disturbances by the school's students.

Dollar Has Late U.S. Rally; Gold Prices Post Sharp Rise
LEAD: The dollar staged a turnaround yesterday, closing mostly higher in domestic dealings after taking a sharp hit in overseas markets that were focusing on events in Eastern Europe.


Department Spent $224,000 In Effort to Unmask Informer
LEAD: The Justice Department said today that it spent $224,000 on an attempt to identify the source of an unauthorized disclosure of a preliminary criminal investigation involving Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

LEAD: Rumania's new leaders paid last respects today to Secretary of State Corneliu Bogdan, the first of their number to die since they took power two weeks ago.


Gary Reasons' Head
LEAD: The head is a strange instrument, an awesome thing, a thing of multiple utilities.
It can be used to cogitate; it can be used to ruminate; the skeletal remnant can be a memory device - ''Alas, poor Yorick!
I knew him, Horatio.'' And it can be used as a weapon - like being armed with your head.


Paroled Killer Accused in Deaths Of 11 Women in Rochester Area
LEAD: A convicted killer of two children was accused today of killing 11 women, most of them prostitutes, in a series of attacks that began here in March 1988, a year after his release from prison for the earlier slayings.


Inquiry at Clemson
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will conduct an official investigation of the Clemson football program, the school said yesterday.
A preliminary investigation uncovered 14 alleged rule violations, ranging from wrongful payments to illegal recruiting contacts, the school said.


Campeau Unit Trims Office Staff 14%
LEAD: Federated Department Stores, a subsidiary of the financially troubled Campeau Corporation, said yesterday that it had eliminated 52 positions in its Cincinnati headquarters, or about 14 percent of its already reduced corporate staff.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Stain-Resistant Carpets
LEAD: These days, almost all American-made nylon carpets offer some sort of stain protection, which makes it easier than ever to remove spots.
So, parties that chase the post-holiday blahs need no longer leave permanent reminders.


Peru's Inflation Is Owed To Lack of Restraints
LEAD: To the Editor:


What? Send Women to War?
LEAD: Capt.
Linda Bray led an attack in the Panama invasion, apparently the first time that a woman has commanded American forces in battle.
But she was acting as a Military Police officer; women are still barred from combat roles in the armed forces.
Since women like Captain Bray already serve with distinction in danger zones, isn't it time to allow them into combat too?


Beliefs
LEAD: When the baby boomers needed backyards, America got suburbia.
When they protested, America got sit-ins and antiwar marches.
When their hormones began to act up, America got the sexual revolution.


Racial Manipulation in Boston
LEAD: When Charles Stuart jumped off a bridge to his death in Boston Harbor Thursday, he apparently took with him the answers to one of the most bizarre murder mysteries in Boston's history.
But his death is only the beginning of what is sure to be a period of soul-searching, even anger, in a city long torn by racial conflict.

LEAD: Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin took charge of the questioning of Charles H. Keating Jr. today, and in almost five hours of intense inquiries the judge voiced deep concerns about accounting methods used by the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and its parent, the American Continental Corporation.


M.T.A. Amplifier Ban Is Blocked by Judge
LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday blocked the Metropolitan Transit Authority from enforcing a rule that bans musicians from using amplifiers in New York City subways.


Elegy for an English Bike
LEAD: My bicycle was stolen the other day.
Or maybe I should say my friend was kidnapped on West 23d Street sometime between 7 P.M. and 10 P.M.
She was a Raleigh three-speed, English, heavy, black and one of the most remarkable machines I've ever had.
No effete, high-strung 10-speed from Italy or Japan was she.


Stocks Drop Broadly, With Dow Off 22.83
LEAD: Stocks retreated broadly yesterday in continued moderate trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.83 points, to 2,773.25.


Grand Juries: Wasteful and Pointless
LEAD: If a defendant pleads not guilty to a felony charge, the New York State Constitution provides that he cannot be tried for that charge unless he is indicted by a grand jury.
The idea is sound: No one should be accused, arrested or required to answer a felony charge at trial if there is no evidence to support the charge.

LEAD: At the age of 58, after making the playoffs 11 times as an assistant coach, Bud Carson will run his very own National Football League playoff team for the first time today.

LEAD: The recent explosion in petroleum prices, especially diesel fuel, is raising transportation prices in a way not seen for a decade, economists and industry executives say.
Airlines and trucking companies are imposing fuel surcharges or indexing their rates to fuel costs.

Washington Talk;   Rationing In the Sky: U.S. Takes New Look
LEAD: Even in this era of deregulation and free markets, rationing remains the Federal Government's preferred solution to some problems.
While competition may be constrained, some social purpose is served, or so goes the theory, by limiting immigration, radio and television licenses - or the right to land and take off at airports where traffic is at full capacity.

LEAD: The authorities in the northern state of Kashmir have imposed an indefinite curfew in Srinagar, the capital, and 10 other cities after militants seeking independence threatened to disrupt the region, Government officials said today.

A New Air Force One
LEAD: A new Air Force One jet will be delivered to President Bush on Sept. 30, almost two years late, largely because of efforts to make it resistant to a nuclear explosion, the Boeing Company said Thursday.
Boeing, which has been building two modified 747 jumbo jets for the President's use, originally promised that a new Air Force One would be ready in November 1988.

LEAD: President Bush today left open the door for Gen.

71 Ships Use Suez Canal
LEAD: Seventy-one ships sailed through the Suez Canal today, the highest number in 12 years, earning Egypt $6 million in tolls, Canal Authority sources said.
The record was set in 1978 when 95 ships passed through the canal in a single day, they said.
A southbound convoy of 41 ships sailed through the 117-mile waterway from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea, including 9 oil tankers and 13 container ships.

LEAD: The Italian lira was devalued by 3 percent against other major European currencies late today, while its trading band within the European Monetary System was narrowed.

LEAD: Hundreds of Vietnamese who helped the Americans during the Vietnam War and who were punished for it after the Communist victory are on their way to the United States.
Three jets brought the first 156 former re-education camp inmates and their families today to Bangkok from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, and 151 more are expected on Saturday.

LEAD: A Bronx pharmacist and a New Jersey podiatrist have pleaded guilty to stealing $1 million apiece in separate Medicaid schemes, a state special prosecutor said yesterday.

LEAD: Score one for Mayor David Dinkins.
In his first days in office he announced that he had delayed hiring the next class of New York City police recruits.
The gesture, though blunt, was brave and important.
Nobody wants fewer police officers.
But neither does anyone want the city to stumble back into fiscal trouble.

LEAD: The pilots of a Northwest Airlines jetliner who flew for nearly 25 minutes on Thursday unaware that one of the plane's three engines had sheared off and plummeted 35,000 feet would have had no way of knowing what had happened, aviation experts said yesterday.

He pledged that by the end of his first term he would put an officer on every train every night, not in every car.

Mortgage Rates Mixed
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.83 percent, up from 9.78 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.35 percent this week, down from 8.39 percent the week before.

LEAD: There will not be any Greenwich mansions at Levittown prices in the Government's sale of 30,000 properties taken over from failed savings institutions.
But a look yesterday at some of the 20 residential properties offered in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut showed housing for every pocketbook and life style and, maybe, a chance to save a few thousand dollars.

From a spaghetti sipper to a new jump rope, patents were granted for simple devices offering a creative, often whimsical twist to things most people assume cannot be improved.

LEAD: A collapse of Government regulation of the oil tanker industry created conditions that led to the Alaska oil spill, a panel of scientists and oil industry experts concluded in a report released today by the state of Alaska.

LEAD: When Michael Palin agreed to circle the world in the company of a small television crew from the BBC, he knew the result would be no more a learned travelogue than the Jules Verne novel that inspired the journey.


Manila to Dismiss 126,000
LEAD: The Government will dismiss 126,000 employees this month in an effort to weed out unqualified civil service workers who got their jobs through patronage, an official said today.
The affected employees hold temporary positions received through the intercession of politicians, said Patricia Santo Tomas, head of the Civil Service Commission.

Tandy Expects Earnings Decline
LEAD: The Tandy Corporation, whose sales have been hit in a weaker domestic computer industry, said it expects to post lower earnings for its quarter that ended Dec. 31.
The consumer electronics maker, which operates Radio Shack stores, said its profit for the second quarter would be lower than in the period a year ago, when it had earnings of $1.50 a share on sales of $1.4 billion.

LEAD: More than four months after they were forced to leave their homes, tenants of a Gramercy Park building that was coated with asbestos when a Consolidated Edison steam pipe exploded last summer can move back to their apartments beginning Jan. 15, the utility said yesterday.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Credit Card Savings
LEAD:
With interest rates headed down, as they are now, holders of bank credit cards with payments based on a fixed rate of interest can save as much as $100 a year in fees by switching to cards with interest payments tied to a variable rate.
The fixed rate charged on many bank cards has been holding at current levels for a few years - good for card holders while interest rates rise.

Weighing The Differences Among Heaters
LEAD: Another fad is taking hold in the business of keeping warm: ceramic electric heaters.
Like the portable kerosene burners and quartz electric heaters that preceded them, ceramic heaters have a few advantages over older models.
But they are also the subject of advertising and sales promotions that sometimes promise too much.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
EASTER ISLAND: The Mystery Solved.
By Thor Heyerdahl. (Random House, $24.95.) The explorer Thor Heyerdahl argues in ''Easter Island,'' as he has in such books as ''Kon-Tiki,'' that ancient peoples were more developed and mobile than modern thinking gives them credit for.
Easter Island, off South America in the Pacific Ocean, has long been a subject of scientific speculation for its large stone statues, its cultural history, its language and even its plant life, all of which are distinct from those of its island neighbors.

END PAPER: Community College;   Every Student Is a Story
LEAD: DESPITE the bargain-basement image and second-rate reputation of the community college - the ''K Mart of Education'' is what some people call it - its inner life is often rich and complex.
In one row there may be a middle-aged professional actor, an ex-marine who studies Amish philosophy, a wife and husband who separated during the term, a young day-care worker who hugs abused children every day, a French emigrant and an intelligence officer who says he was left to die in an outpost in Vietnam because he refused to perform illegal activities.

LEAD: SINGLE-HANDLE kitchen and bathroom faucets often feature replaceable cartridge valves.

WHAT'S DOING IN: Boston
LEAD: Boston in the wintertime has a nasty reputation.
The snow flies, the slush forms and the wind howls on a daily basis.
But the city is small and easy to negotiate, and the crowds are thin.
Cars should be left at home if possible; the city's public transportation is reliable and fairly inexpensive, and in many cases it is possible to walk unless the precipitation is truly blinding, which is rare.


To the Brink and Back in Real Estate
LEAD: Back in the late 1960's, most people saw nothing more than cattle and horses rambling over the rolling prairie northwest of Dallas.
Ben Carpenter saw the community of the future.
So, in 1969, he set about building it.


STREETSCAPES: The Christian Herter Home;   Another Transformation For a 'Modern French' House
LEAD: IT has always been one of the most striking buildings on Madison Avenue - an ancient limestone facade over a newer but still elegant iron storefront below.
Now the 1893 Christian Herter house at 819 Madison, at 68th Street, is in the middle of a renovation - at least of its 1933 storefront - and the results should be available for inspection this spring.


Campus Tours for the College-Bound
LEAD: IF the wind-chill factor is minus 7 degrees and it's Sunday, we must be inspecting the campus of the University of Massachusetts in Amherst.
I am a few years out of practice in looking at campuses, but it all came back recently when I made a round of New England colleges with a high school senior to test a new travel offering: college tours conducted by a Long Island company that takes a van or bus of young people between Friday afternoon and Sunday evening, providing driver, hotel rooms, chaperones, meals and transportation for $315 a person.


Add-ons Ease the Pain of Shrinking Sterling Sales
LEAD: With consumer demand for silver sinking, silversmiths in the 80's started to cast about for other products that could benefit from their venerable names.
To survive, several began to import and market stainless steel and to move into other tabletop products like crystal and china to fill out their lines and make their accounts more attractive to department store retailers.

Traditions Offer Shelter From the World
LEAD: AT Aunt Ruth's house there is always candy.
And every child who visits there eats tons of it.
Aunt Ruth believes children need candy.
Their mother believes they need fruit.
But she gives in, for the debate is a sham, and Aunt Ruth always wins.
The children know to head straight for the chocolate as soon as their mother grins.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: MOST Americans say they would personally pay an additional $200 a year in taxes to improve public education.
Three-quarters of the 1,234 adults surveyed by the Gallup Poll said Federal spending on programs to improve public education should be increased.
The poll found that the public supported increased spending on education even when the condition of higher taxes was added.

Review/Dance;   Isadora Duncan Repertory From Her Soviet Period
LEAD: In 1921, Isadora Duncan, the great pioneer of American modern dance, went to teach and choreograph in the Soviet Union.
Excited by the social changes she saw, she created several dances to Soviet workers' songs.
Five rarely revived ones were offered Friday night at Eden's Expressway in a program called ''From the Repertory of Isadora Duncan,'' and the stagings by Julia Levien and Hortense Kooluris proved fascinating.


IN THE TRENCHES OF THE DRUG WARS
LEAD: The United States' ''war on drugs'' was first declared by President Richard Nixon in the early 1970's.
The current drug crisis provides ample proof that this particular war has been a colossal failure.
The reasons range from obscene profits and widespread corruption to national interests and geopolitical maneuverings.

ARKADY RENKO GOES TO MUNICH
LEAD: IN AN UNLIT PARKING LOT, JUST OFF the road leading north out of Munich, the prostitutes are in their jeeps.
It's about 10 P.M., and there are maybe two dozen vehicles in the lot, some of them dark, with curtains drawn around the side and back windows.
In the others, the cab lights are on so the men who are walking or cruising by in their own cars can get a good look at the girls inside.

Romance That Henry James Would Approve Of
LEAD: Perhaps no dinners have ever sparkled as brilliantly as the annual Waterloo banquets held by the first Duke of Wellington at Apsley House, on the anniversary of the battle.
Not only were there 69 candles burning in various silver-gilt candelabra down the center of the table - surrounded by formations of silver dancing nymphs - but the whole extravaganza, known as the Portuguese service, was set off on the gleaming surface of a silver-gilt plateau 26 feet long.

A Black Theater Group Faces New Hurdles
LEAD: Twenty-three years ago, black American drama was not yet a part of the country's cultural milieu.
Largely unwelcome on Broadway, black playwrights had their work confined mainly to a few Off Broadway and Harlem-based theaters.
When the Negro Ensemble Company opened in Greenwich Village in 1967 - and in that inaugural year staged plays by Richard Wright and Wole Soyinka - it ushered black drama into the mainstream, helping to alter the nation's cultural landscape.

Shopping Isn't Fun For Retailers Either
LEAD: I can certainly appreciate Mr.
Fluhrer's complaint about the somewhat dubious joys of shopping during the holiday season [''Why Shopping in Department Stores Is No Fun,'' Opinion, Dec. 17] .
It is true that though we in the retail profession may deck the halls and staff the malls (as best we can in a tight labor market), shopping may not be the exhilarating experience one would wish for.


Diana Tasco Is Wed to John B. Meyer
LEAD: Diana Lee Tasco, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Frank J. Tasco of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Barry Meyer, the son of Beverly Barry Meyer of New York and John DeBard Meyer of Brooklyn.
The Rev.
James P. Swiader performed the ceremony at St.
Mary's Roman Catholic Church.


Assuaging Children's Fear of Surgery
LEAD: WHEN 10-year-old Amanda Bagatta of Smithtown was wheeled into the operating room for surgery to remove her tonsils and adenoids, her father went along with her, holding her hand along the way.
And he stayed in the operating room until the anesthetic had taken effect.


Textbook Gold
LEAD: HOLD THE OLD and the new textbooks in your hands and the difference is startling.

LEAD: The University of Miami will receive tangible evidence - a large, ornate silver bowl named after Gen.
Douglas MacArthur - to go along with its selection in the polls as the nation's No. 1 college football team.

Msgr.
Gerald A. Hughes performed the ceremony.

Baseball Notebook;   Yanks Champs! In 80's Payroll, That Is
LEAD: If there ever was any doubt that George Steinbrenner is the biggest spender in baseball, doubt it no longer.
The Yankees' owner spent so much more money on players in the 1980's than anyone else that the Players Association should erect a monument to him at Yankee Stadium in the form of a giant, 24-carat gold dollar sign.


Correction
LEAD: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Nov. 26 about airline-ticket prepay charges referred incompletely to their use.
The $25 charge, for reserving seats in advance but picking up tickets at the airport, is imposed by some airlines on passengers who reserve directly with them, not just those who reserve through travel agents.


Sensory Overload
LEAD: LIKE the Chimera of Greek mythology, multimedia - a combination of techniques, hardware, software and applications - is a fabulous creature comprising elements of several familiar beasts.
It encompasses computers, television, textbooks, libraries, overhead projectors and blackboards.
As electronic technology makes multimedia more sophisticated, it has become - depending on whom you ask - either the most revolutionary educational technology since the textbook, or a marketing buzzword concocted by computer makers to sell more machines.


Axie Gibbons Engaged to William E. Sutcliffe 3d
LEAD: The engagement of Anne Thomas Gibbons to William Edward Sutcliffe 3d has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Anne T. Gibbons of Fairfield, Conn., and Maxfield S. Gibbons of Greenwich, Conn.
Mr.
Sutcliffe is the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Sutcliffe Jr. of North Redington Beach, Fla.
A 1990 wedding is planned.


Health Costs Worry Hospitals and Business
LEAD: DESPITE the rising cost of employee health insurance that businesses in the county have had to pay in recent years, hospitals are reporting increasing financial losses and warning that quality health care is being jeopardized.


On Language;   Trick or Treaty?
LEAD: WE ALL REMEMBER the names of old battles and wars, but few of us are attuned to the nomenclature of peacemaking. ''Faraway Places With Strange-Sounding Names,'' as the song had it, form the basis of much of the language of treatying.
Worldly economists and geopolitical scientists - the sort of people who begin their questions with given and begin their answers with absent - like to stud their argot with pact-impact.

LEAD: With a collective click of their heels, hundreds of soldiers from Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega's disbanded army snapped smartly to attention today as their civilian President, Guillermo Endara, walked onto the grounds of the new Panamanian police force.


Artful Science
LEAD: IN HIS two published volumes of poetry, Roald Hoffman, a Nobel Prize-winning chemist and the John A. Newman professor of physical science at Cornell University, has struggled to unite the worlds of science and art, of reason and instinct.


Savory Fried Bread Of New Mexico
LEAD: WHETHER the visitor to New Mexico samples Spanish-American or American Indian fare, some form of simple native bread is likely to be offered with the meal.
The most ubiquitous forms are Indian fry bread, served at Indian pueblos or cultural centers, and sopaipillas - the puffed pillowlike breads served in most of the Spanish-American cafes and


Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Discard the old catalogues as the new ones arrive.
If the seed lists of plant societies have arrived, do not hesitate to check them over and mail orders promptly.
Start to plan next year's garden.
Be sure gift plants are kept out of drafts and cool; too much sunlight and overwatering will shorten their lasting time.


UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Japan;   Tokyo Broadens Plan to Aid A New Poland and Hungary
LEAD: In a signal of Japan's eagerness to take part in the emerging new order in Europe, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu plans next week to announce a package of more than $1 billion in loans and guarantees for Poland and Hungary, Japanese officials said today.


Charlotte Fans Should Study Amazing Mets
LEAD: They are booing the home team in Charlotte.
Can you believe it?
Until last year, they didn't even have a home team.
Now they are yowling at it.


The Russians Are Coming, in Droves
LEAD: As political developments seem to bring surprises every day in the Soviet Union, a surprising torrent of music from that country has been pouring our way on recordings.
Some of it, by Soviet artists, is attributable to a confusing tangle of international distribution agreements that followed the recent split-up of the Soviet Melodiya label and Mezhdunarodnaya Kniga, the Soviet export company that formerly handled the label and still owns several hundred titles from the Melodiya catalogue.

Failures Offer Lessons on Winning
LEAD: FAILURE - a word fraught with emotion, easily spoken in daily conversation, but feared by the person to whom it is applied.
Error, mistake, wrong, defeat, loss, all words that when directed at us evoke embarrassment and pain.
We are trained and culturally conditioned to want to succeed, to be the best, to win.


Uprooted by Blast, Gramercy Park Residents Return Home, to New Horrors
LEAD: Patti McCarthy returned home to Gramercy Park yesterday for the first time since she and others were forced out by a steam-pipe explosion last summer and found an elderly neighbor sobbing in the lobby, heartbroken by the condition of her apartment.
So Miss McCarthy asked another neighbor to go with her into her own apartment for support.


Prospects;   Housing Bounces Back
LEAD: Sales of new homes rose by 9.6 percent in November, the biggest jump in four months, according to the Commerce Department last week.
The Northeast and Middle West posted the strongest gains.
After months of soft prices and slow sales, do the November figures signal an end to the housing slump?
Four experts give their views.


Tour Grades From a Student
LEAD: The success of the College Preview Tour depends on the individual tour leader at each university.
The tour guide at Tufts was so enthusiastic about his school that he made me wonder why I had not previously considered it.
However, the guide at UConn gave the distinct impression that four years there could the worst four years of your life.


Our Suburban Children Could Learn Much From the Immigrants Among Us
LEAD: THIS new year is the 100th since the last of my ancestors left Eastern Europe to settle in Connecticut. 1990 is therefore a coming of age for my family, and I've been thinking how fitting it is that our anniversary falls during one the largest periods of immigration in recent American history.
These days, however, the immigrants often come from other directions: South America, the Caribbean and Asia.

FICTION
LEAD:
BOY, GIRL, BOY, GIRL.
By David Michaelis. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) Sam Simon is one of the first boys to enroll in Miss Little's School, a private all-girl academy.
The setting of this first novel is Concord, Mass., the time 1971 - and the prospects for adventure rich.
Which is not to say that Sam and his older brother, Murray, prosper in their new milieu.

Mutual Funds Turn to the Hard Sell
LEAD: Time was when the managers of the Janus Capital mutual fund group paid scant attention to their customers.
Cash-flow multiples and moving averages concerned them far more.
But faced with persistent redemptions, Janus concluded in 1987 that performance alone wasn't enough.
The marketing specialists came in, the advertising budget went up, and in 1989 the company's accounts doubled.


Broncos Aim to Stop Steelers' Momentum
LEAD: As the Denver Broncos head into the playoffs and take aim on a possible third Super Bowl appearance in the last four years, Coach Dan Reeves can take comfort in a rock-solid defense and productive running game, elements that generally win championships.
But he is not a satisfied coach.
Reeves is feeling obvious discomfort about his team's flaccid finish during the regular season.


HEIDEGGER FOR FUN AND PROFIT
LEAD: Martin Heidegger's centenary year has come and gone, and just as well.
It came at a bad time.
In Berkeley, New Haven, Moscow, Chicago, Paris and Marburg (and other places besides), conferences and parties have been celebrating the philosopher's birth.
Two or three years ago, when these jamborees were planned, it was still possible for most people to write off Heidegger's flirtation with Nazism as merely that - a foolish minor entanglement, which Hannah Arendt, who was briefly his lover, could generously attribute ''partly to the delusion of genius, partly to desperation.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different.
My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame.
When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside.

A Revolution Reshapes Movies
LEAD: Nothing that happened in the 1980's compares to the Videocassette Revolution, sometimes known as the VCR, a term also used to designate the appliance on which cassettes are played.
The VCR is turning the business of movies upside down and even affecting the kinds of movies we see.
Movies will never be the same again.

Food;   Celtic Cuisine
LEAD: AT MY FIRST WHIFF OF THE STEAMING GOLDENJU bowl of chowder thick with mussels, scallops ringed by coral roe, salmon and sole, I knew this was not the Ireland of old.
That was a place I'd visited many times for the sound of Gaelic, for warm folk and cold Guinness, but never for food.
A smoking peat fire, the slosh of fishermen's boots, a roaring laugh in Boluisce's Seafood Bar at Spiddal - all this was as familiar as the brine of wild Galway oysters.

Reviews/Music;   Playing Bowls of Water: An Indian Tradition
LEAD: The idea of filling bowls of different sizes with varying amounts of water so that each bowl produces a different pitch when struck, is both basic and ancient.
It is also fairly universal: makeshift instruments of this sort have appeared in many cultures, although few serious traditions of performance on such instruments have come down through the centuries.

LEAD: THE CHORUS of alarms over the deterioration of science education in American colleges has reached a crescendo.
A familiar air of crisis prevailed when the physical sciences faculty gathered for a special convocation at the University of California at Los Angeles last month to hear the Dean of Physical Sciences, Clarence Hall Jr., warn: ''Unless there is a revolution in the way we teach and the way we help students learn, it is obvious that the nation's economic standards will follow those of the test scores and the number of majors in math and physical science.

In Jazz, Two Steps Forward, One Step Back
LEAD: Jazz, through much of its history, has been seen by critics, fans and musicians as sticking close to a simple progression, where one stylistic innovation follows another.

From one generation to the next, these companies had always considered their market to be forever green.

Taxi Fares Increase Today
LEAD: Taxi fares in New York City are increasing today.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: THE United Nations has proclaimed 1990 International Literacy Year.
A fourth of the world's adults are illiterate, but the problem is not confined to developing nations.
Thirteen percent of Americans 20 years old and older are considered functionally illiterate.
The basic skills of functional illiterates do not reach beyond the fourth grade.

LEAD: SINGLE-HANDLE kitchen and bathroom faucets often feature replaceable cartridge valves.

CARTER REDUX
LEAD: The article on Jimmy Carter's new career was accompanied by brief biographies of other Presidents who had active public careers after their White House years.
You stated that John Quincy Adams was the only former President to serve in Congress.
However, Andrew Johnson was elected to the United States Senate from Tennessee in 1875, six years after his Presidential term ended.

LEAD: Greg Woodard scored a career-high 27 points tonight as Villanova took advantage of another poor shooting night by Syracuse and sent the Orangemen to their first loss of the season, 93-74.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
INVISIBLE MATTER AND THE FATE OF THE UNIVERSE.
By Barry Parker. (Plenum, $23.50.) Barry Parker explores what may be the ultimate mystery in ''Invisible Matter and the Fate of the Universe,'' combining history, astronomy, cosmology and physics.
Mr.
Parker, a professor of physics and astronomy at Idaho State University, traces a line of research from the first faint questions about our own galaxy's missing mass in 1932 to those questions' growth into a major concern for thousands of astronomers worldwide.

LEAD: Every business depends on forecasting, whether its executives know it or not.
How many new franchise stores should we open in 1990?
Will we have enough cash on hand in November to pay expenses?
Will our current staff be adequate to meet manufacturing demand in 1992?
When do we need to reorder widgets?

LEAD: A state grand jury has issued subpoenas to about a half dozen Exxon Corporation employees in New Jersey as law-enforcement officials continued a criminal investigation into the spill of at least 200,000 gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill, officials said today.


From Russia, In Love
LEAD: If the world needed one last sign of new warmth between East and West, it came last week.
Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of the cold war's first general, President Eisenhower, announced her engagement to Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a former chief of the Soviet space program.
The couple, who met at a conference on Soviet-American relations in 1987 and got to know each other better a year ago when she helped him work on his memoirs, admitted they had felt some trepidation about how officials in their countries would react.

Birds and Beasts Inhabit Mattatuck Show
LEAD: NOT all the animals in the ''Animal Show'' are recognizable, some being fragmentary, others outright inventions.

The small display, on view at the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury, consists of works by Reuben Nakian as well as by Eddie Oates, Karen Rossi, Gil Scullion and Peter Woytuk, Connecticut sculptors to a man and woman.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different.
My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame.
When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside.

A Dinner to Showcase a Fragrant Thai Curry
LEAD: ALTHOUGH curry usually brings to mind Indian food or dishes flavored with a premixed packaged spice blend, the term is actually an umbrella for a variety of preparations.
They do have in common a collection of spices, notably turmeric, cumin, coriander, ginger and pepper.
These are the main components, but the list can be expanded with many others.

LEAD: A small seaside hotel and an adjoining waterfront residence on Ocean Avenue in Ocean Grove, N.J., are being rehabilitated into 11 condominium apartments.
The Victorian-style hotel, built in 1870, and the home, built in 1920, had been used as rental apartment houses and had fallen into neglect when they were bought for $750,000 last summer by the Booth Development Company of Ridgewood, N.J.

LEAD: How much longer must New York City elections remain hobbled by outmoded manual voting machines prone to breakdowns?

Single-Handle Faucet Woes
LEAD: SINGLE-HANDLE kitchen and bathroom faucets often feature replaceable cartridge valves.
Signs that a cartridge faucet needs repair are water dripping from the spout, difficulty in adjusting the water temperature, hot water entering cold water outlets like toilet supply lines and inadequately heated water at some faucets.

Togetherness After the Age of Reason
LEAD: WHEN my children were young, we took separate vacations.
Each June I packed them off to their grandparents, a continent away, and when they returned, we were all glad to see each other again.
I'd had a respite from single parenthood, and they'd had a month of unqualified approval and unlimited indulgence.


After A Fashion
LEAD: Uniforms have long been synonymous with elite private schools.
Crisp white shirts, ties, gray slacks or pleated skirts gave students that satisfyingly neat and, well, uniform look.
But these days some public schools, too, are seeing salvation in standard student dress.
Uniforms or dress codes, they reason, will put an end to clothes-horse competitions.

The Invisible but Giant Indispensible Giant
LEAD: When the All-Pro or Pro Bowl teams are chosen, some specialists are hailed for their skills.
Place-kickers, punters, even special-team tacklers.
But never a blocking back.
Although success in football has been defined by coaches from Amos Alonzo Stagg to Bill Walsh as boiling down to blocking and tackling, there is no such species as the All-Pro blocking back or a Pro Bowl blocking back.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: MORE than 7 in 10 public-school teachers in the United States are women.
Moreover, male teachers seem to cluster in specific parts of the country - in the North, for example, which has more male teachers than the South.
Oregon, Minnesota, Washington State, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin have teaching forces that are about 38 percent male.


Riverhead's Grant To Buy Music Hall
LEAD: The article ''Riverhead May Lose $300,000 Grant'' (Dec. 10) states incorrectly that I, Harold Smith, am the owner of the 1881 Vail-Leavitt Music Hall.
In actuality, Music Hall is owned by the Council for the Vail-Leavitt Music Hall Inc., a nonprofit, tax-exempt organization that has been restoring and operating the building for the past six years without a deficit.


Eurobeep
LEAD: Little noticed among the rattling upheavals that dominate the news, the 12 nations of the European Community are formulating a plan to synchronize beepers.
Unsuspecting observers may see this as no more than sensible coordination, removing yet another barrier to the free movement of commerce in the Common Market.

CONFIDENT AT 11, CONFUSED AT 16
LEAD: THE ATMOSPHERE IN CAROLJU Gilligan's office at the Harvard Graduate School of Education could hardly be less like my own days as a Harvard graduate student - those seminars mired in torpor from which students were periodically roused by revivifying jolts of pedagogical bad temper.
Professor Gilligan's faculty and student colleagues at the Project on the Psychology of Women and the Development of Girls seem relaxed and almost unaccountably buoyant as they gather around the conference table on a rainy Cambridge morning to describe their current work.


THE NATION: New Rules;   California the Clean Faces Up to Corruption
LEAD: NEARLY three quarters of a century ago, as their state emerged from its rambunctious frontier days when money and water equaled power, Californians imposed strict new rules of government under the idealistic Progressive Party Governor, Hiram Johnson.
Provisions were made for the recall of elected officials, for lawmaking by public initiative and for nonpartisan local elections - measures emulated elsewhere and credited with having kept state politics comparatively honest.


New Zealand's Tougher Treks
LEAD: WHILE planning a recent hiking trip to New Zealand, I mulled the paradox of the Milford Track.
The three-day trek from lake to sea is so renowned for its scenic glories that it's billed as ''the most beautiful walk in the world.'' But the Milford is also a popular tourist destination and is strictly controlled by the authorities.


Pakistan Arrests Switchman In Worst Railroad Calamity
LEAD: The police have arrested a switchman in Pakistan's worst rail disaster, in which 307 people were killed and 700 injured when two trains collided in a station, officials said today.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different.
My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame.
When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside.
