POSTINGS: 14th for Newark;   New Airport Hotel
LEAD: Hampton Inns of Memphis is building a 154-room hotel near Newark International Airport, the 14th to serve the terminal's immediate area.
The $5 million facility on Route 1-9 in Elizabeth, N.J., facing an entrance to the airport, is expected to be finished in about a year.
Airport officials attributed part of a major increase in hotel business around the terminal to the growing practice among business executives of flying in, attending meetings overnight in conference rooms and returning home the next day.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: VERMONT earned the most from public college and university tuition for the 1988-89 academic year, collecting an average of almost $5,500 per student.
A large number of students at Vermont's public colleges are from another state and therefore pay the higher nonresident tuition.
California charged the lowest average tuition - about $500 per year.


A Dinner to Showcase a Fragrant Thai Curry
LEAD: ALTHOUGH curry usually brings to mind Indian food or dishes flavored with a premixed packaged spice blend, the term is actually an umbrella for a variety of preparations.
They do have in common a collection of spices, notably turmeric, cumin, coriander, ginger and pepper.
These are the main components, but the list can be expanded with many others.

Lige was ready to swear that the hill was haunted; never would go near the place at night, after what he said he saw there one time.

A Mother's Lot: Exhaustion
LEAD: I AM at home recovering from an illness.
My son's.
Nothing serious; just the usual virus that a 7-year-old seems to get every other month.
He's trying to see how far he can shoot up the mercury before Mommy passes out.
Anything less than 104 and he's toying with me.
Put the toys away, Mama. 105.


Pastimes;   Bridge
LEAD: The American Contract Bridge League has a membership of about 190,000 - just about what it was a quarter of a century ago.
But a downward trend has been reversed, thanks to a number of innovative efforts to attract new members.


Bed and Breakfast
LEAD: To the Editor: There are still a large number of reasonably priced B &amp; B's in both urban and rural areas.
There are plenty of people (probably the majority of B &amp; B travelers) who are not looking for all those luxuries and amenities offered by these so-called bed and breakfast places.
In my opinion such places should call themselves inns and omit the words bed and breakfast completely.

LEAD: We hardly knew each other.
He and his wife had left the city, as we had, relocating to this small town in upstate New York with the idea of finding cleaner air and less noise and russet-colored dogs in russet-colored leaves.
I had two young sons, he had three, and we shared the conviction that this small, clean, safe part of the world would insure our children ''a better way of life.

HAS FIFTH AVENUE BECOME BESIDE THE POINT?
LEAD: There is a fragility inherent in the symbolism of every great street in New York: Broadway stands for a theater that is perpetually in crisis, Wall Street for financial empires that seem ever ready to decamp to New Jersey, and Fifth Avenue, perhaps the most celebrated of them all, for a luxury and a style that once seemed unique to New York, but now feels more and more like what can be found in every medium-sized city and shopping mall from here to La Jolla.

LEAD: Marilyn Horne will be the guest soloist in a benefit concert by the New York City Gay Men's Chorus, March 1 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall.
Proceeds from the event will benefit the chorus's AIDS Outreach Fund, which makes donations to organizations that help people with AIDS.
The mezzo-soprano will sing Brahms's ''Alto Rhapsody'' and excerpts from ''L'Italiana in Algeri'' and ''Tancredi,'' both by Rossini.

In the Citadel, A New View of Jerusalem
LEAD: When King Herod ruled Judea, Jewish sages said of its capital, ''Whoever has not seen Jerusalem in its splendor has never seen a fine city.'' In fact the splendor of Jerusalem changed dramatically during the centuries under the influence of several major religions.
Today visitors can trace the city's history in a new museum actually woven into the ruins of its most ancient fortress.

FLASHCARD
LEAD: A 1989 study of elementary-school children in North Carolina found that teachers judged latchkey children (children who care for themselves after school) to be better adjusted than children with other after-school child-care arrangements.
Researchers at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro reported that teachers found no difference in the academic performance achievement of latchkey children and other students.


CAN HE SAVE THE ELEPHANTS?
LEAD: THE FLAT, KHAKI grasslands around Nairobi recede into the blue distance as the light plane piloted by the new director of Kenya's wildlife agency pushes north, past the snowy slab of Mount Kenya to the once magnificent Meru National Park.
Today, the park lies in tatters, most of its rhinoceroses and many of its elephants killed off.

This Year's Cold
LEAD: It makes you cough.
It makes you sweat.
It makes you stare aimlessly at telephones you can't find the strength to dial and at television channels you haven't the energy to switch.
It makes ''phlegm'' the buzzword of the week and possibly -heaven forfend - of the month.
It's the thing that's going around.

Shift of Control at Kao
LEAD: In an unusual move for a Japanese company, the Kao Corporation said Friday that it was shifting worldwide control of two divisions to the United States and West Germany.
A spokesman for the giant consumer products concern said the heads of the two divisions would be an American and a West German.
He said its floppy disk division would be controlled by its Kao Infosystems Company subsidiary in Hyannis, Mass., because sales of the disks in the United States were several times more than in Japan.

Reviews/Dance;   'Cortege Hongrois,' Big and Cheerful, From City Ballet
LEAD: George Balanchine created ''Cortege Hongrois'' in homage to Melissa Hayden on her retirement from the New York City Ballet in 1973.
His third nod to the ''Raymonda'' of his Imperial Ballet days in St.
Petersburg, ''Cortege Hongrois'' is an artificial blending of two elements of the third-act divertissements of ''Raymonda'' and a galloping salute to Russian ballet classicism, character dancing and spectacle.


Under Pressures and Stigma, More Doctors Shun Abortion
LEAD: Under siege from protesters and largely isolated from medical colleagues, doctors who perform abortions say they are being heavily stigmatized, and fewer and fewer doctors are willing to enter the field.


Market Place;   Stocks in Europe Start Year Strong
LEAD: THE stock markets in West Germany and Britain came out of the blocks like a shot this New Year's week, hitting record highs and carrying into 1990 much of the euphoria and buying sentiment of the end of last year.
But even as these markets were taking off, several analysts were waving a caution flag, expressing concerns about the effect of Europe's rising interest rates and doubts about the optimism that has greeted changes in Eastern


Counting on Congress
LEAD: Members of the 101st Congress, on average, showed up for 95 percent of the roll call votes in last year's session.
That was the highest rate of participation in the 36 years that Congressional Quarterly magazine has been keeping track.
At first glance, it might appear that the 101st is attending more to its legislative obligations.

Question Box
LEAD:
Dodger Managers
Q.
In the 51 seasons since Leo Durocher became their manager in 1939, the Dodgers - in Brooklyn and Los Angeles - have had only five full-time managers.
Has any nonexpansion team had as few in that span?
A.
The contest is not even close, for not even an expansion team has had fewer managers.

Review/Television;   The Life, Death and Secrets of Rock Hudson
LEAD: Having spent most of his life trying to keep his homosexuality secret, Rock Hudson ended up having his AIDS-related death sensationalized internationally.
No more hiding.
The all-American guy, the very image of handsome ruggedness, was gay.
Ironically, his death was a turning point in the strenuous efforts by concerned citizens, especially gay groups, to have serious attention focused on AIDS.

Collins and the Giants paid dearly for the change in strategy.

Researchers Prepare For Fist Human Tests Of an Artificial Lung
LEAD: A DEVICE that adds oxygen and removes carbon dioxide from the blood has been developed as a temporary artificial lung, ready for its first human tests.
The device is to be inserted in a vein in the groin or neck and then guided into the body's main vein in the chest, where it can stay in place for up to a week, easing the burden on the lungs while they heal.

LEAD: E. Leland Webber, who worked at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago as an usher at age 13 and eventually became its president, died of cancer Sunday in Evanston (Ill.) Hospital.
He was 69 years old and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

LEAD: Bill Curry, who resigned Sunday as head coach at Alabama, became the coach at Kentucky yesterday after his hiring was approved by the board of directors of the school's Athletics Association.

LEAD:
Mind Your Own
Q.What exactly is beeswax?
A.Beeswax is secreted by four pairs of glands under the abdomen of worker bees, said Roger Morse, chairman of the department of entomology at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y.

LEAD: Two water main breaks over the weekend - one at Waverly Place and Broadway, the other on Fifth Avenue between 18th and 19th Streets -disrupted utilities in the West Village and Chelsea.
Water and subway service have been restored, but the following services continue to be disrupted:
GAS. 5,000 customers in 450 buildings remain without gas service.


Judge Says Murphy's Movie Is Based on Buchwald's Idea
LEAD: A Superior Court judge ruled today that the Paramount Pictures Corporation must pay Art Buchwald for a script idea that the columnist contended was the basis for the hit movie ''Coming to America,'' which starred Eddie Murphy.
But the judge, Harvey A. Schneider, also said the studio had not acted in bad faith and was not obligated to pay the humorist millions of dollars in damages.


Avibras Industria
LEAD: Avibras Industria Aeroespacial S.A., one of Brazil's largest weapons makers, said today that it was seeking bankruptcy protection from its creditors.
The company said one client had owed it $40 million for more than a year.
People at Avibras identified the client as Iraq.
Avibras, a private company, said it had $100 million worth of equipment ready for shipment to the same client, which has not been shipped because of nonpayment of the debt.

LEAD: The chief regulator of nationally chartered banks said today that a significant number of consumer loans made by commercial banks were turning sour.

A Natural Laboratory on Hazards of Breathing Thin Air
LEAD: THE thin air atop this extinct volcano poses a potentially lethal hazard to workers at the numerous observatories proliferating on the mountaintop.
But the hazard has created an unusual opportunity to study the physiology of altitude sickness.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, two pictures on Saturday with coverage of Eastern Europe were reversed in some editions.
The picture of a large group carrying signs showed Muslims demonstrating in Bulgaria as protests over ethnic rights spread; the other picture on the same page showed people gathered in Prague discussing President Vaclav Havel's statement that Czechoslovakia owed Sudeten Germans an apology.

LEAD: Edward J. Ennis, a former Federal prosecutor who became chairman of the American Civil Liberties Union, died of complications of diabetes on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

Avondale Layoffs
LEAD: Avondale Industries, a Louisiana shipbuilder, laid off about 300 workers, and a company spokesman said another 615 workers might be released to cut costs.
The company, one of the nation's most active shipbuilders, has about 8,500 employees.
It has a $2 billion backlog of work, but much of it will not begin before later this year, the spokesman said.


Insider Case Accord Set
LEAD: A Connecticut man who is said to have traded on inside information obtained when one of his tenants opened someone else's mail agreed to pay almost $20,000 in fines and penalties, Federal officials said today.

In Shuffling Cards, 7 Is Winning Number
LEAD: IT takes just seven ordinary, imperfect shuffles to mix a deck of cards thoroughly, researchers have found.
Fewer are not enough and more do not significantly improve the mixing.


Careers;   Ever-Rising Demand for Paralegals
LEAD: THE Labor Department recently estimated that the need for paralegals would increase by 75.3 percent between 1988 and 2000, making paralegal work the nation's fastest-growing field.
Its projection: the 83,000 paralegals employed nationwide in 1988 will increase to 145,000 by the turn of the century because of rapid growth of the legal services industry as well as widening use of paralegals in corporations and elsewhere.

LEAD: In El Salvador, which too often resembles an army with a country attached, a conservative civilian President now links the military to a barbarous human rights crime.
In a nationally broadcast speech, Alfredo Cristiani said that ''elements'' of the armed forces were indeed involved in the November slaying of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter.

LEAD: A Newtown man convicted of killing his wife and shredding her body with a wood chipper was sentenced today to 50 years in prison after his sister complained he had shown no remorse.

Pacific Telesis Plan
LEAD: The Pacific Telesis Group said it would repurchase up to 25 million shares of its stock, totaling about $1.2 billion, based on Friday's closing price.
The stock rose $1.25 today, to $49, on the New York Stock Exchange. ''We continue to believe that repurchasing our stock at current prices is a very good investment for our shareowners,'' said Sam Ginn, Pacific Telesis's chairman and chief executive.

Orlando Ends Eight-Game Slide
Scott Skiles hit a 3-point shot and Otis Smith hit five free throws in the final 1 minute 9 seconds last night as the Orlando Magic ended a losing streak at eight games with a 111-102 victory over the visiting San Antonio Spurs.
The victory was only the third in the last 19 games for the expansion Magic, but all have come against division leaders.

White House Denies Plans For Blockade Off Columbia
LEAD: The Bush Administration said publicly today that it was not planning a naval blockade off Colombia as part of its fight against drug trafficking.
Some Colombian officials had accused the United States this weekend of moving toward a naval and air blockade.

LEAD: Paramilitary troops shot and killed at least 12 people today during anti-Indian riots in parts of the Kashmir valley, officials there said.

LEAD: In its largest eruption since reawakening last month, Redoubt Volcano hurled an anvil-shaped plume of steam and ash more than eight miles into the air today.


Doug Jones Arbitration
LEAD: Doug Jones, the Cleveland Indians' ace relief pitcher, is seeking $1.15 million in salary arbitration.
Jones, who last year earned $307,500, submitted that figure yesterday.
The Indians filed a salary of $950,000 for the pitcher, whose 69 saves the past two seasons are only 3 fewer than the 72 compiled by Mark Davis for San Diego.

'90 Detroit Church Closings
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit announced Sunday that it would close five more churches in the city this year.
The diocese closed 30 last year.
The five parishes were among 25 subjected to a yearlong test of viability by Edmund Cardinal Szoka.
Nineteen parishes passed the test and one new parish will be formed from two of those to be closed, said Jay Berman, a diocesan spokesman.

Grand Met Deal
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said it would buy 20 Wimpy restaurants in Britain and convert them to Burger King outlets.
In announcing the purchase from Allied Leisure P.L.C. of London, Grand Met said the sale was to be completed by Jan. 29.
No terms were disclosed.
In the last three months, Burger King has doubled the number of its outlets in Britain and now operates 60 restaurants there.

Topics of The Times;   Yankee Ingenuity
LEAD: Americans distressed by Japanese inroads into fields like automobiles and electronics sometimes find comfort in the Extrapolation Explanation.
They believe that the disciplined Japanese skillfully exploit known technologies to their fullest potential in the marketplace.
But, the theory goes on, it is stubbornly independent Americans who devise new technologies.

LEAD: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he had decided not to delay a new rule that would allow an option to be listed on more than one exchange in the United States.


Ruling Spares Utilities a Tax on Deposits
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the security deposits that many public utilities require of their customers are not taxable as income to the utilities.

Rawley Agrees to Pact
LEAD: The Boston Red Sox, trying to bolster their starting pitching rotation, reached agreement yesterday with Shane Rawley, a free agent whose 1989 team, the Minnesota Twins, chose not to sign him.
Rawley, a left-hander who earned $4.25 million in his previous five-year contract, accepted a nonguaranteed $350,000 salary.

Name Changes Decline
LEAD: The number of corporate name changes declined 14 percent last year, to 1,600, from a record 1,864 in 1988, according to a survey released Monday by Anspach Grossman Portugal Inc.
The 1989 total was the third highest in the 20 years that the identity-consulting firm has conducted its annual survey.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: MARTIN E. SULLIVAN has long admired the Heard Museum in Phoenix for its commitment to Indian culture.
Now, he is leaving his job as director of the New York State Museum in Albany and is to take up his new one as head of the Heard on March 1.


Topics of The Times;   Franking Frenzies
LEAD: With great fanfare, Congress last fall tightened lawmakers' free mailing privileges.
The Senate now gives itself $24 million for mass mailings for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1.
That's still high, but more reasonable than the $35 million spent last year.
Further, the old rules put no dollar cap on individual senators.

LEAD:
N.B.A.
Rare Victory for Suns Over Lakers
Kevin Johnson scored 10 of his 34 points in overtime, including four free throws in the final 10 seconds, as the Phoenix Suns beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 121-118, last night in Phoenix.
The Suns beat the Lakers for only the eighth time in their last 33 meetings, despite Magic Johnson's club-record-tying 24 assists.

LEAD: For 30 years, New York law enforcement officials and politicians have debated the sensible idea of folding the Transit Police into the larger New York City Police Department.

Two Guilty on Drug Charges
LEAD: A Federal jury in Manhattan yesterday convicted a Harlem man of leading a violent gang that dealt heroin.
The defendant, William R. Underwood, 46 years old, was found guilty of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, narcotics conspiracy and of being leader of a gang known as the Vigilantes.
The indictment accused the gang of committing six murders and of controlling street-level distribution of heroin in certain areas of Harlem from 1971 to 1988.

Children's Names: Mirror of a Society
LEAD: IF a child's name tells more about the parents than it does about the child, then the 1980's may well be remembered as a decade in which some parents were self-indulgent, ambitious, proud of their heritage and just a little outrageous.


Farm Debate to Center on Pesticides
LEAD: Proposals intended to make American agricultural practices safer and less polluting are likely to emerge as the most contentious issues in the Congressional debate over national farm policy, farm groups, trade organizations and influential farm policy makers say.


Review/Opera;   Balancing Farce and Poignancy In First 'Cosi' of the Met Season
LEAD: Opera as a medium of musical expression is apparently not dead.
The first ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' of the Metropolitan Opera's season on Monday evening proved this in a performance that effectively fluctuated between low farce and deepest poignancy.
Led by Carol Vaness, a Fiordiligi who showed the vocal and emotional range of a young Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, the cast struck a fine balance in a work that requires high-wire poise by all concerned.

Adding Noise to Cut a Car's Noise
LEAD: Automobile engineers seeking to make a car quieter have typically padded body panels with a bit of cloth or fiberglass and added rubber to motor mounts.
Now, researchers at Lotus Engineering in Britain have devised a way to cut interior noise with microphones and microchips, a technique dubbed ''anti-noise.


Rumania Seeks Trade Status
LEAD: The new Government said today that it would seek most-favored-nation trading status with the United States.
Nicolae Ceausescu, the executed dictator, renounced the American trade agreement in February 1988, when it appeared that Congress would not renew it because of rights abuses under Mr.
Ceausescu.


The U.S. and Panama: Civilian Dead;   The Invasion's Civilian Toll: Still No Official Count
LEAD: Nearly three weeks after United States troops toppled Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega's Government, killing what military spokesmen said were 314 of his troops, officials acknowledge that there is still no reliable count of how many Panamanian noncombatants died as a result of the fighting and street disorders.


C.P.A. Group Adopts Rule
LEAD: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants said yesterday that its members had approved a bylaw change to require all of its members who audit public companies to undergo regular reviews by their peers.
The measure was approved by 87 percent of those who voted, the group said.


Percentage of Blacks in South Rose in the 80's
LEAD: The percentage of black Americans living in the South increased in the 1980's for the first time in the 20th century, the Census Bureau reported today.

LEAD: The mourners listened solemnly to the song of praise for the deceased, a man who loved to dance.

LEAD: Boston College and Harvard, the preseason favorites in the East's Division I leagues, made auspicious moves after slow starts as the second half of the college hockey season commenced last week.


Sales of Genentech Drug Improve
LEAD: Genentech Inc. said today that sales of its main product, tissue plasminogen activator, grew 30 percent in 1989, to $196.4 million, compared with $151.4 million in 1988.

LEAD: Five astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia rocketed into orbit today on a complex mission to deploy one satellite and after an intricate three-day chase to retrieve another.

LEAD: As part of an extensive promotional effort to identify a forthcoming prime-time dramatic series as unusual television, ABC is considering broadcasting the two-hour premiere of ''Twin Peaks'' without any network commercials, Capital Cities/ABC executives said this week.
The show would include commercials sold by local television stations, however.

LEAD: The Justice Department said today that it planned to file an antitrust suit to block the Gillette Company's acquisition of the Wilkinson Sword wet razor blade business outside the European Community.

LEAD: TO some, 1984 may forever be linked to George Orwell and Big Brother, or to Ronald Reagan's landslide re-election, but on Wall Street it is remembered for the only slow and sustained decline in stock prices of the 1980's bull market.

LEAD: ''When [abortion]  was illegal, the fear was of losing my medical license and going to prison.

Curtis Boyd told a New York Times reporter recently.
Now, he said, ''the harassment is tremendous.
Every day I have to walk through picketers who call me a murderer.


13 Fewer Rigs Working
LEAD: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas dropped last week by 13, to a total of 1,029, Baker Hughes Inc., an oil-services company, said on Monday.
The number of working rigs a year ago was 872.
The weekly count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas, not those producing oil and gas.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: THE prospects are dim for a substantial bay scallop harvest in Long Island Sound this year.
The results of the devastating brown tide of 1988 linger, and the few bay scallops that survive will be exceedingly expensive.
Hence, sea scallops are in greater demand than ever.


Reviews/Dance;   A Mixed Troupe From Japan And the U.S.
LEAD: Ballet is very popular in Japan today.
And the 21 teen-age Japanese dancers who performed on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater in ''Young Ballet Dancers From Japan and New York'' were well trained and often personable.
But few were developed performers.
The performing highlight of the evening was the minxish Mihoko Sasao's easy and authoritative portrayal of the 19th-century Danish ballerina Lucile Grahn, in a staging of ''Pas de Quatre'' by Katsuko Okamoto.


New Move For Buyout Of UAL
LEAD: The management of the UAL Corporation and the unions at its United Airlines unit are preparing another effort to assemble a buyout proposal, people involved in their discussions said yesterday.

LEAD: In ''Clarence Darrow for the Defense,'' by Irving Stone, a passage has remained in memory as a striking and most unexpected dollop of good sense.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an alien detention center in Rosedale, Queens, referred incorrectly in some copies to comments by Susan Noreika, chairwoman of Community Board 13.
She said the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Wackenhut Corrections Corporation, the private company that operates the center, should have notified the community of their plans to establish it but were not legally required to do so.

LEAD: Citing a limited potential for growth, Tarlow Advertising has resigned the $1 million trade advertising account of Cosmopolitan magazine. ''I want us to be working in areas where if you a do a great job, you reap the benefits,'' said Dick Tarlow, the agency's president.
George H. Simpson, a spokesman for Cosmopolitan, said creative differences had existed as well.

He replaces David P. Jaicks, who was named chairman of the division.

Late Drop Sends Dow Down 28.37, to 2,766
LEAD: Stocks ended sharply lower yesterday as trading accelerated near the close of the session.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 28.37 points, to 2,766.


EX-DEFENSE CHIEF OF PERU IS KILLED
LEAD: A former Peruvian Defense Minister was shot and killed today, and security officials said Maoist guerrillas were responsible.


Computer Chaos Called Mistake, Not Felony
LEAD: A Cornell University student made a ''mistake'' in allowing a computer program he designed to go wild and paralyze a national computer network, his lawyer told jurors today in opening arguments at his felony trial.


Brooklyn Teen-Ager Killed For Failing to Give a High-5
LEAD: A 15-year-old died early yesterday after being shot Monday night in Brooklyn in a feud that started when he refused to give another youth a high-five greeting, the police said.


CBS Ends Contract Of Program Executive
LEAD: CBS announced yesterday that it has reached an agreement with Barbara Corday, the executive vice president of programs, to terminate her contract.
Her departure completes a housecleaning of the top ranks of the CBS Entertainment division.
The head of the division, Kim LeMasters, resigned under pressure in December and was replaced by Jeff Sagansky.


Students' Skills Termed 'Dreadfully Inadequate'
LEAD: Despite the efforts made in the 1980's to improve schools, the reading and writing skills of American students remain ''dreadfully inadequate,'' Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said today in releasing the latest results of a national education assessment.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Business People column on Monday about a new chief operating officer at the Centex Corporation misidentified the company's chairman.
He is Paul R. Seegers.


Patients to Benefit From Reforms for Interns;   No Way to Learn
LEAD: To the Editor:


A Rich New Biotech Frontier
LEAD: Biotechnology companies are developing potentially revolutionary new treatments for rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, multiple sclerosis and other disorders in which the body's disease-fighting system attacks the body's own tissues.


Mexico Inflation Rate
LEAD: Mexico's inflation rate was 19.7 percent last year, the country's lowest since 1978, the Government announced Monday.
Thus, Mexico ended the year meeting its goal of keeping inflation at 18 percent to 20 percent, the Government said in a report.


Treasuries Finish Little Changed
LEAD: Concern about a rush of new longer-term securities continued to build in the credit markets yesterday as dealers prepared to place bids on $7.5 billion of seven-year Treasury notes.


U.S. Forgives Portion Of Kenya's Loan Debt
LEAD: The United States today formally agreed to forgive all economic-assistance loans to Kenya, as part of an effort to give economic relief to Africa, including some of the continent's poorest countries.

LEAD: *
Bruce I. Carlson has been named chairman of Grant/Jacoby Advertising, Chicago, replacing Robert L. Flink, who is retiring.
R.
Milton Lynnes will replace Mr.
Carlson as president.

LEAD: Despite American objections, France has decided to become the first Western country to send its diplomats back to Afghanistan, French and American officials said today.

He was 70 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: Doug Graber, a stranger to New Jersey and Rutgers football, was named today as the head coach of the Scarlet Knights.


Coke Settles Case in Europe
LEAD: The European Community Commission said Tuesday that it had closed an anti-competition case against the Coca-Cola Company, satisfied that the soft-drink maker had ended anti-competitive practices in the European Community.


CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: A FRIEND said once that he wished I'd write about men.
But I will have nothing to say, I protested.
I don't make gender distinctions.
I think about men the same way I think about women: I either like somebody or I don't.
Neither sex has a premium on any one quality.
I couldn't possibly begin a sentence with ''Men are .


Surprise and Skepticism On Campeau Payments
LEAD: Executives at some of Seventh Avenue's largest fashion houses were pleasantly surprised and elated yesterday when the Toronto-based Campeau Corporation notified them that they were going to be paid for goods shipped in December.


Farm Credit Issues Total $635 Million
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced at par a total of $635 million in consolidated systemwide bonds with maturities of three years and five years.

U.S. to Pare War Games in South Korea
LEAD: The United States and South Korea will reduce the size of their annual joint military maneuvers to improve the climate for negotiations between North and South Korea, President Roh Tae Woo said today.


From Nissan, The Future On Wheels
LEAD: THOSE taking the pulse of future automobile design often look beyond industry soothsayers to concept cars.
If Nissan Design International Inc.'s Gobi concept car, introduced last week at the North American International Automobile Show in Detroit, is any indication, trends for the 1990's will include soft squeezable materials and a separation of components vaguely reminiscent of deconstructivism.


Beijing's Very Small 'Big Event'
LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng presents China's lifting of martial law in Beijing as ''a big event.'' And the Bush Administration claims it as vindication of Brent Scowcroft's recent highly visible visit to Beijing.
They are wrong.


Note Cards Created For a Cause
LEAD: INSPIRED by Unicef, the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS has recently published a series of 12 boxed note cards by leading graphic designers.
Under the aegis of ID Magazine, the designers - Neville Brody, Ivan Chermayeff, April Greiman, Milton Glaser, Michael Vanderbyl and M &amp; Co. - were asked to create cards that could symbolize the foundation.


New Jersey Casinos Fight Plan for Taxes On Gifts to Gamblers
LEAD: Atlantic City's casinos today tried to head off talk of a new tax on the complimentary items they dole out to high rollers with a study that they say shows Nevada is a far more hospitable place to do business.

RJR Completes Sale of Del Monte
LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. has completed the previously announced $1.5 billion sale of its Del Monte unit to a Merrill Lynch group.
The sale, RJR said, substantially completes its plan to reduce debt through asset sales.


F.D.A. Withdraws Approval for Jarvik-7 Heart
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has withdrawn its approval of the continued experimental use of the Jarvik artificial heart because of deficiencies found in the manufacturer's plant operations, an FDA spokesman said today.

School District Won't Eat Tuna
LEAD: Aurora's schools have crossed tuna off the lunch menu at the behest of a dozen students who object to fishermen's using nets that can drown dolphins.
An associate district superintendent, Dave Zeckser, who approved the ban, said the 43 schools use 40 cases of tuna a year.
The 26,000-student district is following the lead of schools in Milford, Conn., where a tuna boycott was begun as part of a nationwide effort to pressure fishermen into using fishing lines instead of nets.


Washington Journal;   The Dress for Success A Second Time Around
LEAD: ''Secondhand Rose,'' the Fanny Brice song of pluck and pathos, has become an anthem of the up-and-coming here, with two Capitol Hill consignment stores doing land-office business reselling the pinstripes of the powerful.


Siemens Buying 51% Of Nixdorf
LEAD: Siemens A.G., the West German electronics giant, said today that it would acquire a majority stake in Nixdorf Computer A.G.


HONG KONG CAMPS TERMED INHUMAN
LEAD: An American refugee monitoring group said today that conditions in Hong Kong's closed detention camps for Vietnamese, where more than 44,000 men, women and children are imprisoned, were ''inhuman.''


Bells, Whistles, Microchips
LEAD: THE glittering gold and crimson arch on the main floor of the Winter Consumer Electronics Show here last weekend seemed the entrance to a vast electronic casino filled with 70,000 players.
Like the darkened game rooms just a short ride away, it was full of diversions, deals and flashing lights.


Seven-Year Notes Well Received
LEAD: A successful auction of $7.5 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes helped to bring prices in the credit markets off their lows yesterday.
As a consequence, prices in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds closed narrowly mixed.


LAOS IS COURTING NEW BENEFACTORS
LEAD: Laos, one of the world's least-developed countries by the standards of the United Nations, is seeking several sources of foreign aid to replace assistance from Communist countries that now have other preoccupations.


Tokyo Market Uneasy On Fears About Soviets
LEAD: Fears about political turmoil in the Soviet Union helped undermine a record-setting stock market rally, causing prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange to skid over the last week in an increasingly nervous investment climate.


Metro Matters;   Out-of-Towners Vs. New Yorkers: Vying for Posts
LEAD: Lee P. Brown, Joseph A. Fernandez and Alan F. Kiepper have something in common besides being named to the three most prominent appointive public posts in New York City: None is a New Yorker.


Chronicle
LEAD: Treasury Secretary NICHOLAS F. BRADY is back at work on crutches this week, a little more than three weeks after he had surgery to replace his right hip.
Mr.
Brady, 59 years old, had suffered from arthritis for many years and had begun to walk with a pronounced limp.


Exxon Names Executive on the Environment
LEAD: The Exxon Corporation yesterday named Edwin J. Hess, a veteran executive, as corporate vice president for the environment and safety, the first time it has elevated environmental concerns to the senior executive level.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about AIDS in Texas rendered the numbers incorrectly in a state legislator's comment on the idea of adding $48 million to spending on AIDS programs.
Apparently unable even to imagine an increase of that size, the legislator said, ''Four to eight million - why, that's unthinkable!

European and Asian Buyers Push Gold Sharply Higher
LEAD: Precious metals prices climbed yesterday, led by increased demand for gold in Europe and Asia.


Asiana in Tokyo Debut
LEAD: South Korea's fledgling second airline, Asiana, made its inaugural international flight today when a Boeing 737-400 flew to Tokyo from Seoul with 147 passengers, a company spokesman said.
The private airline, competing with Korean Air Lines, also privately owned, will fly to Tokyo four times a week.

LEAD: The board of the Campeau Corporation met today for the third day in a row, amid great secrecy, to consider its options in the face of the possible bankruptcy confronting its American retail subsidiaries.

Hallmark Cards In Stock Buyback
LEAD: The greeting card giant Hallmark Cards Inc. said it had bought back $289 million of its own stock from the Hall family and from the company's employee stock ownership plan.
The stock was bought Dec. 28 with ''available corporate cash reserves,'' a Hallmark spokesman, Steve Doyal, said.
The shares were repurchased so the employee plan would have enough cash to pay for future retirements, he said.

A.T.&amp;T. Sues MCI; Says Rival Switched Clients
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a lawsuit yesterday charging its main rival, the MCI Communications Corporation, with ''unfair and deceptive'' marketing practices and with switching some of A.T.&amp;T.'s residential customers over to MCI's long-distance network without the consumers' consent.


Tyson Promoter Sued
LEAD: Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, a heavyweight contender, and Murad Muhammad, his promoter, are suing Don King, the promoter for the heavyweight champion Mike Tyson, for breach of contract.


Canadian Pacific's D.&amp;H. Bid Chosen
LEAD: Canadian Pacific Ltd. won the right to buy the bankrupt Delaware &amp; Hudson Railway for $35 million, beating five other bidders.
Francis P. Dicello, a Washington lawyer who is the trustee of the D.&amp; H., announced his selection of Canadian Pacific in United States Bankruptcy Court.


Cutbacks by Ames
LEAD: Ames Department Stores Inc. cut 85 jobs in its corporate offices and announced plans to rename the last surviving Zayre stores as Ames outlets.
The discount retailer, acknowledging that it had overestimated customer loyalty to the 392 Zayre stores it bought in 1988, also said that a sluggish fourth quarter would prevent the company from showing a profit this year.


Doubt Raised on Noriega Prosecutor
LEAD: When Dexter Lehtinen took charge of the United States Attorney's office here 18 months ago he pictured himself as a battlefield commander.
At one meeting he waved a replica of a Russian-made AK-47 assault rifle and circulated a two-sentence message: ''No Guts.
No Glory.''

LEAD: In new research into the bonds between humans and animals, therapists are discovering that pets provide unexpected psychological benefits for children beyond the obvious.

Egyptian Bonds Are Selling Slowly
LEAD: Egypt has sold only 11 percent of the new dollar bonds it issued in November but is optimistic that it will eventually find buyers and create a new capital market, Mahmoud Abdel-Aziz, deputy chairman of the National Bank of Egypt, said today.

LEAD: THE Social Register would seem to be an unlikely place to look when predicting the course of a takeover battle.

Chronicle
LEAD: STU JACKSON, the coach of the New York Knicks, became a father a day earlier than planned yesterday when his wife, DR.
JANET TAYLOR, gave birth to twin girls by Caesarean section at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y.
The girls, still unnamed, weighed 6 pounds 10 ounces and 4 pounds 8 ounces.


Lean Budget Plan in California
LEAD: Gov.
George Deukmejian today proposed a lean $53.7 billion budget for California, calling for freezes in spending on health, welfare, AIDS programs and other social services.


Kenya Stressing Tea
LEAD: Kenya said Tuesday that it would increase payments to its tea producers in an apparent bid to increase output of the commodity.
President Daniel arap Moi announced that the Government would raise its initial payment to tea farmers some time this month to 3 shillings (14 cents) a kilogram (2.2 pounds) from 1.9 shillings (9 cents).

LEAD: The Devils were so efficient in every aspect of their game tonight in their 6-3 triumph over the Penguins that it infuriated Mario Lemieux.

From Concert Operas to Cliburn, Carnegie Plans a Starry Season
LEAD: Carnegie Hall announced details yesterday of its star-studded 1990-91 centennial season, which will include an ambitious concert-opera series, 14 newly commissioned compositions, the return of Van Cliburn to the hall stage, a six-week folk-music festival in Weill Recital Hall and a 10-day festival culminating in a gala concert on the hall's 100th anniversary on May 5, 1991.

BRIEFS
LEAD:
Debt


In the East Bloc, It's Trade or Fail
LEAD: Moscow's proposal that members of Comecon, the Soviet-led trade bloc, begin trading at market prices is a sign that the old order is crumbling.
To help fill the void, the West should move quickly to encourage new forms of economic collaboration among Eastern European nations.
Otherwise, support for democratic government and for reform itself could be undermined.


Albany's Optimism Wanes As Budget Shortfall Grows
LEAD: After several months of maintaining what analysts said was an overly optimistic view of New York's finances, the Cuomo administration today acknowledged that the state would end the fiscal year with a shortfall of almost $700 million.


Noriega Associate in Sanctuary


Calls Abroad May Cost Less
LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation today announced cut-rate calling plans to Western Europe, the Pacific and Canada.
The plans - Call Europe, Call Pacific and Call Canada -will provide flat per-minute rates on weekdays and all weekend for a $3 monthly fee, MCI said.


Chronicle
LEAD: MARGARET E. MAHONEY, president of the Commonwealth Fund, will be the first woman to serve as a trustee of the Century Association.
She is on the unopposed slate - all the others are men - that is to be elected tonight at the club's annual meeting in Manhattan.


No Special Shield for Universities
LEAD: The Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that universities, as employers, enjoy no special exemption from civil rights laws that allow Federal investigators to see their personnel files.
It is a correct decision, even if too glibly dismissive of serious arguments for confidentiality in academic employment decisions.

To Avoid Measles: A Vaccination Guide
LEAD: Here is a summary of the new measles vaccination recommendations issued by the Federal Centers for Disease Control:
Each child should get two doses of measles vaccine, the first at 15 months and the second just before entering kindergarten or first grade.
If a child lives in a high-risk area, where five or more cases a year have been reported for last five years, the first dose should be administered at 12 months.

Hong Kong's Governor Seeking to Ease Strain
LEAD: Hong Kong's Governor, Sir David Wilson, arrived today in Beijing for three days of talks with Chinese leaders intended to ease the hostility and recriminations that have developed between China and Hong Kong since the military crackdown in June.


Results Plus
LEAD:
N.B.A.
Celtics End Piston Streak
Reggie Lewis capped a season-high 32-point performance with 5 points in the final two minutes as Boston ended visiting Detroit's six-game winning streak with a 104-97 victory last night.
Kevin McHale, who added a season-high 30 points, had two key rebounds and four free throws in the last 15 seconds after Lewis's foul shot with 15.8 seconds left put Boston ahead 100-97.

LEAD: The Mexican Government has relaxed rules on technology transfers, removing obstacles to imports and ending limits on royalties, according to published reports Tuesday.

OPEC Output at High
LEAD: Oil production by the OPEC nations rose to an average of 23.7 million barrels a day in the last quarter of 1989, the highest level since early 1981, the International Energy Agency said on Tuesday.

LEAD: President Bush will travel on Jan. 19 to Atlanta for a speech and Miami for a fund-raising dinner for Gov.
Bob Martinez of Florida.
Mr.
Bush's Atlanta speech will be to the National Association of Homebuilders, the White House said.

LEAD: DAN GRAHAM'S photographs of suburban tract houses and model-home interiors explore the cliches of the 1960's, ''the ticky-tacky houses that the folk singers sang about,'' said the 47-year-old artist, who grew up in, yes, the suburbs.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Unisys Corporation said separately yesterday that they had set up special units to help customers manage computer operations.

LEAD: The Ralston Purina Company said it would establish a new division for its specialty pet food unit and to promote its premium Pro Plan pet foods.
Pro-Visions Pet Specialty Enterprises will market Pro Plan products to pet shops, feed stores and veterinarians, the company said.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Keeping Decks Young
Q.
Three years ago we built a wood deck onto our house.
To help preserve it we have always swept off snow as soon as it accumulates.
Now we have decided to enlarge the deck and realize that constantly sweeping snow will become quite a job.
Do we need to keep doing this, or does it really matter if the snow is allowed to remain?


Who's Demagoguing Capital Gains?
LEAD: ''I am sick and tired of the demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich.'' Thus President Bush blasted critics of his plan to cut the capital gains tax.
But such talk shouldn't frighten the critics, who have a lot to offer Mr.
Bush on this subject - if he'd only, well, cut out the demagogy.


Stocks Continue to Slide; Dow Off by 15.36
LEAD: The stock market continued to retreat yesterday on sharply higher volume.


PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: FOR many adults, the amount of money they make and how they choose to spend it is the most private of affairs.
Money is a topic laden with symbolism, a source of pride or of shame, a standard for measuring success and competence after concern with school grades or football touchdowns has passed.
It also brings about conflicting feelings of competitiveness between parents and children, who can be both proud and jealous of each other's success.

LEAD: The American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation, which include some of the nation's most famous department stores, said yesterday that they had met a deadline for paying suppliers for December merchandise.

Peterson is a wholehearted hard-bop revivalist, working in the style of Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers and the mid-1960's Miles

LEAD: THE Staffordshire dog slammed against the wall is bound for an oblivion it well deserves.
The topiary deer suffers a decapitation as merited as Marie Antoinette's.
As for the glitzy chandelier in ''The War of the Roses,'' that appalling confection looks better smashed into smithereens as the movie ends.

LEAD: Panama's new civilian Government signed an accord with the United States today in which it pledged to cooperate in efforts to crack down on narcotics trafficking and money laundering.

LEAD: Dr.
Veronica Prego calmly recounted yesterday her four years of terrifying uncertainty from the time she pricked her finger with an AIDS-contaminated needle at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn to the day she learned she had contracted the disease.

An Office Tower On Park Ave. Will Be Rebuilt
LEAD: The 32-story former ITT building in Manhattan will be redesigned and substantially rebuilt starting early next year, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday, making it ''the first new building project on Park Avenue in more than a decade.''


Metro Datelines;   Part of 5th Ave. Shut In Search for a Leak
LEAD: Fifth Avenue from 34th to 28th Streets was closed yesterday afternoon as engineers from the Environmental Protection Department searched for a water leak.
A leak was reported at 12:20 P.M. in a building at 29th Street, and a crew opened a valve too wide and overloaded sewer lines, a spokeswoman for the department, Tina Casey, said.


Richard P. Hayes, Theater Teacher, 60
LEAD: Richard P. Hayes, a theater arts teacher and drama critic, died after a heart attack on Monday in his Manhattan home.
He was 60 years old.


Insurers Seek Help for Uninsured
LEAD: Under pressure from government, business and consumer critics, many of the nation's health insurance companies are calling for new Federal and state laws to provide more affordable coverage for millions of working Americans who have no insurance.


N.C.A.A. Stiffens Drug Penalties And Expands Testing in Football
LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association voted overwhelmingly today to require random, year-round testing of players in major football programs for performance-enhancing drugs, and to impose stiffer penalties for violators, in any sport, of the N.C.A.A.'s drug policies.


Lead Effects Still Harmful Over Years
LEAD: Young adults who were exposed to lead early in life have trouble reading and finishing high school, suggesting that even relatively small amounts can cause permanent brain damage, a new study indicates.

LEAD: Barry Lyons and the Mets agreed yesterday to a one-year contract for $220,000, almost double Lyons's 1989 salary of $115,000.
The catcher batted .247 last season. . . .
John Candelaria of the Montreal Expos became the second player to file for salary arbitration. . . .
Rafael Santana, released by the Yankees, joined the Cleveland Indians with a one-year nonguaranteed contract for $250,000.

LEAD: Several governors whose states have already cut the air pollution causing acid rain today denounced a plan that would have them help pay for reducing the problem in other parts of the country.

LEAD: The embattled chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., announced today that his staff director, Kevin C. Gottlieb, will resign March 1 and be succeeded by Stephen B. Harris, the committee's general counsel.

LEAD: Confusion over the case of Charles Stuart increased today as an insurance company denied a report that it had prepared a $480,000 check for Mr.
Stuart, whose pregnant wife was shot to death last October.

LEAD: THE National Endowment for the Arts has published a resource for designers, ''By Design 2,'' that describes all the design projects it sponsored from 1977 to 1987.

LEAD: The MD-11, a new wide-body jetliner from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, is ready for flight.
The plane is the first new trijet introduced since the Douglas DC-10 and Lockheed L-1011 two decades ago.

LEAD: A legal move to force New York City and State to provide drug treatment to anyone who demands it has been dismissed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

LEAD: Three non-Communist parties in East Germany's Government threatened today to leave the coalition if the Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, did not hasten reforms and abandon efforts to create a new domestic security force to replace the one that was disbanded.

LEAD: A memorial service for the writer and critic Seymour Krim is to be held on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets.

Businessland Cuts
LEAD: Businessland Inc., a leading computer retailer, is expected to announce substantial layoffs at a news conference Thursday and may close some of its less active stores, people close to the industry said.
The move by Businessland, based in San Jose, Calif., comes as personal computer sales have softened nationwide, but also stems from the chain's loss of the Compaq Computer Corporation account in April, said Seymour Merrin, a computer retail consultant.

LEAD: Bowing to Soviet pressure, the United Nations Secretariat has agreed to suspend the informal contacts it has conducted for several months with Baltic nationalist groups seeking independence from Moscow, a senior official has announced.

Royal International Acquisition Is Set
LEAD: The Royal International Optical Corporation said it had an agreement to be acquired by the privately held U.S.
Vision Inc.
Royal said the holders of up to 80 percent of its shares would receive $12.50 a share.
Holders not electing to receive cash will receive one common share of the merged company for each Royal share.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about competition among New York department stores misstated the amount of debt held by R.H.
Macy &amp; Company when it bought the California-based Bullock's and I. Magnin stores in May 1988.
It was $3.5 billion, not $7 billion.
Macy's current debt is $4.8 billion.

LEAD: Eleven months ago, a team of doctors performed an abortion on a comatose Long Island woman, Nancy Klein, in a desperate attempt to help her chances of recovery.
The operation culminated a wrenching two-week court battle for her husband, who fought opponents of abortion all the way to the Supreme Court to gain legal guardianship of his 32-year-old wife and the right to decide on her abortion and, perhaps, her last chance for life.

The company plans to expand its ownership of hotels in overseas cities where it flies or plans to fly, the spokesman said.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 483 money market mutual funds surged by $6.82 billion, to $375.23 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 144 institutional funds increased by $1.91 billion, to $90.14 billion.
The assets of the 241 general-purpose funds were up by $1.26 billion, to $124.50 billion.

Fewer Flights, but More Air Traffic Delays in 1989
LEAD: The number of air traffic delays rose sharply last year, especially at the nation's five most congested airports, Government officials reported yesterday.
Aviation experts found the figures particularly disturbing because delays increased even though the number of flights fell slightly.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the winner of a $35 million Lotto prize misstated the Federal tax he will have to pay.
While 20 percent will be withheld from his 21 annual checks, the actual tax owed would be 28 percent under current Federal law.

LEAD: Three members of a personal-injury law firm in Manhattan have been indicted on Federal charges that they falsified evidence and bribed witnesses to lie in 19 accident cases dating to 1979, United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney announced yesterday.
Four private investigators and an office manager for the firm were also charged.

Her ambition, once fired, has no limit.

Review/Music;   American Composers Orchestra
LEAD: Listening to the concert of the American Composers Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, one couldn't help but reflect on a curious argument that seems to be gaining currency: that the symphony orchestra, as an outgrowth and repository of European musical tradition, is an artificial overlay on American culture, superfluous if not subversive of homespun values.


Review/Music;   A Collection Of Keyboard (Neo)Classics
LEAD: The ''Evening of 20th-Century Keyboard Classics'' offered on Monday at Merkin Concert Hall was eccentric in its length and juxtaposition of diverse performing forces.
It might also have been better named ''An Evening of 20th-Century Keyboard Neo-Classics.'' But it was full of good music well performed, and it built to two really excellent combinations of creation and re-creation at the end.

LEAD: President Vaclav Havel's third-floor office in the Prague Castle these days has the urgent chaos of a theater stage the day after opening night.
Mail is piled on the floor.
Young secretaries and assistants rush in and out.
Unwanted paintings stand around against the wall like discarded scenery.
Telephones ring and ring and often go unanswered.

LEAD: Charles Stuart asked one of his brothers to help him kill his wife ''weeks before'' she was fatally shot on Oct. 23, a lawyer for the brother said today.


Philips Industries Sees Lower Profit
LEAD: Philips Industries announced it expects lower third-quarter earnings, casting a shadow over its planned buyout deal with a Merrill Lynch unit, analysts said. ''Merrill Lynch may use this as an opportunity to restructure the deal or reprice the deal,'' said Elliot Schlang of Prescott, Ball &amp; Turben Inc.


Far Out in Space, a Giant Discovery
LEAD: Astronomers reported today that they had confirmed the existence of one of the largest concentrations of galaxies and matter ever found.
The finding could change the way astronomers think about the structure of the universe.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
COMPANIES
The directors of the Campeau Corporation took steps to allow the company's American retailing divisions to operate independently.
After four days of meetings at the company's Toronto headquarters, the directors said Campeau's U.S. operations would be overseen by a new board, with a majority of American residents.


Carolyn Haywood, 92, Illustrator And Author of Children's Books
LEAD: Carolyn Haywood, a popular author and illustrator of children's books who is best known for her ''Betsy'' and ''Eddie'' series for 7-to-10-year-olds, died of a stroke yesterday at her home in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia.
She was 92 years old.


Photography: Images of Past and Future
LEAD: The observance of photography's 150th anniversary may have ended in December, but you wouldn't know it from the number of exhibitions of photographs on view this month.
It's as if a brand new season has begun in the art world, with photographs once again playing a major role.
There's a feeling of fresh possibility in the air, in part because the 1980's are now history, and in part because history itself -in particular, the history of art - suddenly seems a subject on artists' minds.


2 File for Arbitration
LEAD: Wally Joyner, the California Angel first baseman, and Juan Nieves, a Milwaukee Brewer left-hander, filed for salary arbitration yesterday, leaving 184 players still eligible to file by the deadline next Tuesday.
Arbitration hearings will be scheduled for the first three weeks of February.

LEAD: Pressing for a way to restore its credibility with creditors and suppliers, the directors of the Campeau Corporation took steps last night to allow the company's American retailing divisions to operate independently.

LEAD: J. P. Morgan &amp; Company yesterday reported sharply lower profits in its fourth quarter and a loss for the year.

Breitenstein is not sure whether to follow through on his decision or stay and support the dwindling


Ann Stringer, 71, Dies; A War Correspondent
LEAD: Ann Stringer, a war correspondent who in 1945 transmitted the first report of the linkup of American and Russian forces, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Skyrest Nursing Home in Carbondale, Ill.
She was 71 years old and had lived until 1987 in Manhattan and Amagansset, L.I.


F.B.I. SETTLES SUITS BY BLACK WORKERS ON DISCRIMINATION
LEAD: In what appears to be a significant admission of racial problems within the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the agency has reached out-of-court settlements in recent months in major discrimination cases involving black employees.


Savings Unit Seized by U.S.
LEAD: Federal regulators today seized Atlantic Financial Federal, Pennsylvania's largest savings institution, transferring control to a new agency created to handle failing or troubled institutions.


New Dances Explore Offbeat Themes
LEAD: YOU can see a dance this weekend called ''I'm a Frayed Knot,'' inspired by Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''Scarlet Letter.'' Home videos are featured in another dance, ''Malad Justed,'' in which a fish responds to Navy war exercises in its sea.
But two other dances, by choreographers known for their individualism, will tackle relatively familiar dance subjects - women and clowns.


Japan Seen Extending Auto Quotas
LEAD: The Japanese Government is expected to announce soon that it will extend its ''voluntary'' quotas on automobile exports to the United States, but Japan's major manufacturers note that the action is now an annual political gesture that has no effect on the sales of Japanese cars.


Trophy for Montana
LEAD: Joe Montana, the National Football League's top quarterback, won the Jim Thorpe Trophy yesterday as the league's most valuable player.
He is the third successive San Francisco 49er player to win the award, following Roger Craig and Jerry Rice.

LEAD: In the worn old corridors of New York's City Hall these days, police guards at the metal gate outside the Mayor's wing are armed not only with pistols but with newspaper pictures of new deputies and commissioners, to avoid the embarrassment of stopping the wrong people.

LEAD: A robber got more than he bargained for when he held up a convenience store on Wednesday and ran into Billy Conn, the 72-year-old former light-heavyweight champion, the police said.

New York City Study Of Motorists Killed Finds Tie to Cocaine
LEAD: Almost one of every four drivers between the ages of 16 and 45 who were killed in New York City traffic accidents in recent years tested positive for cocaine use, a new study has found.

LEAD: A veterinarian dismissed from the Food and Drug Administration said today that the agency's review of a genetically engineered drug designed to make dairy cows produce more milk had been marked by overly close ties to the animal drug industry.

LEAD: Some 40 black ministers met yesterday to coordinate a response to what they called an escalation in political and personal attacks against blacks.

LEAD: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney announced today that improved management would save the Pentagon $2.3 billion and eliminate 16,000 jobs next year, but he declined to go into detail on what jobs would be cut.


Review/Music;   Guarneri Plus Davidovich
LEAD: Schumann's Piano Quintet (Op. 44) - with which the Guarneri String Quartet, joined by the pianist Bella Davidovich, ended its concert on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall - is one of the composer's ripest creations.
Using a combination of instruments almost wholly novel in 1842, the composer immediately mastered it, producing a rich amalgam of emotion, ebullience and intelligence.


Royal Ballet Drops Plans To Tour U.S.
LEAD: The Royal Ballet announced today that it had canceled plans for a United States tour in July and August because the company could not obtain adequate financing.


Pleased With Past, Kean Looks to Future
LEAD: Eight years ago a former Assemblyman named Thomas H. Kean moved his belongings and a wobbly new administration into the Statehouse here, after stunning the public and himself with a 1,797-vote victory over Representative James J. Florio.


Dealer Is Jailed In 1988 Slaying Of Drug Officer
LEAD: Grim and silent, about 200 off-duty New York City police officers, many of them from distant precincts, crowded into a Manhattan courtroom yesterday to witness the sentencing of a drug dealer convicted last year of murdering an undercover police officer on the Upper West Side.

LEAD: While foreign companies welcome the lifting of martial law in the capital, the action is unlikely to have an immediate effect on their commercial or investment activities here, officials of a dozen companies said today.

Lord Macaulay, on the 1990's
LEAD: As commentators attempt to forecast political events in 1990 and the decade, they would be well advised to confer with Lord Macaulay, a 19th century British historian and arguably the finest designer of dramatic narrative ever to inhabit a page.


Exceptions, Rules and the Court;   In Criminal Law, a Line Maintained
LEAD: For years, prosecutors have been barred from using illegally obtained evidence at criminal trials.
But for years, with the Supreme Court's blessing, they've used a backdoor tactic to get such evidence before juries.
For example, when the defendant takes the witness stand, prosecutors will introduce such evidence during cross-examination - not, in theory, to prove guilt, but to impugn the defendant's credibility.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev implored Lithuanians today to remain within the Soviet Union, warning that secession would mean economic calamity for this tiny republic, while weakening Soviet security and endangering his own position and program.


Harold Zyskind Dies; A SUNY Professor, 72
LEAD: Harold Zyskind, professor emeritus of philosophy at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on Tuesday at the Veterans Hospital in Northport, L.I.
He was 72 years old and had been in the hospital for the last 15 years.


Panama Needs No Army
LEAD: An army's primary mission is supposed to be the defense of national territory.
In Latin America, that is rarely the reality.
Costa Rica's President, Oscar Arias, proposed on the Op-Ed page this week that Panama abolish its army, as his country did in 1948.
His suggestion makes good sense.


Drew Middleton of The Times Dies at 76
LEAD: Drew Middleton, who covered World War II and postwar Europe for The New York Times and later served as the newspaper's military correspondent, died quietly in his sleep Wednesday night at his apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
He was 76 years old.

Stallings Replacing Curry at Alabama
LEAD: The University of Alabama, where the pressure of being head football coach is so intense that Bill Curry left after a 10-2 season, yesterday hired as Curry's replacement Gene Stallings, who has a losing record as both a college and a professional coach.


Thames Controls Reeves
LEAD: Thames Television P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had been tendered about 12.2 million shares, or 96.2 percent, in its $7-a-share bid for the Reeves Communications Corporation, a New York television production company.
Thames said the remaining Reeves shares will be acquired in a merger at the same price as soon as possible.

McGraw-Hill Purchase
LEAD: McGraw-Hill Inc. said this week that it had acquired TAB Books Inc., a publisher of nonfiction books, for an undisclosed amount.
TAB Books, based in Blue Ridge Summit, Pa., publishes books in 12 fields including computing, electronics, aviation, engineering and several how-to subjects.
The company will become part of McGraw-Hill's professional publishing division.

LEAD: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' playmaker, and Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star forward, paid yesterday for what Commissioner David Stern called the informal wagers between themselves in the game Wednesday night.

LEAD: ''Beautiful'' and ''graceful'' may have been the last words Al Held would have chosen to describe the paintings he produced between 1953 and 1955.

LEAD: The 80th New York National Boat Show opens today at 10 A.M. in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.
Today's session, which runs from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., is for so-called red-carpet visitors, those willing to pay $15 a ticket to avoid the crowds.

LEAD: ''Terminal Hip,'' Mac Wellman's ''Spiritual History of America Through the Medium of Bad Language,'' is a post-Joycean Jabberwocky.
Expect no exegesis.
Just sit back and enjoy the torrent of language, as Mr.
Wellman zigzags through time, space and participle.


Review/Film;   Physicality on Many Levels in 'Internal Affairs,' a Police Drama
LEAD: Mike Figgis's films could be watched at any hour, but they're really best suited to the middle of the night.
With only two theatrical features to his credit, the terrific 1988 sleeper ''Stormy Monday'' and now ''Internal Affairs,'' a dizzying police thriller, Mr.
Figgis has established himself as a master of steamy sex appeal and brooding, nocturnal murk.

LEAD: The glow of X-ray radiation that suffuses the universe, mysterious since its discovery 28 years ago, is apparently issuing from distant galaxies that are giving birth to new stars, astronomers said today.

No other conclusion can be drawn from his State of the State message, where in 178 pages of text he never once mentioned the pending reduction.

Sonics' Ellis Is Injured In Traffic Accident
LEAD: Dale Ellis, who is leading the Seattle SuperSonics in scoring with a 23.6-point average, suffered a collapsed lung in a traffic accident early yesterday and will be out indefinitely, the club announced.
He was arrested for investigation of reckless driving and driving while intoxicated but was not taken into police custody because of his injuries.

LEAD: Monday is the birthday of the Rev.
Dr.
Martin Luther King Jr.
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Government offices: Closed.
Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Closed.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.

It is 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. tomorrow, not today.

LEAD: Walter J. Brownstone, the former president of a chain of clothing stores, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness.
He was 89 years old.


Hong Kong Calls China Talks Useful but Sees No Progress
LEAD: The Governor of Hong Kong said today that his three days of talks with Chinese officials had been useful, but neither side reported major progress in easing tensions between Hong Kong and Beijing.

Salvadoran Leftist Abducted
LEAD: A prominent Salvadoran leftist was kidnapped today in the Guatemalan capital, party officials said.
Hector Oqueli Colindres, deputy secretary general of the National Revolutionary Movement, was seized with a Guatemalan woman who was driving him to the airport, the group said in a statement released in San Salvador.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: NICOLA RESCIGNO waves his baton over the Dallas Opera for the last time tomorrow.
Mr.
Rescigno has resigned, effective after tomorrow's matinee, as artistic director and principal conductor, positions he has held since 1957 when he co-founded the company with Lawrence V. Kelly.


Patents;   States Held Immune on Infringement
LEAD: In a decision viewed by some experts as a blow to inventors, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington has ruled that state governments are immune from charges of patent infringement.

Spurs End Slump Against Celtics
San Antonio ended a streak of 20 consecutive losses to the Celtics last night with a 97-90 victory at Boston Garden.
The Spurs, who had not beaten Boston since Jan. 5, 1980, outscored the Celtics by 31-15 in the second quarter for a 56-43 halftime lead, then survived a 9-point third quarter.

Earl D. Johnson, 84, Aviation Figure And Cabinet Officer
LEAD: Earl D. Johnson, who was an Under Secretary of the Army and a top executive at General Dynamics and Delta Airlines, died in his sleep on Thursday at a nursing home in Greenwich, Conn.

Upheaval in the East: The Baltics;   Nationalists in Vilnius Turn Down Soviet Call for New Secession Law
LEAD: Nationalist leaders in the Soviet republic of Lithuania today rejected a Kremlin call for a new law outlining the procedures when a republic seeks to secede from the Soviet Union.
The proposal was called a ''propagandist trap'' and an ''attempt to deceive the people of Lithuania.''


Wilding Is a Crime, Except in Law
LEAD: Whatever else needs to be done in New York City, we must maintain law and order.
No constructive social program can work if we descend into chaos.


Patents;   Fixed Mortgages Down
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.80 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
That rate was down from a rate of 9.83 percent last week.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.41 percent this week, up from 8.35 percent the week before.


2 Teen-Agers Arrested In Central Park Attack
LEAD: Two teen-agers were arrested yesterday after their indictment in the attack of two men in the Central Park rampage by a group of youths that ended in the rape and beating of a female jogger last April.


Indian Shift on Bhopal Case
LEAD: The Indian Government said today that its predecessor was wrong to agree to absolve the Union Carbide Corporation of criminal liability in the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster, and it called the $470 million settlement inadequate.


Jack Lazar, Founder Of Knitwear Maker And Style Setter, 79
LEAD: Jack Lazar, the founder of Kimberly Knitwear Inc., in Manhattan, died Thursday at his home in Teaneck, N.J.
He was 79 years old.
With his wife, the former Helen Bandow, as the designer, Mr.
Lazar opened the company in 1946.
Over the years, Kimberley's knit dresses and other items came to be fashion staples in wardrobes of women from the Duchess of Windsor to secretaries.


Nets' Brundy Suspended For Drug Use
LEAD: Stanley Brundy, a seldom-used rookie forward with the Nets, has been suspended for the rest of the National Basketball Association season for failing a random drug test.


Review/Film;   Meanwhile, Pops Is Back At the Lodge
LEAD: Beware of movies that feature sweet old men named Pops.
If the writers can't do any better on a name, what can you expect from the rest? ''Ski Patrol'' has a Pops - Ray Walston, in about five brief scenes, as the owner of a resort - and sure enough, it turns out to be a perfect example of the nothing-is-too-obvious school of comedy.

Review/Dance;   'Prodigal Son' Weaves Poignancy and Motion
LEAD: Slight and fair-haired, Ib Andersen is not the prototypical hero of ''The Prodigal Son,'' a signature ballet by Balanchine set to music by Prokofiev.
The role has been defined, in part, by dark and muscled dancers.
But Mr.
Andersen's performance of the title role with the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater was so poignantly realized that it was almost painful to watch at times.

Retail Sales Rose 0.2% Last Month
LEAD: Retail sales rose two-tenths of a percent in December, and holiday spending was the weakest since 1985, the Government reported today.
For the year, sales increased 5 percent, the slowest gain in seven years.

He was 49 years old and lived in Boston.

Upheaval in the East;   Kissinger Predicts Baltic Split
LEAD: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, said today that the Baltic republics would secede from the Soviet Union despite appeals by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ''If he has really forsworn the use of force, then he probably cannot control events and then I think the Baltic states will break away,'' he told the BBC.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost ;   Reviewing Investments
LEAD:
The first quarter of the new year is a good time to review or plan personal investment portfolios.
Thus far many market strategists are making stocks the early choice as the lead component for most portfolios.
Inflation is in check and the economy is gradually slowing, lowering interest rates.
Stocks and bonds benefit from lower rates.

A Good Place to Act Affirmatively
LEAD: In the broadcasting field, white males are anything but an endangered species.
A decade ago blacks and Hispanics owned less than 1 percent of the nation's radio and television licenses.
Modest Federal Communications Commission programs have doubled that rate - to 2 percent.
Yet two of those programs are under constitutional attack in the Supreme Court.

Bridge
LEAD: One of the most exciting bidding environments is never faced by tournament players.
It occurs in Chicago (four-deal) bridge, or in traditional rubber bridge, when both sides are vulnerable and both sides have a part score.
Consequently almost any part score may earn a vulnerable game bonus, and innocuous hands become crucial.

SPORTS OF THE TIMES
LEAD: As he lay in a ward in Harlem Hospital, with five other patients and no telephone, he said he remembered how the crowd at Madison Square Garden would chant his name: ''Wing-o!
Wing-o!'' It usually came late in the game.

Egypt Cotton Profits Off
LEAD: Cotton, once known as Egypt's ''white gold,'' faces another year of much lower profits in 1989-90 as farmers grow less and imports rise.
Cotton exports are expected to earn Egypt about $200 million this season, the Egyptian Cotton Authority said Thursday, down about $100 million from last season.
Egypt also expects to import 130,000 bales of United States cotton in the 1989-90 season, up from 100,000 bales the year before.

The Call of the Roads Brings A Driver Back Home
LEAD: ON a June afternoon my friend Sherry's driver's license arrived in the mail.
She drove over to my house, honked, and waited for me behind the wheel of her mother's white-walled, baby-blue Buick Catalina, with the motor running.
I slipped into the front seat, shivering less from the air-conditioning than the sight of her white moccasin caressing the gas pedal.

A FEW WORDS FROM JENNY HOLZER
LEAD: Regarding Grace Glueck's article ''And Now, a Few Words From Jenny Holzer'' (Dec. 3), I would like to draw attention to a use of words in art before this century.
In an engraving titled ''Laocoon'' (circa 1820), the artist and visionary poet William Blake crowds aphorisms pertaining to art, Christianity, Classicism and economics around a central image of the famous Hellenistic sculpture.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Now, while woody plants are dormant, is an excellent time to prune, especially trees and summer-blooming shrubs.
But if the plants bloom early in spring, delay pruning until immediately after bloom.
Start seed indoors of early flowering plants such as pansies.
Check coldframes to be sure young plants and seedlings are secure and their soil moist.

Serene Haven of Buddhist Art
LEAD: THE road north from Chongqing, city of fog and ferries far up the Yangtze River, undulates through market towns by fish ponds, brick kilns and mulberry bushes.
Bamboos brush gray slate roofs, leathery men working in the fields hold pink umbrellas above their sweating brows, pigs are being carried to an urban fate in a special cane basket called ''pig's sedan chair,'' and heavily made-up young women in high heels by the muddy roadside call out invitations to take meals at their aromatic private cafes.

11 Wounded in Gaza Clashes
LEAD: Israeli troops shot and wounded 11 protesters today in scattered clashes in the Gaza Strip, hospital officials said.
Two Palestinians in the area were killed by fellow Arabs, but it was unclear whether those attacks were related to nationalist politics.
The officials said that a 54-year-old man was stabbed to death today in Gaza City, but residents said he was not known as a collaborator with the Israeli authorities.

LEAD: To the Editor When the Supreme Court gave stockbrokers the power to insist that aggrieved customers submit their disputes to arbitration, it accorded them something given to no other American industry. (''When Naivete Meets Wall Street,'' Dec. 3) No other industry is privileged with a dispute resolution system in which the adjudicator is not required to explain the basis of the decision and no mechanism is available for review and correction of mistakes.
