LEAD:
MONDAY: The stock markets are open, but most banks and Government offices are closed for Martin Luther King Jr.
Day.
The Campeau Corporation's Allied and Federated retailing units are to assure a banking group, which loaned Campeau $2.34 billion, that they are solvent.

Costs of Cable: False Comparisons
LEAD: The Dec. 17 article [''Cable TV vs.
Consumers: Battleground Emerges'']  included a chart titled ''The Cost of Cable,'' which compared Cablevision's Long Island rates in 1986 (before deregulation of the cable industry) and in 1989.
The chart provided an incorrect and invalid comparison between basic cable service in 1986 and family service in 1989 on Long Island.

KASPAROV BEATS DEEP THOUGHT
LEAD: IN A CROWDED AUDITORIUM, THE CHAMPION hunches over a chessboard.
He is surrounded by cameramen.
Taking refuge in himself, he pillows his jaw in his hands.
He is thinking hard in order to make himself think harder.
His opponent, also a champion, is some 300 miles away, pondering the next move, engaged in calculations on a scale too colossal for anyone in the audience to grasp.

BUSINESS DIARY: January 7-12
LEAD:
COMPANIES
Debt Ahead for UAL
The UAL Corporation had better learn to love debt.
Either management and the employees will load the company with debt to buy it, or the board will undertake a buyback - mortgaging the company to pay some impatient stockholders a premium.
The noisiest of these stockholders, Coniston Partners, threatens to unseat most of the board unless UAL coughs up a satisfactory payoff.

Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
LEAD: The good teams in the N.F.C. (49ers, Giants, Rams) are better than their A.F.C. counterparts (Broncos, Browns, Bills) and should win the Super Bowl.
But the bad teams in the N.F.C. (Cowboys, Falcons, Cardinals) are worse than their A.F.C. counterparts (Jets, Chargers, Patriots).
The average teams in each conference are about the same.

Penney building was acquired by the Tishman Speyer Trammell Crow Limited Partnership in 1988, the architectural firm of Skidmore Owings &amp; Merrill was hired to offer advice about renovating the structure and its sunken plaza on the west blockfront along the Avenue of the Americas between West 52d and 53d Streets.


Yonkers Seeks to Block Housing Plan
LEAD: Mayor Henry Spallone, buoyed by the United States Supreme Court's ruling that overturned contempt fines against four City Councilmen in the city's desegregation case, has asked municipal officials to examine the options of further legal action to prevent construction of court-ordered integrated housing.


Overnight Transformation At Midtown Welfare Hotel
LEAD: It was only 24 hours since New York City took over operations at one of the most squalid Manhattan welfare hotels, but already Glynis Slater, a 33-year-old mother of two, could see some improvement.


Campus Life: UConn;   Proposal to Close Teaching Center Is Angering Students and Faculty
LEAD: A steady reduction of services to students at the University of Connecticut, prompted by recent state budget cuts, have been greeted with murmurs of protest in the last few months.
But the most recent money-saving effort - the planned closing of the Center for Educational Innovation, which helps student teachers and university faculty members improve their teaching skills - has upset not just students, but faculty and union members as well.


Elegant Dinners in a Victorian Setting
LEAD: THE Copper Beech Inn, occupying the shade of a venerable copper beech tree on Main Street in Ivoryton, has been considered one of Connecticut's most elegant restaurants for almost 20 years.
It has survived a change in ownership, menu changes and minor tinkering and has managed to maintain its reputation for leisurely dining in restful and attractive surroundings.


EAST BERLIN DIARY
LEAD: I read Christoph Hein's article ''East Berlin Diary'' (Dec. 17), and memories of my many trips to East Germany over the years came back to me.
My first visit to East Berlin was in 1963, just 18 months after the wall was built.
My first trip to Leipzig, in East Germany, was in 1964.

Review/Music;   Industrial Clankings With Guitar Backing
LEAD: Drum machines went ''boom-chucka-boom'' and singers growled and glared in a triple bill of industrial rock Thursday night at the Ritz.
Ministry, KMFDM and Controlled Bleeding all make music that draws its power from the deepest, loudest thuds the musicians and electronics can produce.
Guitar and keyboard sounds and the chanted vocals are subordinate in songs that try to turn the depersonalized sounds of assembly-line machinery into statements of personal fury and horror.

Maps That Try to Hide Their Age
LEAD: IF the map says French Indochina, it is probably not the best one to buy for getting around in Southeast Asia.
But failing such startling evidence of age, it is difficult these days to tell how old a map in a store may be.
Copyright laws have been eased and some cartographers have been chary about saying how long it has been since a map was revised, even though it may have a fresh new design on the cover.

As the Sun Sets Slowly in the West . . .
LEAD: Few home-grown myths have exerted a more powerful influence on popular culture than that of the American cowboy.
Pictured as a heroic loner, a visionary frontiersman, a glamorous outlaw and a man's man in movies, television, songs and cigarette ads, he has stood as an icon of American masculinity for decades, though recently his supremacy has been challenged by fictional descendants from James Bond to Luke Skywalker, and revisionist historians have set about demolishing the romanticism of the Old West.


Should Sotheby's Be Strictly Cash and Carry?
LEAD: ART collectors were euphoric when, less than a month after the Wall Street crash of 1987, Sotheby's sold van Gogh's ''Irises'' for $53.9 million, the highest price ever paid for a painting at auction.
Then, two years later, it was revealed that the auction house had given the buyer a loan amounting to half the price of the painting and was still holding the artwork as collateral.

Saving the Bacon
LEAD: PORK AND I WERE NOT ON TASTING TERMS FORJU nearly 25 years.
Our disagreement had nothing to do with religion, although it did start in church.
The evening I was scheduled to play an angel in a pageant, my mother baked a big, juicy ham for dinner and I got sick as the devil.


CAN OPERA SURVIVE FRIENDS LIKE THIS?
LEAD: How comforting to know in a turbulent world that one of Western culture's most venerable traditions survives: the visionary interview granted by the freshly anointed artistic director upon taking office.
The organization changing pilots may be as formidable and unwieldy as a major opera company or as marginal as an amateur chamber orchestra.

LEAD: It makes some sense to watch the Indiana Jones trilogy backward - or more precisely, in reverse chronological order.

College Names And the 'Grand Word'
LEAD: The effort of state and private colleges in New Jersey to call themselves universities (''Colleges Ask to Be Called Universities,'' Dec. 3) is an example of what the 19th-century British poet and critic Matthew Arnold called ''the grand word without the grand thing.''


Carbon Paper 1, Technology 0
LEAD: Fat forms - invoices, purchase orders, bills of lading and other multipart documents that require a number of copies - are the bane of most small-business computer printers.
The cries of anguish seem to peak at this time of the year when companies start trying to print W-2 forms.
Each Federal, state and local agency wants its own copy of the wage statement that employers are required to provide to employees.

EAST BERLIN DIARY
LEAD: The current turmoil in Communist countries is often described as a struggle between freedom (which is assumed to require a free-enterprise economy) and Communism (dictatorship combined with a socialist economy).
Christoph Hein cuts through this confusion between political and economic issues to make it clear that democracy versus dictatorship and private enterprise versus socialism are separate issues.

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: Congress will have to deal with several bills concerning coins in the next few months.
One will change the look of the coins.
Another will abolish the cent in favor of a new coin valued at one dollar.
Both bills are mired in controversy.
The bill to change the design on the reverse side of the coins is supported by the American Numismatic Association and by many collectors.

Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
LEAD: Recent history says yes.
From 1984 through 1989, no N.F.C. team won its division with less than 10 victories.
But six A.F.C. teams managed to win.
In the last two seasons, four N.F.C. teams have missed the playoffs despite winning 10 games, none have done that and missed in the A.F.C.

Scuba Diving
LEAD: To the Editor: With the recent rise in the popularity of scuba diving, readers of Jane Adams's article ''Into the Void, and Back'' (Travel, Dec. 10) unfamiliar with the sport should be alerted to the possibility that the author might have been experiencing a major danger of scuba diving known as nitrogen narcosis, also called rapture of the deep, not to be confused with the bends or nitrogen saturation of the blood.

Isadora's Dances Take On a Life of Their Own
LEAD: A young woman in a short red tunic leaps out with a tattered flag, skips and falls ''wounded.'' Immediately, a second woman enters to take up the banner, and as she falls, two women materialize.
Five bodies lie on the ground and two more appear with raised fists, overlapping in their jumps.
On tape, the Red Army Chorus sings the ''Varshavyanka,'' a turn-of-the-century Polish-Russian revolutionary song.

LEAD: Ever since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in 1985, neoconservatives and other hard-liners have strained to find new rationales for old cold war animosities.
It hasn't been easy.
Mr.
Gorbachev doesn't fit the mold of Soviet leaders with his political and economic reforms, his unilateral force reductions, his freeing of Eastern Europe, his willingness to reveal the lies of his predecessors and now his statement that a multiparty system in his own country would not be a ''tragedy.

Martin Luther King: The Books Are Getting Better
LEAD: Tomorrow is the fifth official celebration of the Martin Luther King holiday, and enough time may have passed for at least a preliminary reckoning of this new national institution.
There has been a strained, showman's smile about the holiday since it sprang unexpectedly from Congress in 1983, as though in recompense for the 20-year institutional disengagement on most public issues touching race - from cities and transportation to schools.

LEAD: An article on Dec. 31 about corporations that finance programs in the public schools misidentified a corporate sponsor at the K. T. Murphy Elementary School in Stamford.
It is the General Electric Capital Corporation of Stamford, not the General Electric Company of Fairfield.

More Trouble With Oiled Waters
LEAD: Exxon is not having a good year.
Nor is the environment.
Last March brought the Valdez oil spill.
On Christmas Eve, an Exxon refinery in Baton Rouge exploded.
And on New Year's Day, 500,000 gallons of heating oil burst through a ruptured pipe into Arthur Kill, a 13-mile stretch of water off Staten Island that is a vital breeding ground for herons and egrets.

Dentists Are Lacking A Sense of Humor
LEAD: As a faithful reader of Barbara Klaus's Long Island Sound columns from almost its inception, I was able to take her article ''Smile, Darn You Smile'' as I'm sure it was meant: a tongue-in-cheek poke at my profession containing many of the cliches about dentists that I have heard for years.
This column was certainly not one of her most humorous, but I found myself chuckling in several places.

LEAD:
TRACKINGS: Composers Speak With Richard Dufallo.
By Richard Dufallo. (Oxford University, $35.) No one should require more of this book of splendid interviews.
Still, how wonderful it would be if Richard Dufallo's ''Trackings'' rekindled the old passions and rancor surrounding 20th-century music before the composers and their scores fade into the next century.

If You're Thinking of Living in: Bernardsville
LEAD: LONG before the dawn of civilization the area that is now Bernardsville was a meeting ground.

China Seeks Respectability, But Painlessly
LEAD: DENG XIAOPING is gambling again.
The 85-year-old Chinese leader, who has proved an astute political oddsmaker, is betting that by ending martial law Beijing will reap economic and diplomatic benefits without risking further unrest.


Silicon Valley Is Changing Programs
LEAD: SILICON VALLEY, where it once seemed growth had no limits, is in the midst of a midlife crisis.
Faced with fierce Japanese competition and a market for personal computers that is growing more slowly than the industry's early visionaries predicted, high technology has lost some of its luster.
If boom times are to return, the valley's engineers and entrepreneurs will have to find ways to make the personal computer cheaper, more powerful and portable enough to live up to its name.

Creaking Floors, Sleeping Children
LEAD: THERE are not many sights more ridiculous than a 40-year-old father crawling out of a sleeping toddler's bedroom.
On my knees, moving one hand at a time, I try to leave the room without making a sound.
Putting a child to bed will unwind even the most assertive and confident parent.

JoAnne, Allison and a Cruel Promise
LEAD: Neither JoAnne Johnson, 19, nor Allison Atlas, 20, has very long to live - not unless they receive bone marrow transplants that might defeat their leukemia.

Neither can most of the 9,000 Americans who might benefit from transplant surgery.

Want a Hit? Don't Flunk Marketing
LEAD: Robert de Niro and Dustin Hoffman, arguably the two greatest film actors of their generation, went belly-up at the box office this Christmas.
But Chevy Chase and Sylvester Stallone, who can be found elsewhere on the great acting spectrum, made out just fine.
What happened?
It wasn't a direct consequence of the films themselves, since all four vehicles in which these actors appeared were disappointing.


Lifestyle;   Pushing On in Spite of the Flu
LEAD: Gretchen L. Mergenthaler caughtthe flu over Christmas weekend, and throughout the following week she sneezed, coughed, sipped orange juice and breathed through her mouth when she slept.
Her ears hurt so much that ''when I went outside, it felt like two anvils hit me in the side of the head,'' she said.

More Talented Than We Knew
LEAD: To the Editor:


&gt;Breakfast Offerings That Stand Up to the Elements
LEAD: BREAKFAST, the health experts tell us, is the most important meal of the day.
But most people try to get by with cereal, juice and a cup of coffee.
This may be all very well if your morning is spent in front of a desk.
But if you plan to keep going on the ski slopes - or indeed, in any form of vigorous outdoor winter exercise - you will need something considerably more substantial.


ALL ABOUT/Minivans;   Zippy Hybrids Win a Place in the Family Driveway
LEAD: For sheer inventiveness, there is little in the automotive world to rival theVoyager III, the Chrysler Corporation's vision of the ultimate minivan.
As a whole, it resembles a bulbous, stretched-out van.
It has two engines and four rear wheels.
With the flip of a few switches and levers - voila! - the van separates into two parts: a three-seat urban commuter car and a rear module that can be parked until needed.

LEAD: A PROPOSED shelter for homeless people on the grounds of a Roman Catholic church here has left a neighborhood and parish bitterly divided and raised a moral question: Do property values supersede the observance of Christian values?

LEAD: I WAS HERE, AFTER 60 OR SO YEARS, in the northeastern corner of Poland, at the house of my adolescent vacations.
The manor still stood, though it had been remodeled into apartments for workers in Poland's Forestry Service.
What had been the park was now an impassable tanglewood descending to the lake shore, with no trace remaining of the paths.

JPW RAP MOVES TO TELEVISION'S BEAT
LEAD: Ask most pundits about rap music, and they'll describe it as rude, jumbled noise.
A few others may consider it million-selling post-modernism in audible form - songs as mix-and-match collages that treat the history of recorded music as a scrapheap of usable rubble and, often, trade narrative and logic for a patchwork of bragging, storytelling, speechifying and free-form rhymes.

Schuster Buys Janus
LEAD: Simon &amp; Schuster said last week that it had acquired Janus Book Publishers Inc., a textbook company based in Hayward, Calif.
The terms were not disclosed.
Janus publishes textbooks under the Janus and Alemany Press imprints.
Simon &amp; Schuster said it would combine the Janus imprint with two other educational units, Fearon Education and the Quercus Corporation.


Sports of The Times;   Joe Montana: Cleaner Than a Surgeon
LEAD: MOST of his 49er teammates had the look of little kids who had been playing in Candlestick Park's muddy slick grass.
They had mud on their scarlet jerseys, mud on their golden khaki pants.
But as Joe Montana stood in the 49er locker room after yesterday's 30-3 dissection of the Rams, his pants had only a thin smudge along the right thigh (as if he had dried his passing hand there) and another smudge along the red stripe down his left leg.


Business Scene;   Are True Profits Falling or Rising?
LEAD: CORPORATE profits are in decline.
Company after company is reporting sinking net income and the trend seems certain to continue, given the weak economy.
But there are several ways to measure profitability and some show American business to be in not such bad shape.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about Temple H. Buell, a Denver architect and developer, referred incompletely to a philanthropic venture.
In the 1960's Mr.
Buell announced a $25 million donation to Colorado Women's College, which renamed itself Temple Buell College.
The money was to be presented posthumously, but other donors, apparently unaware of this, stopped contributions.

A 10-Point Guide To Attempting a Running Streak
LEAD: Not every runner can tolerate the stress of daily workouts.
If you feel you can, keep the following suggestions in mind.
Keep a diary of your running as a source of motivation.
Establish a minimum mileage requirement.
Most streakers run at least two or three miles every day.
Know your pace so you can compute distance when running on unfamiliar routes.

Review/Concert;   The Juilliard and Beethoven: Lasting Musical Symbiosis
LEAD: In 43 years of existence, the Juilliard String Quartet has developed a highly varied repertory.
Yet to the general public it remains best known for its periodic traversals of two standard bodies of literature, the 16 quartets of Beethoven and the six of Bartok.
According to the program the Juilliard gave the first complete Beethoven cycle in New York in 1948-49, and has since played all 16 works more than a hundred times around the world.

A Fishing Watch
LEAD: rrA watch for fishermen has been designed to keep track of tides and temperatures as well as time. rrTimex has developed a timepiece called the Hooks.
The watch is made with a thermometer for reading air or water temperature.
The face of the watch has a ring for estimating tidal changes.
By adjusting the bezel to a known tide, you can read the time at which to expect the next tide.

Review/Theater;   'Jonquil,' the 3d Play in a Saga of Black History
LEAD: With harshness as well as equanimity, Charles Fuller's ''Jonquil'' reveals the obstacles to full emancipation in the South immediately after the Civil War.
Through a voting rights episode in a small South Carolina community, the author views the Reconstruction period as one of the uglier chapters in the nation's history.

LEAD: About 60 masked gunmen burst into a vacation camp on this island today and held tourists at gunpoint while they set off explosives to destroy vacation homes.


Mid- and Low-Income Minorities in Decline on College Rolls

Runners Keep in Step As Time Marches On
LEAD: WHILE cross-training and easy-does-it running will continue to mark fitness programs in the 1990's, there are still individuals who run every day and prosper from it.
At this time of year, that approach comes under scrutiny because January is when some runners pledge to run every single day without a voluntary break.

NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:
INTERNATIONAL
A3-11
Violence has erupted in Azerbaijan, the southern Soviet republic, leaving at least 25 people killed in the capital city, Baku.
Azerbaijani mobs are reportedly roaming the city's Armenian quarter, committing pogroms and atrocities.

The Editorial Notebook;   Flavors of Capitalism
LEAD: Free trade is best, everyone agrees, but what should the United States do when its partners distort trade by closing their markets or targeting special industries for support?
The answer is a subject of hot debate, as demonstrated anew in a study group commissioned by the Twentieth Century Fund, a New York research foundation.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Debut for Agency
LEAD: Danza, Schulman &amp; Glennon Advertising is making its national advertising debut with a series of print ads for ''J.UK.
Lasser's Your 1990 Income Tax,'' a book published by the Prentice Hall trade division of Simon &amp; Schuster Inc.
Illustrated by Robert Weber, a cartoonist for The New Yorker, the ads list some expenses that are deductible, like hair transplants, and some that are not, like entertainment during fishing trips.


Egypt Cotton Profits Off
LEAD: Cotton, once known as Egypt's ''white gold,'' faces another year of much lower profits in 1989-90 as farmers grow less and imports rise.
Cotton exports are expected to earn Egypt about $200 million this season, the Egyptian Cotton Authority said last week.
That compares with about $300 million earned last season.


Key to Sears Turnaround: Patience
LEAD: Despite widespread pessimism over the prospects of Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company, some industry experts think the nation's largest retailer has bottomed out and will eventually become the turnaround story of retailing in the 1990's.

345 pages. Viking. $18.95.


Airlines Give Break To Business
LEAD: A year after announcing tighter restrictions on many discount fares used by business travelers with an eye toward increasing revenue, the nation's airlines have been quietly giving large companies a break.

LEAD: Beatrice and Jerry Franklin conserved water all summer.
They never let the faucet run needlessly; they were stern about the dishwasher.
And instead of keeping their sprinkler system on a timer, they controlled it by hand.

LEAD: Alex Machaskee, vice president and general manager of The Plain Dealer, has been promoted to publisher of the Cleveland newspaper, and Thomas H. Greer, executive editor, has become editor.

LEAD: The road that George Seifert has traveled to Super Bowl XXIV has been full of anonymity, a road laden with smoldering fires that he has watered with an unassuming nature and a keen sense of exactly what place he says he believes his ego belongs and how much his inner satisfaction is his greatest reward of all.

LEAD: A state judge has ruled that a Long Island nursing home cannot collect fees of more than $100,000 for continuing to care for a comatose woman whose family wanted life-sustaining treatment stopped.

LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation said a $470 million settlement for victims of the industrial disaster in Bhopal, India, was binding even though the country's new Government had disavowed it. ''There is simply no basis for overturning it,'' said Joseph E. Geoghan, Union Carbide's vice president and general counsel.

Streptococcal Infections Are Rising in U.S.
LEAD: Serious streptococcal infections, including strep throat and rheumatic fever, are on the rise and have re-emerged as a public health problem, Federal health officials say.


Cost Cuts Announced By Apple
LEAD: Facing a possibly protracted slowdown, Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would begin a number of cost-cutting measures.
These measures include a reduction of employees at the company's headquarters in Cupertino, Calif.; a revised profit-sharing plan; less frequent salary increases, and the elimination of company cars for executives.


Human Genes Turn Plants Into Factories For Medicines
LEAD: SCIENTISTS are inserting human genes into plants and turning the plants into miniature factories that can produce large quantities of useful human proteins.


Campbell Soup's New Chief Offers Strategy for Growth
LEAD: In an energetic first day in office, David W. Johnson, the Campbell Soup Company's new president and chief executive, outlined his plans to revitalize the big food company, pledging to maintain its independence and to increase profits by curbing costs and possibly pruning operations.


Identifying Schools Most in Need Is First Step to Helping Them
LEAD: To the Editor:


Man Charged in Cake Death
LEAD: A man was charged Sunday in the death of a 3-year-old girl who apparently suffocated when she was force-fed a chocolate cake, the police said.
Frank F. Johnson, 46, of Baton Rouge, was accused of murder in failing to help the girl, Myra Griffin, when the incident occurred on Dec. 21, Officer Jeff Wesley said.


Gordon Jackson, an Actor, at 66; Hudson in 'Upstairs, Downstairs'
LEAD: Gordon Jackson, an actor known to millions of television viewers as Hudson, the archetypal butler in the popular series ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' died on Sunday in Cromwell Hospital in London.
He was 66 years old.
The cause of death was not disclosed, but Mr.
Jackson's agent, Michael Anderson, said the actor had been ill for a short time before being hospitalized.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.B.A.
A First for Price as Cleveland Wins
Mark Price recorded the first triple-double of his pro career with 25 points, 12 assists and 11 rebounds as the Cleveland Cavaliers defeated the San Antonio Spurs, 92-89, yesterday in Richfield, Ohio.
Price made six of nine 3-point shots for the Cavaliers, who set a team record by hitting 10 long-range shots in 22 attempts.


Mubarak Saves Life of a Sudanese
LEAD: A quick trip by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt here last month apparently persuaded the governing Sudanese junta not to hang a physician found guilty by a military tribunal of fomenting a strike.


U.N. Official Views Africa
LEAD: African economies improved slightly in 1989 but failed to keep up with population growth, and on average Africans became worse off, an economist said today.

With Notes of Charm, Children Help Neediest
LEAD: Children tend to give smaller gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund than adults.
They have, after all, just their allowances, earnings from household chores or holiday and birthday gifts to draw from.
But the wishes they express are eloquent and direct.


Symbol Stock Falls
LEAD: Symbol Technologies Inc.'s stock lost nearly one-third of its value yesterday after the company said fourth-quarter earnings would be below Wall Street estimates.
Symbol's shares tumbled $5 to finish at $10.50, a loss of 32.3 percent, the biggest percentage loss on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Bohemia, L.I., company, which makes bar-code reading equipment, said it expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share, well below Wall Street's forecast of about 30 cents a share.


Lawyers for Noriega to Seek His Release on Bail
LEAD: In a reversal of legal tactics, lawyers for Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that they would argue that their client be freed on bail.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: ALTHEA WETHERBEE, a Long Islander, finished the Tenneco Marathon in Houston on Sunday, the oldest woman to do so.
But her son, Lieut.
Comdr.
JAMES D. WETHERBEE, fell asleep before he heard the news.
Commander Wetherbee is currently orbiting the earth as pilot of the space shuttle Columbia.


Heating Oil Drops Sharply As Weather Turns Warm
LEAD: Heating oil futures prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as unseasonably warm weather spread across the country, easing demand for home heating fuel.


4 Men Convicted in Drug Case
LEAD: Four men were convicted today in a major drug smuggling operation, but 16 other defendants in the 2 1/2-month-long trial were found not guilty.


Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Thursday about a new product assignment for the Isidore &amp; Paulson advertising agency misstated the agency's relationship to two Kraft General Foods cereal accounts.
It handled only the introduction of the cereals, Crispy Critters and Honey Bunches of Oats.

Chrysler Layoffs
LEAD: Faced with slumping auto sales, the Chrysler Corporation of Canada said it would lay off about 1,000 workers at its assembly plant in Bramalea, Ontario, for five weeks starting immediately.
The plant makes the Eagle Premier and the Dodge Monaco.
Earlier this month, Chrysler announced it would lay off 1,200 workers at its Jeep plant in Brampton, Ontario, and 2,100 workers at its van plant in Windsor, Ontario.


Foreman Wins in 2d Round and Sends Cooney Into Retirement
LEAD: George Foreman, an evangelical preacher from Humble, Tex., smote an opponent tonight.


Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   BULGARIAN PARTY LOSES DOMINANCE
LEAD: This country today became the last of the Soviet Union's East European allies to strip the Communist Party of its dominant role, following the others in a halting transition to multiparty democracy.


'Junk Bond' Prices Little Changed
LEAD: The long-awaited bankruptcy filing by two of the Campeau Corporation's primary subsidiaries had little effect on prices in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market yesterday.


U.S. Memories: Too Short
LEAD: An unusual cooperative venture with the apt name of U.S.
Memories has failed to raise the necessary funds from American computer companies to go into the business of making memory chips.
A major opportunity to guard against future pressure from Japanese competitors thus seems to have been frittered away.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the aftermath of a shooting spree that killed Cambodian refugee children last year in Stockton, Calif., misstated the number of Southeast Asian children injured.
Of the 29 who were hurt, 21 were Southeast Asians.


Mad Dashes to Cash the Stores' Checks
LEAD: When Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation announced last week that they would issue checks to pay suppliers for more than $100 million in merchandise, some suppliers went to great lengths to try to cash those checks before the stores could file for bankruptcy.


Europe Wary On New Ties
LEAD: The European Community told the six European Free Trade Association nations today that it would not be pushed into a hasty agreement on closer ties.

Marilyn Neale, Executive, 37
LEAD: Marilyn Neale, a vice president of Ruder Finn &amp; Rotman Inc., the public relations firm, died on Sunday of breast cancer at her home in Manhattan.
She was 37 years old.


Judge Quickly Assumes Active Role in the Stores
LEAD: In signing five orders yesterday morning, a Federal bankruptcy judge in Cincinnati quickly showed how involved he would be in the operations of one of the world's largest retailing empires.


Corrections
LEAD: A brief article in SportsMonday this week about the ticket lottery for the N.C.A.A.
Eastern Regional basketball tournament misstated the dates for the event, the ticket price and the method of payment.
The semifinals of the tournament will be played on March 22 and the final on March 24.
Tickets cost $43 each plus a $2 fee for each order.


Beijing Journal;   Stilled by the Unthinkable, a Singer Tries His Voice
LEAD: Like a thick carpet of snow, silence has settled over China.
In muffled voices, among friends, some people still mock their leaders and dream of change, but despite the lifting of martial law last week they are quiet in public, or they are in jail.

In the Ebb and Flow Of Ancient Glaciers, Clues to Next Ice Age
LEAD: THE climatic history of the last half-million years is largely a history of ice and cold, punctuated every 100,000 years or so by brief, glorious intervals of unusual warmth called interglacials.
If nature takes its course, scientists say, the current interglacial - the one in which human civilization developed - should begin to end within the next 2,000 years or sooner.

LEAD: Because of slowing orders, the General Electric Company plans to close its factory here for the week of Jan. 22-26, idling nearly 1,700 workers.

By Design;   Hats Floppy and Flexible

That is one of the nice features of the rakish but casual hats spotted around town.
Made of soft fabrics like velvet, wool or rayon ribbon, they can be put on any old way.
Floppy and flexible, they adjust to the whims of the wearer.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about the relationship between cocaine use and traffic fatalities in New York City included a scientist's incorrect figure in some copies, on the extent of cocaine use.
A 1986 survey by the State Division of Substance Abuse Services reported that 11 percent of New Yorkers between 18 and 25 had used cocaine within the previous six months, not that 11 percent of the entire population used cocaine regularly.

Ecolab said that under its buyback program it had bought back about 2.4 million shares for about $72 million.

On 59th St., The Topic Is a Hot One
LEAD: The Campeau Corporation's decision to put its American department stores into Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings was topic No. 1 on both sides of the counters at Bloomingdale's yesterday.


Scientists Learn to 'Listen' for Avalanches
LEAD: AVALANCHE warnings can be improved by using special microphones that detect low-frequency sounds from more than 50 miles away, a research team has reported.


South Carolina Coach Courts Local Players
LEAD: South Carolina has not had a player from the New York City area make a significant contribution since Mike Doyle of the Bronx averaged 12.6 points in 1979-80.
It is noteworthy because of the legacy of Frank McGuire.


Business and Health;   Health Insurers' Changing Role
LEAD: HEALTH-INSURANCE executives say their business has changed radically in the last two years in the nation's struggle with double-digit growth in medical spending.
Many insurers say their traditional work of assuming risks has been eclipsed by services to help their customers' health dollars go further.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: MILOVAN DJILAS, the dissident Yugoslav writer, flies to Moscow from Belgrade today as the guest of the Soviet journal Literaturnaya Gazeta.
In a conciliatory mode, the Russians have invited him to participate in a round-table discussion of Moscow's break with Yugoslavia more than 40 years ago, the very break that he helped precipitate.


A Storybook Development With an Uncertain Ending
LEAD: When Federal regulators seized control of New Jersey's largest savings institution last month, one of the troubled properties that came with it was Port Liberte, a storybook development of sumptuous town houses rising above lazy canals on the cluttered waterfront here.


5-Nation Panel Considers U.N. Role in Bringing Peace to Cambodia
LEAD: With France calling for action to prevent the Khmer Rouge from returning to power, the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council met here today to analyze a plan to involve the United Nations in bringing peace to Cambodia.


Grey Advertising Gets Wonder Bread Account
LEAD: Wonder Bread will now be pitched by Grey Advertising.
The Continental Baking Company, the subsidiary of the Ralston Purina Company that bakes Wonder, has consolidated its bread line at Grey, which already handles the Home Pride, Oatmeal Goodness and Beefsteak Rye brands.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: WILLIAM J. GRINKER, until last October the head of the New York City Human Resources Administration under Mayor Edward I. Koch, is leading a study of drug-treatment programs in a project financed by the Twentieth Century Fund and several other foundations.
Mr.
Grinker, 54, once a senior program officer at the Ford Foundation, will explore existing treatment alternatives, research and methods of disseminating information.


Desperation Shot Lifts Knicks Over the Bulls
LEAD: Trent Tucker accomplished the impossible yesterday.
With a tenth of second left on the Madison Square Garden clock, the Knicks' guard caught an inbounds pass, turned and let fly a high-arcing 26-footer that hit nothing but net and gave the Knicks a 109-106 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

Review/Theater;   A Surgeon's Crisis of Faith In a Marsha Norman Work
LEAD: Marsha Norman's ''Traveler in the Dark'' aims to be a play about a crisis of faith but becomes an unresponsive argument between a skeptic and a believer.
The work is didactic when it needs to be humanizing, single-edged when it should be at its most penetrating.
First presented in 1984 at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., ''Traveler in the Dark'' is having its New York premiere at the York Theater Company.

Coors Enters Bottled Water Market
LEAD: For the first time since Prohibition, the Adolph Coors Company is selling a nonalcoholic beverage.

Din of Assembly-Line Justice in New York
LEAD: A din filled courtroom 941 at State Supreme Court in Brooklyn the other day as Justice Nicholas Coffinas looked down from the bench.
Before him was a spindly young man who had been caught with an unregistered pistol.
Minutes before, an admitted burglar had his turn before the judge.
Then had come a purse snatcher, a man accused of selling drugs and a man charged with splitting another man's lip in a street brawl.

The Editorial Notebook;   After the Election: Surprise!
LEAD: Remember David Dinkins, candidate?
He was the indecisive one, so bad at making decisions that even some supporters predicted he'd be merely a ceremonial mayor while those around him did the heavy lifting.
Now look.
Mr.
Dinkins announced, just two days into the job, that because of budget problems, the city would have to delay hiring 1,800 police officers.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
THE CAMPEAU FILING
Campeau's American retailing operations filed for bankruptcy protection, saying they had debts of about $7.5 billion.
The filing will enable Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores to keep their 260 department stores open while plans are made to stock merchandise, reschedule debt payments and reorganize the company, perhaps selling some divisions.

LEAD: Hachette S.A., a leading French publisher, said today that it had signed a deal late last month with Progress Publishers of the Soviet Union that will allow unknown Russian authors to be published for the first time in the West.

Market Place;   Manager Favors Depressed Bonds
LEAD: CLOSED-END bond funds have been an out-of-favor investment category shunned by many analysts for the last six months.
But while others have been selling these funds, Thomas J. Herzfeld Advisors of Miami has been buying them since mid-December.
In Mr.
Herzfeld's view, they offer the best bargains in the closed-end market these days.

LEAD: Mexico and its bankers have agreed on how to cover the $300 million shortfall in their landmark deal under which most of the banks involved will reduce the value of the country's existing debt by 35 percent, according to bank and Mexican officials.

Review/Television;   Life Since the Intifada, As Viewed by Israelis
LEAD: Whatever else it does or fails to do, ''A Search for Solid Ground'' lets viewers know from the start what they are getting.
The hourlong documentary, at 8 tonight on Channel 13, carries the subtitle ''The Intifada Through Israeli Eyes.'' It opens with a statement that no Palestinians have been interviewed and that this program offers the perspective of mainstream Israelis on the Palestinian uprising, or intifada, which began in December 1987 in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

Disaster Aid for Florida
LEAD: President Bush today declared part of Florida a major disaster area from the freeze last month that devastated citrus and other crops.
John Herrick, a White House spokesman, said the declaration covers the counties of Broward, Collier, Dade, Hendry, Lee, Monroe and Palm Beach.
It makes those left without jobs by the freeze eligible for unemployment compensation and other Federal assistance.


Temple Loses Two
LEAD: Duane Causwell and Joseph Robinson of the Temple basketball team have been declared academically ineligible.
Causwell, a senior from Cardozo High School in Queens, was the Owls' starting center and was averaging 11.3 points, 8.3 rebounds and 4 blocked shots a game.
Robinson, a freshman from Philadelphia's Central High School, joined the team as a walk-on.(

44 Injured in Italian Theft
LEAD: A holdup went awry today when an explosive that robbers planned to used to blast open a safe went off prematurely, injuring 44 people in a crowded post office, the police said.
Among the wounded were retirees lining up to receive their monthly pension payments, the police said.

LEAD: Herbert Buell West, a retired foundation president and a former advertising executive, died of abdominal cancer on Sunday at his home in Darien, Conn.
He was 73 years old.

A spokeswoman for Columbia Records confirmed the report, but did not say whether the couple would marry.
Ms.
Scialfa was Mr.
Springsteen's backup singer.

LEAD: A picture caption with the television listings yesterday about Gordon Parks misstated his contribution to the ballet ''Martin.'' He wrote the music; the choreographer was Rael Lamb.

No Headline

Or at least less expensive.

Review/Television;   Prince Pronounces on State of Architecture
LEAD: Who thinks that architecture isn't a fit subject for television?
Not Prince Charles, surely.
Tonight, he will appear on Public Broadcasting Service stations nationwide (at 10 P.M. on Channel 13) in ''H.R.H.
Prince Charles: A Personal View of Architecture,'' a film produced last year for the BBC.
The hourlong program is precisely what it claims to be: the Prince, as both writer and star, chats, converses and pronounces on the state of architecture as he sees it.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about the rise of Vaclav Havel to the presidency of Czechoslovakia misstated the country's system for dividing high offices between Czechs and Slovaks.
A conference last year between the Government and the opposition agreed that the President must be a non-Communist Czech since the Prime Minister, Marian Calfa, was a Communist Slovak.


Early-Month Vehicle Sales Up Sharply
LEAD: Sales of cars made in the United States jumped by 29.8 percent in early January compared with a sluggish period a year ago, as buyers took advantage of factory incentives and flocked to showrooms after an absence of several months.
Light-truck sales also surged, rising by 22.8 percent.

LEAD: The Federal Government yesterday halved the recommended dose of AZT, the only drug approved for the treatment of AIDS, after concluding that the lower dose was just as effective and caused fewer dangerous side effects.

LEAD: The military chiefs of 35 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, sat down together at the same table for the first time today at an extraordinary seminar intended to reduce tensions in Europe.


60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: IN this age of fettuccine with radicchio and goat cheese, foie gras ravioli and exotic risottos, the notion of serving spaghetti with meatballs seems downright primitive.

PRAGUE HONORS MARTYRED STUDENT
LEAD: In an act as symbolic as Jan Palach's self-immolation 21 years ago, the people of Prague today renamed Red Army Square for the student who burned himself to death to protest what the Soviet occupation in 1968 had done to his country.


N.F.L. Draft Lures Star Junior at Alabama
LEAD: Keith McCants, a junior linebacker who won all-America recognition last season at the University of Alabama, said yesterday that he would pass up his final year of eligibility to enter the National Football League draft in April.
He said his main motive was financial security.


A Price on Their Heads
LEAD: To the Editor:


Positive Sign for Gooden
LEAD: Dwight Gooden, the right-handed ace of the Mets' pitching staff, underwent another magnetic resonance imaging test on his right shoulder yesterday.
The club said early indications were that the shoulder was continuing to improve.


Lomax Retires
LEAD: Neil Lomax, the Phoenix Cardinal quarterback who sat out last season with degenerative arthritis in his left hip, announced his retirement from the N.F.L. yesterday.


GREATER U.N. ROLE IS URGED TO SETTLE CAMBODIA CONFLICT
LEAD: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council called today for the United Nations to administer Cambodia and supervise free elections there.


Chronicle
LEAD: ISAAC ASIMOV barely made it to his own party last night.
The prolific author slipped out of the cooperative-care unit at Tisch Hospital, where he has been in treatment for several days.


New York Region and the Budget: School-Aid Proposal Is Big Change
LEAD: Like most aspects of Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget, the line items that most affect New York City and its suburbs are what Assembly Speaker Mel Miller called ho-hum - neither greatly enhanced nor greatly diminished from last year's appropriations.


Rochefort Returns
LEAD: Norman Rochefort returned to the Rangers yesterday and was to play his first National Hockey League game in almost a year tomorrow, against the Penguins in Pittsburgh.


Grand Met Buying 2 Liquor Stakes
LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food and liquor giant, said its International Distillers and Vintners unit would buy a 49 percent stake in the French liquor company Remy Martin et Cie S.A. and a 19 percent holding in Cointreau et Cie S.A.
Grand Met is buying the stakes from the Max Cointreau family.


U.S. Postpones Deploying Ships Near Colombia
LEAD: The Administration has postponed plans to deploy an aircraft carrier battle group off the coast of Colombia to help prevent drug shipments from Latin America to the United States, Administration officials said today.


Review/Opera;   Popular High-Decibel Delights of 'La Gioconda'
LEAD: ''La Gioconda'' is not the worst opera ever written, far from it.
The competition is too stiff even to allow Ponchielli's melodrama of lust and treachery in 17th-century Venice to contend for that distinction.
It certainly is, however, one of the crudest musical efforts to keep a place in the repertory for more than a century, going toe-to-toe with the best Mozart, Verdi and Wagner could offer.

Jeff Alexander, 79; Composer for Screen
LEAD: Jeff Alexander, a composer who worked in radio, television and motion pictures for more than 50 years, died of cancer on Dec. 23 at his home on Whidbey Island in Washington.
He was 79 years old.


Georgia Gulf's Plan Is Backed
LEAD: The head of the company that controls 9.9 percent of the stock of the Georgia Gulf Corporation, the Atlanta-based chemicals maker, said he would support a recapitalization plan announced Monday by the Georgia Gulf board.


Lee Goldstein, Composer, 37
LEAD: Lee Goldstein, a conductor of operas and musical-theater pieces and a former composer in residence at the Lyric Opera of Chicago, died on Friday at St.
Joseph Hospital in Chicago.
He was 37 years old.


157 More Request Salary Arbitration
LEAD: Kevin Mitchell, the San Francisco Giants slugger who was considered the best player in baseball in 1989, reached the $2 million salary plateau yesterday.
The agreement kept him out of salary arbitration, but 157 other players, including Jose Canseco, Will Clark, Paul Molitor and Bo Jackson, filed for arbitration on a record-setting day.

Northern California Jolted
LEAD: An earthquake shook a sparsely populated area in Northern California today but no injuries or major damage was reported, the United States Geological Survey said.
The epicenter was off the Pacific Coast, about 50 miles southwest of Eureka.
A spokesman for the earthquake center here said the tremor, which measured 5.3 on the Richter scale, was unrelated to the major earthquake that shook the San Franciso Bay area last Oct.


For Every Five Young Women, Six Young Men
LEAD: SOCIAL myth: There are not enough young men for all the young women looking for boyfriends or husbands.


Blue Chips Lead Rebound; Dow Up 23.25
LEAD: Blue-chip stocks rose strongly yesterday on sharply higher volume, as the stock market bounced back from two losing sessions.

Leader of Opposition Returns to Nicaragua
LEAD: The leading opposition presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, returned to Nicaragua today and was apparently in good health after receiving treatment in the United States for a broken right knee.


Renowned Renoir to Be Auctioned in May
LEAD: Pierre Auguste Renoir's 1876 depiction of an open-air dance hall in Montmartre, ''Au Moulin de la Galette,'' will go on the auction block in New York on May 16, Sotheby's announced yesterday.

Is she about to carry her tough-guy persona a little too far and thereby alienate the audience she once charmed with her impudent bulk and nasally quips?
True, her weekly sitcom still hangs up there at the top of the television ratings, often in the No.


Briton Pledges Hong Kong Changes
LEAD: The British Foreign Secretary wound up a four-day visit here today, saying Hong Kong wanted to see the pace of democratic changes quickened as the colony moves toward its return to Chinese control in 1997.

LEAD: Advice to underrated rock bands: Stick around, keep your sense of humor, and if you're lucky, what once sounded secondhand will turn out to be classic.

Basil D. Henning, 79, Resident Master at Yale
LEAD: Dr.
Basil Duke Henning, an educator, author and the resident master of Saybrook College at Yale University for 29 years, died Monday at Yale University Health Services Center in New Haven after a long illness.
He was 79 years old and lived in New Haven.

With Vaclav Havel


India Edwards Dies; Advocate of Women In Politics Was 94
LEAD: India Edwards, former vice chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, who worked to advance the role of women in politics, died Sunday at Fircrest Convalescent Hospital in Sebastopol, Calif.
She was 94 years old and lived in Greenbrea, Calif.


Rorer Details Value of Merger
LEAD: The Rorer Group Inc., a maker of pharmaceuticals, said that a merger plan it is discussing with another company would value Rorer at $3.14 billion.
Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa., said it had authorized 43 million shares of common stock, including only 32 million shares outstanding, two bond issues that would convert into 10.2 million, and shares held by an employee stock ownership plan.


Slovenia Seeks Party Change
LEAD: Slovenia's party leadership demanded today that Yugoslavia's ruling League of Communists transform itself into a loose coalition of regional communist parties.
The proposal is to be discussed at a national party congress scheduled for Saturday, the state Tanjug news agency reported.


Chronicle
LEAD: The show doesn't always go on.
Succumbing to the flu, ANTHONY HEALD and NATHAN LANE, the two leads of ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' did not appear last night at the Promenade Theater in Manhattan.
Because both actors have the same understudy, the performance was canceled.


New York City Real Estate's Value Rising by 10.8%
LEAD: The taxable value of real estate in New York City will rise to $77.7 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1, an increase of 10.8 percent over the current year's figure, tentative city figures showed yesterday.


Opposition's Talks With Communists in Sofia Off to a Rough Start
LEAD: The first round of talks between ruling Communist officials and members of the Bulgarian opposition began today.
But they quickly hit a snag, with the opposition demanding access to news media and office space and the Communists, who still maintain near-total control, asserting that they were being confronted with ultimatums and grandstanding.


Egyptian in Washington for Talks To Revive Stagnant Peace Process
LEAD: The Egyptian Foreign Minister flew to Washington today carrying what diplomats called an appeal to the United States to continue its newest Middle East peace effort.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell further and short-term bill rates shot higher yesterday as market participants sold securities in the aftermath of another big drop in prices on Japanese financial markets.

LEAD: Nearly two weeks ago, the Suffolk County District Attorney held a news conference to announce that Charles Stuart had become the focus of the investigation into the killings last autumn of his wife and unborn child.


Kopeck Capers
LEAD: Not the least of Mikhail Gorbachev's problems is the Soviet Union's unbalanced budget.
To trim the deficit, he is taking a substantial bite out of military spending, and otherwise looking for small savings wherever he can find them.


Fear Grows That Ethiopia Will Bar Relief to Famine-Stricken Area
LEAD: Concern is growing over the reluctance of the Ethiopian Government to allow relief agencies to distribute food to the four million to five million people facing starvation in northern areas of the country, relief officials and American legislators say.

LEAD: The Lowe Group of Britain has appointed Adelaide Horton to the new position of chief operating officer of its American unit, Lowe Group USA.
She was formerly a senior vice president at Chiat/Day/Mojo.
The Lowe Group's roster of agencies includes Lowe Marschalk.

Israeli Inflation Up in '89
LEAD: Consumer prices rose by 20.7 percent in Israel in 1989 despite an austerity program aimed at reducing inflation, the Government said Monday.
The increase compared with a rise of 16.4 percent in 1988 and 16.1 percent in 1987.
The Government said prices rose 1.1 percent in December, compared with 1.3 percent in November and 1.6 percent in December 1988.


Former Lion Sentenced
LEAD: Reggie Rogers, a former Detroit Lion convicted of negligent homicide, was sentenced yesterday in Pontiac, Mich., to up to two years in prison for the deaths of three teen-agers in a 1988 traffic accident involving the vehicle he was driving.

N.H.L.
Lemieux Extends Point Streak

The Flyers are 0-5-3 in their last eight games.
The Penguins won for the fifth time in six games.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Jan. 6 about the coming marriage of Susan Eisenhower and Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a Soviet scientist, referred incorrectly to the institute where he does research.
It is the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J.


Centuries of Strife Between 2 Groups
LEAD: Antagonism between Azerbaijanis and Armenians is longstanding, caused by religion, nationalism, territorial friction and other factors, experts at United States universities said in interviews this week.

LEAD: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad began random drug tests of its employees yesterday under a Federal mandate, a railroad spokesman said.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has ordered its divisions to cut or delay media advertising spending by 25 percent as part of its cost-cutting efforts, the company said today.

Japan Promises More Economic Aid for Hungary
LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan promised increased economic aid to Hungary today as he completed a 10-day trip in which Japan's largess made him a big hit in Eastern Europe and its huge trade surplus made him a big target in Western Europe.


New Wyse Models
LEAD: Wyse Technology Inc. said it had added to its product line the first in a series of Unix systems for the midrange multi-user computer market.
The new computers include the Wyse Series 9000I, which supports symmetric processing and is based on the Intel Corporation's 386 microprocessor.
The family of computers supports up to 128 users.


From Dictatorship to Revolt, Rumanian Defends a House
LEAD: There are nine bullet holes in the walls and ceiling of Venera Darian's bedroom in the residential district of northern Bucharest where she has lived for most of her 89 years.


Georgia Pacific Seeks New Nekoosa Board
LEAD: The Georgia Pacific Corporation, which is engaged in a battle to win control of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, said yesterday that it had begun to solicit proxies to remove Great Northern's board at a special shareholders meeting.


Brainard Cheney, Novelist, 89
LEAD: Brainard Cheney, the author of five novels set in the swamp country of Georgia, died at a nursing home Monday after a long illness.
He was 89 years old.


Rights Gains Reversed In Korea, Group Finds
LEAD: A two-year trend of human rights improvements in South Korea has been reversed, Amnesty International, the international human rights group, said today.

LEAD: It was 2 in the morning, and on the fourth floor of Caesars Atlantic City, just down the hall from his room, the Geezer still had himself an audience.


A.T.&amp;T. Pinpoints Cause of Phone Disruption
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had traced the huge disruption in long-distance service that occurred Monday to a single computer program that malfunctioned and caused a chain reaction in the network.


President Is Selected At Citibank and Parent
LEAD: Richard S. Braddock, for many years a key executive in Citicorp's highly profitable consumer banking business, yesterday was named president of Citicorp and its main subsidiary, Citibank.

LEAD: James Heffernan, a retired photographer for the New York City Fire Department and for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died of colon cancer on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.
He was 79 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

Fund and C.D. Yields Drop
LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week ended yesterday.
Analysts said conflicting signals on the state of the economy had slowed the decline in yields and could keep them near current levels.

LEAD: The deadline for entries to the 1990 One Show has been extended to Feb. 9, from Jan. 31, because of a water main break on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan that temporarily closed the club's office on 18th Street.


The Reagan Boom - Greatest Ever
LEAD: Almost everyone knows that the greatest depression the U.S. ever had was in the 1930's.
It was known as the Great Depression, and its infamy merits a separate section in economics textbooks.
But what was its counterpart?
When did our greatest economic expansion occur?

Cuomo Proposes More Anti-Drug Spending, but the Legislature Is Wary
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo today proposed adding more than $250 million to the $1 billion a year the state already spends on anti-drug programs.
But several of his top aides, citing bureaucratic delays and community opposition to drug-treatment centers, conceded that they would not be able to spend all of the money in the coming year.

LEAD: Karsten Mahlmann was re-elected chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade in a rare contest for the job, exchange officials said tonight.

Supreme Court to Consider An Antitrust Suit by States
LEAD: At the urging of the attorneys general of a majority of the states, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states can bring Federal antitrust suits charging energy producers with illegal price-fixing.


18 Tourists Killed in Brazil
LEAD: At least 18 Argentine tourists, including 4 children, died today when their bus overturned near the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre, radio reports said.
The bus had left the town of Trenque Lauquen in Argentina on Sunday loaded with tourists bound for the coastal Brazilian town of Camboriu when it flipped on its side before dawn, the reports said.

LEAD: Prices of orange juice futures rose sharply yesterday after a report that Brazil expects to export 450,000 metric tons of frozen concentrate to the United States this year, an amount that might not meet United States demand.


T.W.A. Sells Jets To Raise Cash
LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc. said it had sold 11 jumbo jets for $210 million to two leasing companies to raise cash and reduce its large debt, company officials said.
It was the second time in less than a month that the airline had announced the sale of assets.
On Dec. 18, it said it planned to sell its Chicago-London route and related assets to American Airlines for $195 million.

Corrections
LEAD: An illustration with the Personal Health column on Jan. 4 about cross-country skiing depicted a technique improperly.
In the basic motion, as the column said, when one leg is forward, the opposite arm is also forward, pushing off with the pole.


Northwest and Delta Match $12 Surcharge for Fuel Cost
LEAD: Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines matched American Airlines yesterday in adding a $12 surcharge on every round-trip ticket to help cover the rising cost of fuel.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Science Times on Jan. 9 about card shuffling misstated the value of 52 factorial, or 52 X 51 X 50, etc.
It is approximately 0.8 X 10 to the 68th power.

LEAD: THIS is a plea for chopsticks.
Chopsticks for pasta.
Chopsticks for string beans.
Chopsticks for french fries.
Chopsticks for grilled chanterelles.
Indeed, chopsticks for just about anything, except perhaps a thick hunk of meat.
I have one friend who even uses them to eat ice cream.

LEAD: Alain Tanner, the Swiss director of ''La Salamandre,'' ''In the Middle of the World'' and ''Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000,'' has been one of the most securely cerebral of European film makers.
Like Eric Rohmer, with whom he otherwise has little in common, Mr.
Tanner makes films about people who think and talk and argue about matters of importance, often at cross-purposes and sometimes for little ultimate effect.

U.S. WILL EXAMINE A METAL'S EFFECTS
LEAD: The Department of Energy announced today that it planned to conduct a study to determine the effects of beryllium, a toxic metal, on thousands of workers in nuclear weapons plants exposed to the substance, The Energy Department designated a special panel, which is already looking into how well the department is assessing the health of its workers, to help design the study on beryllium.


Aristech Gets Bid
LEAD: The Aristech Chemical Corporation's stock rose $5.50, to $24.625, on the New York Stock Exchange today, after the company said it had received a cash bid of $26 a share, or $845 million, from a group that includes Aristech's chairman, Thomas Marshall, and the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan.
The Pittsburgh-based company has virtually ignored a previous offer of $25 a share made in October by Jon Huntsman, a Salt Lake City investor.

BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Akzo N.V., Arnheim, the Netherlands, a chemical company, said it would discontinue its two joint ventures with Kollmorgen Corp., Simsbury, Conn., and had set up a new joint venture with AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., a maker of electrical and electronic connectors.
The new joint venture will acquire the business of Additive Products Co., one of the joint ventures of Akzo and Kollmorgen.


Intel Profit Up Sharply
LEAD: The Intel Corporation today reported strong gains in earnings and revenue for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 30.
Revenue for the year was a record, but 1989 earnings declined from last year's level.

LEAD: A Senate bill to set Federal standards for private companies that test employees for drug use would provide consistency and eliminate lawsuits, Dr.
C.

LEAD: The contrast was striking: On the day last week when American electronics companies decided to abandon their cooperative venture to make computer chips, their competitors in Tokyo had already moved in lockstep.


Bulls Protest Tucker's Shot
LEAD: The National Basketball Association said yesterday that it had been notified by the Chicago Bulls that they intended to protest the Knicks' 109-106 victory Monday at Madison Square Garden.
The Knicks won the game on a 3-point basket by Trent Tucker with one-tenth of a second remaining.


The Punishment: To Knit
LEAD: A few people convicted of misdemeanors in Marquette County have been handed knitting needles and told by a local judge, Patricia Micklaw, to knit away their debt to society.
With yarn donated by a church, the offenders are knitting afghans, scarves, mittens and the like for the needy.

LEAD: There seems, finally, to be the promise of life in the Killing Fields.
If all goes well, the Khmer Rouge fanatics who slaughtered more than a million Cambodians in the 1970's will, under a plan sponsored by the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, be denied control of Cambodia.

AMR Net Falls 66.7% In Quarter
LEAD: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, yesterday reported sharply lower earnings in the fourth quarter mainly as a result of rising fuel costs.

LEAD: ''The Republicans,'' Ronald Reagan once declared, ''are the party of July Fourth and the Democrats are the party of April 15.''


Brainard Cheney, Novelist, 89
LEAD: Brainard Cheney, the author of five novels set in the swamp country of Georgia, died at a nursing home Monday after a long illness.
He was 89 years old.

LEAD: The New York Life Insurance Company, one of the nation's largest life insurers, yesterday named a new management lineup to take charge on Aug. 1.

LEAD: The Southmark Corporation, the troubled Texas real estate and financial services concern, filed a plan of reorganization in United States Bankruptcy Court today that would allow it to keep its troubled savings and loan institution, the San Jacinto Savings Association in Houston.

LEAD: Mike Richter, his entire body having wound up in the net in his attempt to keep the puck from doing the same, stared out through the cage of his goaltender's mask into the lights and applause of Madison Square Garden.
One of the sport's singular moments - a penalty shot - had become just another of his multiple successes.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.B.A.
Sharp Shooting Helps Celtics Win
Visiting Boston made its first 25 free throws last night in beating the Orlando Magic, 133-111.
Boston never trailed.
After the teams traded baskets in the first minute of the game, Boston went on a 12-point run.
Ed Pinckney was the only Celtic to miss a free throw, with 4 minutes 17 seconds left in the game, as the Celtics came within one of their team record of 26 in a row.


Turnovers Hurt Duke In Loss to the Tar Heels
LEAD: North Carolina's intense defense and Rick Fox's 19 points led the Tar Heels to a stunning 79-60 victory over Duke tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

Steel Imports Decline
LEAD: Steel imports in November fell 13 percent from October's level, and represented 18.9 percent of the domestic supply, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.
The November imports came to 1.49 million tons, compared with 1.7 million tons in October and 1.8 million tons in November 1988, the institute reported.

Nagasaki Mayor Is Shot in Attack
LEAD: The Mayor of Nagasaki, who has received numerous death threats from right-wing groups over his suggestion that the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot in chest today by a lone gunman in front of the City Hall in his home city.

Home Improvement
LEAD: BEFORE wallboard, paneling or accoustical tile can be attached to finished and sometimes to unfinished walls and ceilings, a grid of narrow wooden strips called furring usually must be applied.
They provide smooth, flat surfaces to fasten the new material to, and to support it.

LEAD: Y. C. James Yen, founder of a movement to combat illiteracy, poverty and hunger in developing countries on three continents, died of pneumonia yesterday at St.

Soviet Wheat Purchase
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 525,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in March under a long-term grain-supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.
The wheat was sold by four private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program.

LEAD: The nation's trade deficit grew in November to $10.5 billion, the biggest monthly gap of 1989, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: A young entrepreneur who said he was seeking control of the Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. without explaining how he would finance his $197 million bid or address the Australian conglomerate's immense debt said on Tuesday that he had abandoned the offer.

LEAD: ''Mystery'' has finally apprehended Hercule Poirot, Agatha Christie's best known detective.
In the nine-part series that begins tonight at 8 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channel 49, the nattily turned-out little egoist is played by David Suchet, exuding superiority from the shine of his pomaded hair to the sheen of his spats.

LEAD: The most popular opposition leader in Myanmar, formerly Burma, was disqualified today from running in elections scheduled for May, Western diplomats said.

LEAD: Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins' coach, has agreed to a three-year contract extension, The Palm Beach Post reported yesterday.

Max Gordon, Daily Worker Editor, 79
LEAD: Max Gordon, who was city editor of The Daily Worker when he broke with the Communist Party in 1956 and who later was a medical writer for Purdue-Frederick, a pharmaceutical company, died of a heart attack Monday at the West Boca Raton (Fla.) Medical Center.
He was 79 years old and lived in Boca Raton.


Mr. Cuomo, at Least, Is Serious
LEAD: He might have started sooner, but Gov.
Mario Cuomo has now faced up directly to the harsh fiscal reality facing New York.
There will be debate about details of his austere new state budget but taken as a whole, it represents a serious response to a chill fact: Tax revenues are in sharp decline.


Groupe Bull Plan On Zenith Division
LEAD: Groupe Bull, the French computer company that bought the computer business of the Zenith Electronics Corporation late last year, said yesterday that it would keep the Zenith operation a separate division with its own identity.
Bull said it would keep Zenith's headquarters in Schaumburg, Ill.

LEAD: Expressing deep concern over the latest tumultuous ethnic conflict to unsettle their country, many Soviet citizens voiced overwhelming support today for the decision by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to send troops to control violent fighting in parts of Azerbaijan.


Detectives Seek Leads in Officer's Shooting
LEAD: Detectives investigating the shooting of an off-duty police officer in Brooklyn on Tuesday night were left with more questions than answers yesterday as the officer remained in a coma at Kings County Hospital Center, police officials said.

LEAD: An Indianapolis art dealer has asked an appeals court to reverse a court order directing her to hand over four rare Byzantine mosaics from the sixth century to the Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus, court records showed today.


Perfect Record Restored
LEAD: The Illinois High School Association today restored the 14-0 record to the basketball team at Martin Luther King Jr.
High School in Chicago.
But a player the association declared ineligible will stay that way.

LEAD: For months, takeover talk has been driving up the stock price of the Consolidated Rail Corporation.
Yesterday, the railroad company, known as Conrail, moved to defend itself by announcing plans to spend about $1.3 billion to buy back more than a third of its outstanding shares.

Review/Music;   At Frick, Chamber Works Performed in a Chamber
LEAD: Public performances of chamber music these days seldom take place in chambers of the size for which much of the music was crafted, and when they do, adjustments are necessary.
Accustomed to having to project into the void of a small or even large concert hall, performers must scale down their sound a bit, and listeners, used to straining to hear a wee distant sound, must prepare for the immediacy and sheer volume of the close encounter.


The Shack as Art and Social Comment
LEAD: IN large, vibrant drawings, color photographs and evocative small wood structures, all set against the stark white walls of a SoHo art gallery, Beverly Buchanan celebrates the lowly shacks of the South in a new show.
The 30 pieces by Ms.
Buchanan, a 49-year-old artist who lives in Athens, Ga., will be on view through Feb.

Review/Theater;   The Details of Daily Life, Surrealistically
LEAD: Although ''Casa,'' Denise Stoklos's new performance piece at La Mama, bills itself as a comedy, it could just as accurately be called a mystery.
In her one-hour play, this Brazilian director, performer and writer, who calls her physically sparse, mimelike style of drama essential theater, heads a cast of eight actors, including her two children, who act out rituals of daily life in surrealistic caricature.


Silber of Boston University Enters Massachusetts Race
LEAD: Saying his role as a political outsider was an asset, John Silber, the president of Boston University for 19 years, declared today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor of Massachusetts.

Correction
LEAD: An obituary on Friday about Dudley Field Malone, a theatrical agent and manager, misidentified a position held by his father, who bore the same name.
He was Assistant Secretary of State under President Woodrow Wilson, not Assistant Secretary of the Navy under Franklin D. Roosevelt.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan recently advanced a proposal to reduce Social Security payroll taxes by $55 billion in 1991 and corresponding amounts in later years, thereby moving the Social Security system closer to pay-as-you-go financing.
Such a change of policy, however, would damage the economy.

Rig Count Slips in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United states dropped by 10 last week, to a total of 1,019, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday.
The count, which dropped for the fourth consecutive week, remains above the 840 rigs recorded a year earlier.
Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rotary rigs exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday.

Dirty Money, Dingy Justice
LEAD: Money launderers don't get their hands dirty.
They barely handle the cash that buys the drugs.
What they do is take the proceeds of drug sales and run them through as many transfer accounts as it takes to make the money look legitimate.
They don't poison American children; they merely bankroll the poison.

LEAD: ''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940'' is an exhibition that no thinking person can walk through without feeling a measure of both sorrow and anger.
The 100 or so paintings, sculptures and drawings gathered at the Corcoran Gallery of Art testify to a racism so ingrained in the American consciousness that artists - the overwhelming number of whom were white, but some of whom were black - thought nothing about stereotyping blacks as ''grotesque buffoons, servile menials, comic entertainers or threatening subhumans,'' writes Guy C.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
ECONOMY
U.S. oil production suffered its biggest single-year decline in 1989, falling by more than half a million barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute reported.
Imports surged to make up for the drop in domestic oil production.
As a result, the nation's dependence on imported oil rose to a near-record 46 percent of demand, the highest level in more than a decade.

In 1985, the players struck in August.

L.I. Baymen Resist Shellfishing Ban
LEAD: A battle between state officials and the baymen of eastern Long Island over closing rich shellfishing waters has erupted.
The issue is not polluted seas, but the number of state inspectors available to test the waters.

LEAD: In a matter of days, the joint war against drug trafficking conducted in this country by Mexico and the United States has been transformed into what Mexico's Attorney General today called ''a war of paper and images,'' with Americans and Mexicans lobbing salvos at one other through the press and television, and each accusing the other of being in league with drug dealers.

LEAD: It's unlikely that Abdi Bile will run a world indoor record time in the mile at the Sunkist Meet on Friday night or earn the $100,000 bonus that goes to anyone who does.

A Second Newspaper Is Shut by Lebanese General
LEAD: Gen.
Michel Aoun closed a second daily newspaper in the Christian sector today, barred publications from the Muslim part of Beirut and said journalists who did not agree with his policies should leave the country.


Bulgarian Party Leader Is Under House Arrest
LEAD: Todor Zhivkov, the ousted Communist Party leader, was put under house arrest today, charged with inciting ethnic hostilities and misuse of Government property and money, Bulgarian State Radio announced tonight.


1 Killed as Eastern Jet Rams a Small Plane on an Atlanta Runway
LEAD: An Eastern Airlines jetliner landing here tonight collided with a twin-engine aircraft that had just touched down, killing one person and injuring another aboard the smaller plane, officials said.


U.S. Growth Forecast
LEAD: The United States economy will grow by 2.5 percent to 3 percent in 1990, with one-third of the gain fueled by exports, according to study released Wednesday by the Conference Board. ''Although relying on exports to foreign markets is something new for the United States, it will become a permanent feature of the 1990's,'' said Gail Fosler, chief economist of the New York-based business research group.


Judge Strikes Down Law Forcing Release of College Tests
LEAD: A Federal judge has ruled that New York's truth-in-testing law, which requires standardized testing services to release questions and answers from their examinations, is unenforceable because it conflicts with Federal copyright law.

LEAD:
Friday
ON ICE FOR 50 YEARS


Apple Net Falls 11.2% in Period
LEAD: Amid a broad-based slowdown in the personal computer market, Apple Computer Inc. today reported an 11.2 percent decline in earnings and a 5.7 percent gain in revenues for its first fiscal quarter, which ended Dec. 29.


Mayor Who Faulted Hirohito Is Shot
LEAD: The Mayor of Nagasaki, who broke one of the nation's most sensitive taboos by saying a year ago that Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot today, and the police arrested a 40-year-old ultranationalist.


Phillips to Take A Write-Down
LEAD: The Phillips Petroleum Company will take a $280 million after-tax write-down on its offshore California investments that will cause the company's fourth-quarter earnings to plunge, company officials said.
The investments include the oil-rich Point Arguello field off Santa Barbara, which could hold as many as 500 million barrels of oil.


American Air's Route Changes
LEAD: Faced with a shortage of planes, American Airlines juggled its international routes to add new distinations and postponeothers on its trans-Atlantic routes to Europe.


Consumer Prices Up 4.6% in '89
LEAD: Consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as in November, the Labor Department reported today.
Increases quickened for fuel oil and natural gas, while food prices and medical care rose more slowly than in the previous month.
