Persian Folk Music
LEAD: Reza Derakhshani, a performer on the tar and the sehtar, two varieties of Iranian lute, will perform Persian folk music at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday afternoon at 2:30.
Mr.
Derakhshani's ensemble includes Kamran Rouhani on the tar; Arieh Aghajani on the santur, a hammered dulcimer; Kamran Hatami on the kamancheh, a fiddle, and Behzad Allahyar on the daff, a drum.

LEAD: In an unusual public comment for the Bush Administration on Federal Reserve policy, the White House said today that current economic conditions justified lower interest rates.

LEAD: Terry Marsh, a national hero who worked as a firefighter during the day and trained at night while holding the International Boxing Federation junior-welterweight crown, was charged yesterday with attempted murder in the shooting last November of his former manager, Frank Warren.

Digital Down; Tandem Off
LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported sharply lower earnings today for its second fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31.
The results were below analysts' already pessimistic estimates, sending its shares down $5.875, to $82, on the New York Stock Exchange.


Kraft General Foods Gets a New President
LEAD: Jeffrey C. Bible, an Australian by birth who has worked throughout Philip Morris's far-flung tobacco operations, has a major new assignment on the food side of the giant Philip Morris Companies.


Sankyo Buys Drug Maker
LEAD: The Sankyo Company, Japan's second-largest pharmaceutical concern, agreed today to acquire a majority interest in the privately held Luitpold-Werk Group, a drug maker and distributor based in Munich, West Germany.


TV Weekend;   Michael Caine Takes His Turn at 'Jekyll and Hyde'
LEAD: In films like ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' Michael Caine is adept at playing charming con men.
On television, though, he has taken to exploring seriously the darker side of Victorian society.
Last year, he played the Scotland Yard inspector pursuing the vicious serial killer in ''Jack the Ripper,'' directed by David Wickes.


Profit Outlook At Times Co.
LEAD: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it expected to report earnings of 83 cents to 88 cents a share from continuing operations in 1989.
In 1988 the company reported earnings from continuing operations of $2 a share.

LEAD: Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League, and Richard D. Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, met for 90 minutes yesterday, discussing ways to accommodate underclassmen who seek to be drafted by the N.F.L.

Louis W. Sullivan, expressed outrage today at the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for ''deliberately and cynically'' test-marketing a cigarette aimed primarily at blacks, and he assailed the company as ''promoting a culture of cancer.''


The Long Road Back for a Disgraced Patrician
LEAD: At the Center for Constitutional Rights, Mahlon F. Perkins Jr. is something of an oddball.
Among its young, polyglot legal staff, he is a 71-year-old patrician, who looks and speaks like Robert Frost.
His colleagues wear beards or blue jeans; he favors herringbone trousers.
They like rock music; he watches birds.


Panama-Latin Ties Linked to a Pullout
LEAD: Although President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle are opening a round of diplomacy to bolster the Panamanian Government, Administration officials said today that it was unrealistic to expect formal recognition by major countries in the region until the United States invasion force is withdrawn.

European Assembly Urges Grant to Armenia
LEAD: The European Parliament urged the European Community today to grant emergency aid to Armenia and the Nagorno-Karabakh region in Azerbaijan, but did not specify an amount.


Trouble Goes to Hawaii For 'Murder in Paradise'
LEAD: ''Murder in Paradise,'' tonight's ''NBC Movie of the Week,'' is about the burned-out New York City cop of the week.
Charlie Raski can be encountered at 9 P.M. beach-bumming and bar-boozing in Hawaii.
His problem is that he still wakes up sweating to nightmares about a murderer who killed his wife and eight other people back home with a nylon stocking and painted their faces, too.


Soviets Said to Withdraw Fighters and Bombers From Vietnam Base
LEAD: The Soviet Union has withdrawn all of its MIG-23 fighter planes and about half of its TU-16 bombers from its base at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, Pentagon officials said today, in a move the officials said would reduce Soviet military abilities in Southeast Asia.


2d Thoughts On Bank Deal
LEAD: Bank of New York Company executives are hinting that they are reconsidering the previously agreed-to acquisition of the Northeast Bancorp, a Shelton, Conn., company.


Ferranti Talks End
LEAD: Ferranti International P.L.C., the beleaguered British military electronics group, said in a statement that Thomson-CSF had ended talks on a possible bid for Ferranti.
Thomson has been considering the possibility of making a general offer for Ferranti, which is seeking a rescue from the effects of a reported fraud involving a United States unit.


Starts of Housing at Lowest Level Since '82
LEAD: Housing construction slumped in 1989 to its lowest level since the 1982 recession, the Government said today, but many analysts said further decreases in mortgage rates should improve the situation slightly in 1990.


On Land and in Air, Kennedy Delays Persist
LEAD: Even as Kennedy International Airport embarks on a $3 billion redevelopment, airline officials warn that the plan does not address congestion, especially on the expressways leading to the airport, that threatens its position as the nation's premier international gateway.


Student Testifies His Error Jammed Computer Network
LEAD: Several hours after creating a secret software experiment, a suspended computer science student recalled today, he returned to his terminal at Cornell University, to discover that his program had gone awry and was jamming a nationwide network of computers.


Scientists Use Gravity To 'See' Invisible Matter
LEAD: Astronomers are developing an ingenious way to use a gravitational phenomenon of the heavens to reveal the presence of the mysterious invisible matter believed to constitute the bulk of the universe.
This may lead them to an understanding of forces that shape galaxies, clusters of galaxies and even larger cosmic agglomerations.

Shuttle Set to Return After Escaping Erratic Spin
LEAD: Faulty navigational commands from the ground sent the space shuttle Columbia into an erratic spin last Wednesday, but the astronauts, roused from their sleep, brought the craft safely under control and then prepared for their scheduled return to Earth this morning.


Auctions
LEAD: The huge Americana auction Wednesday to Jan. 27 at Sotheby's is to include some remarkable examples of silver and porcelain tableware made for colonists and post-Civil War tycoons.
The sale of more than 1,490 lots will also offer porcelains, prints, genre paintings, ancestor portraits, folk art and furniture.

LEAD: Rumania's National Museum of Art, severely damaged in last month's popular uprising, was visited today by two senior officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art who said they wanted to see whether American art institutions could help in the restoration.


First Boston Chief Executive Is Shifted to New Position
LEAD: In a move that reflects troubles emanating from its financial exposure to the Campeau Corporation's retailing operations, the First Boston Corporation yesterday removed William E. Mayer as its chief executive and named him head of a new merchant banking subsidiary.

LEAD: In the current savings industry crisis, the collapse of Colorado's Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association would stand out even if one of its former directors were not Neil M. Bush, a son of the President.


Review/Art;   Contemporary Works From Africa
LEAD: ''Contemporary African Artists: Changing Tradition,'' opening on Sunday at the Studio Museum in Harlem, is important.
It comes at a time of increasing openness to art outside Europe and the United States, and in a careful, measured way, it lays groundwork and builds bridges others can use.
Eye-opening exhibitions will follow.


Soviet Press Disrupted By Republic's Violence
LEAD: The Soviet public is receiving only incomplete news reports on the violence raging in the southern Soviet Union as editors in Moscow are asserting that the problems of coverage are similar to those involved in reporting foreign conflicts.

Soviet Force in Vietnam Cut
Pentagon officials said Moscow had reduced its aircraft at Cam Ranh Bay, Vietnam, an American-built installation that has become Moscow's largest overseas naval base.

Ending of H.U.D. Program Seen as Blow to Developers
LEAD: Several housing experts warned today that the Government's decision to end a housing insurance program managed by private lenders could result in long delays in obtaining mortgages for private low- and moderate-income apartment buildings.


Profits at Pfizer Are Down 5.9%
LEAD: Pfizer Inc., the New York-based pharmaceutical company, reported yesterday that its net income fell 5.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 as a stronger dollar hurt sales overseas.


Rumanian Princesses Return Home


Dining Out Guide: Pasta
LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current.
Arqua
** (April 24, 1987), 281 Church Street (334-1888) - The chef who owns and runs this stylish TriBeCa restaurant seems to have a poetic streak, as evidenced by some lyrical pasta compositions.


Cigna to Buy Equicor In $777 Million Deal
LEAD: The Cigna Corporation, the insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $777 million in cash to buy Equicor from the Hospital Corporation of America and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, the joint owners of Equicor.


Changes to Cut Pillsbury Jobs
LEAD: In a move to improve the operating efficiency of its Pillsbury Inc. division, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. today announced a $140 million plant modernization program that will result in the elimination of up to 1,300 jobs as outdated production operations are closed.


Leonard Forfeits Crown
LEAD: If Sugar Ray Leonard fights again, it won't be as a champion.


Review/Film;   Underground Creatures and Dread Events
LEAD: ''Tremors'' is a jokey attempt to re-create the pleasures of those post-World War II B-pictures about commonplace creatures - ants, worms, flies, whatever - that, through some horrible mistake (usually related to radiation), become voracious giants.


U.N.'s Secretary General Agrees To Accept Invitation to Albania
LEAD: The United Nations Secretary General has agreed in principle to visit Albania, the last bastion of Stalinism in Europe and a nation accused of serious human rights abuses, diplomats and United Nations officials said today.


Relief Groups to Cross Rebel Lines in Ethiopia
LEAD: The Ethiopian Government has decided to let church-run relief agencies deliver food aid to one million people threatened by famine in a rebel-held northern province, the Archbishop of Canterbury said today.


Ex-Danbury Mayor's Trial: Extortion Tale Unfolds
LEAD: When a former mayor of Danbury, James E. Dyer, was indicted on extortion and racketeering charges last year, few believed that his trial would include testimony as titillating as allegations of payoffs in restaurant restrooms, cash hidden between the pages of The Wall Street Journal and illegal deals cut over coffee in City

Prodigy at 8, Winner at 21
LEAD: Less than 48 hours after shocking the golf world by winning the first tournament he had ever entered as a PGA Tour professional, Robert Gamez's bliss was disturbed by a frightening voice that filled the California desert with a dark vision of his future.


Filion Driver of the Year
LEAD: Herve Filion, who won a world-record 814 races and passed the 12,000 mark in career victories, was named Driver of the Year for 1989.
The award was the 10th for Filion from Harness Tracks of America, which has 43 members in the United States and Canada.
Filion got 92 points.
John Campbell was second with 80.(

Review/Pop;   Black Rock Coalition Sunders Stereotypes
LEAD: Over the last four years, the Black Rock Coalition, an organization of more than 30 bands that was created to support black musicians playing rock-related music, has slowly but surely been attacking pervasive social problems in the music industry.
By regularly presenting concerts featuring groups that defy musical categorization and the racial stereotyping that goes with it, it has exposed an ugly way of thinking that has been intertwined with the marketing, consumption and criticism of music.

LEAD: As he completes his first year in office, George Bush, helped by overwhelming support for the invasion of Panama, stands higher in the public's approval than any President has at an equivalent point in his administration since John F. Kennedy, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

Review/Art;   18 Works of an Evolving Rothko, a la Francaise
LEAD: The Pace Gallery's latest look at Mark Rothko's achievement is a selection of 18 transitional canvases from 1946-48 that cast the painter in a new role, a role more openly hedonistic and flawed than the Rothko of Abstract Expressionist fame.
These abstract paintings glow with intimations of Rothko's maturity: the saturated colors, the soft-edged forms that push those colors toward the eye.


Texaco's Profit Declines 3%; Environmental Costs Cited
LEAD: Texaco Inc. said its fourth-quarter earnings declined 3 percent, partly because of a $355 million charge for environmental improvement programs.

Pop/Jazz;   Remember Mickey Katz? No? Well, Just Listen to This.
LEAD: WHEN the young clarinetist Don Byron steps on stage at the Knitting Factory tomorrow, he'll be reclaiming the music of a long-forgotten composer working in a long-forgotten genre.
The 30-year-old Mr.
Byron, along with a 10-piece band, will be performing a concert of pieces by Mickey Katz, a clarinetist, a musical director for Spike Jones, a klezmer musician, a composer and the father of the actor Joel Grey.

LEAD: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who was stripped of the 100-meter gold medal he won in the 1988 Summer Olympics after he tested positive for steroids, received a summons after he was involved in a minor accident on Wednesday in Lincoln, Ontario, the Niagara regional police said.

LEAD: Competition from increased legal sports betting may be the greatest battle in horse racing in the years ahead, and the sport appeared to lose an early skirmish this week.


Nintendo Plans Comic Book Line

Money Fund Assets Soar
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 488 money market mutual funds soared by $5.29 billion, to $381.11 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 147 institutional funds increased by $2.03 billion, to $92.65 billion.
The assets of the 243 general-purpose funds were up by $1.85 billion, to $126.66 billion.


World Economic Aide Sees Trouble for Warsaw Policy
LEAD: After a three-day visit to Poland, the leader of a delegation from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that there were major difficulties ahead for Poland's economic liberalization program.

Serendipity Is the Password At the Antiques Show
LEAD: ANTIQUES shows are invariably made memorable by the regal objects antiques dealers present.
This year's Winter Antiques Show has a generous representation of ancient gods and goddesses decked out in Neo-Classical finery, stern-faced ancestor portraits, and such exotica as Louis XIV's wine cooler from Versailles (a marble tub with gilded images of sunbursts and lions' faces), and George Washington in the form of an aristocratic stove figure.

LEAD: The violist Paul Neubauer is to be the soloist with the National Orchestral Association in the world premiere of Joel Phillip Friedman's Concerto for Viola and Orchestra at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8.

LEAD: Antonio Cipollone, whose lawsuit against three cigarette makers resulted in the first jury award against the industry involving the death of a smoker, has himself died, his wife said today.
He was 66 years old.

For Jurors, Facts Could Not Be Sifted From Fantasies
LEAD: In the end, the jurors said, the facts and fantasies that blend in the memories of small children, influenced by the comments of parents and legal questioners, did not offer a firm enough basis for a conviction in the McMartin child molestation trial that ended today.

Beijing to Limit More Posts In Hong Kong to the Chinese
LEAD: China, which has said it will bar holders of foreign passports from top government jobs in Hong Kong after Beijing resumes sovereignty in 1997, will extend the ban to more posts, a Chinese official said today.


Worried About Its Own Azerbaijanis, Teheran Acts With Caution
LEAD: The armed revolt in Azerbaijan has been received with apprehension in Iran, where an estimated 16 million Azerbaijanis represent the largest ethnic minority and have at times challenged the authority of the Teheran Government.


Restaurants
LEAD: Lightheartedness is not a trait that comes to mind when one thinks of sun-starved, hard-working Scandinavians.
So I'm never surprised upon entering Aquavit, the Nordic palace on West 54th Street, to encounter an impassive hostess at the door who whispers, ''Reservations?''


New York Schools Chief Challenges Boards' Power
LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez mounted a frontal assault yesterday on New York City's decentralized school system, demanding that its 32 local boards clear all candidates for district superintendent with him.


Risk Is Seen in Needless Removal of Asbestos
LEAD: Removing undisturbed asbestos from schools and other buildings could needlessly expose the removal workers to cancer, scientists say.


M/A-COM Deficit
LEAD: M/A-COM Inc. said it expects to post a loss of about $115 million for its quarter ended Dec. 30.
Stock in the Burlington, Mass., company fell 50 cents today, to $4.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its decline of 8.1 percent was the fifth worst of the day.
The loss will cover an operating loss and an estimate of the impact closing some business and product lines and shrinking others.


Israelis Accuse a P.L.O. Aide
LEAD: A military court today identified a leading West Bank Palestinian as a supporter and financial backer of the so-called Palestine Popular Army in an indictment of five alleged members of the group.

Argentines Take to the Streets Against Inept Police
LEAD: In a notable shift from the fear Argentines felt of the police during the military Government just a decade ago, residents of several provincial towns have recently risen up in mass protest and accused their local police of corruption and laziness.


Edward H. Kass, 72, Researcher on Toxic Shock
LEAD: Edward H. Kass, an epidemiologist who was a leading researcher into the mechanism of toxic shock syndrome in menstruating women, died of lung cancer Wednesday at his home in Lincoln, Mass.
He was 72 years old.


India Names New Governor for Troubled Kashmir
LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh reassigned a popular former Governor today to Jammu and Kashmir state, where a secessionist movement is taking on alarming proportions for India.


Agents Kill Two Linked to Series Of Bank Thefts
LEAD: F.B.I. agents and New York City detectives who were following a car linked to a series of bank robberies opened fire yesterday on two masked men who left a savings and loan branch in Brooklyn with guns drawn and a satchel of cash.
One suspect, still wearing a stocking mask and a ski cap, died in the barrage of bullets.

LEAD: For many years, the only unofficial Soviet artist to have achieved a measure of fame in the West was Ilya Kabakov.
Mr.
Kabakov's works were shown in Western Europe as early as 1965, and he became known as the leader of a generation of artists whose activities were not sanctioned by the authorities in Moscow.

Pace of Giving To Neediest Is on Increase
LEAD: With the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund drive now past its midpoint, proceeds are ahead of last year's collections by more than a quarter of a million dollars.
If giving continues at the same pace, the drive will again break records when it closes on Feb. 28.
Last year, the $4 million mark was reached for the first time.


Boeing Plans Worker Cuts At Factories
LEAD: Despite an $80 billion backlog of orders for commercial airliners, the Boeing Company said yesterday that its factory work force had grown too large and would be reduced this year by 5,000 workers.

LEAD: The state's highest court today upheld the arbitration process set up by New York's ''lemon law,'' which was passed in 1983 to protect residents who buy cars that turn out to be clunkers.

LEAD: EXECUTIVES in the securities and futures industry have mounted an intense lobbying campaign to change the conclusions of a draft report by an independent Congressional agency that questions some fundamental aspects of the nation's financial system.


Suspect Shot In Terminal At Rush Hour
LEAD: A man the state police said was a suspect in a burglary in Dutchess County was shot and seriously wounded by the Metro-North police last night at Grand Central Terminal as he got off a train he had taken to Manhattan.
Metro-North officials said the officers fired after the man pulled a revolver and pointed it at the officers who met the train.

2 Die as Jet Crashes in Ohio
LEAD: A twin-engine cargo jet crashed today in a rural area 15 to 20 miles northwest of here, killing the pilot and a passenger, aviation officials said.
The Lear 23 jet, chartered by Aero Flight Services, was on its way from Ypsilanti, Mich., to Louisville, Ky., to pick up cargo when it crashed, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman said.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: When the model JERRY HALL makes her London stage debut on Thursday, she may have more than comedy on her mind.

Oberlin Choir
LEAD: The Oberlin College Choir will give the world premiere of Edward Miller's ''Bad Dreams,'' a setting of poetry by Donald Justice, tomorrow evening at 8 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.
The program, which is to be conducted by Daniel Moe, also includes Stravinsky's Mass.
Tickets are $7.50 to $15.
Information: 840-2824.


Treasury Issues Decline Sharply
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in more than six months yesterday in a selloff that traders said was largely spurred by comments from two Federal Reserve Board governors that suggested the Fed was not about to ease monetary policy again any time soon.

Quake Jolts California Coast
LEAD: A moderate earthquake jolted the Northern California coastline early today, but no injuries or damage was reported.
The epicenter of the earthquake, which registered 5.1 on the Richter scale, was at the juncture of the San Andreas and Mendocino faults, 30 miles northeast of here, said a spokeswoman for the United States Geological Survey in Menlo Park.

LEAD: Time is at once the composer's ally and enemy.
Ally because music exists over a certain measurable span or it does not exist at all.
Enemy because it forces the composer, like the listener, to face the fact of its frightening, inexorable flow.

Mavericks Bracing For Knicks
LEAD: When the Dallas Mavericks gathered for practice this morning to prepare for Friday night's game here with the Knicks, they met to talk about such problems as how to end their five-game losing streak, and how to get more scoring from Herb Williams, Randy White, Brad Davis and Anthony Jones.
Those key bench players have been outscored by the opponent's bench by an average of 34.8 points to 18.5 in the last 12 games.


Czech-Vatican Ties Restored
LEAD: Czechoslovakia's new Government decided today to restore full relations with the Vatican after a break of more than 40 years.
The official news agency C.T.K. said the Government had decided that ''diplomatic contacts with the Holy See be restored'' but gave no details.


Uncovered Short Sales Decline by 6.4% on the Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined by 35.3 million shares, or 6.4 percent, in the four-week period ended Jan. 12.
Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

LEAD: Retiring to Florida is still a cherished dream for millions of Americans.
And midwinter is the time when those on the edge of leaving the workday world come from the Northeast and other cold areas to look for a community that will suit them.

Senator Tells of His Cancer
LEAD: Senator Spark M. Matsunaga disclosed today that he is being treated for prostate cancer. ''I can't conclude at this juncture that this condition is debilitating to the extent that I should step down,'' the 73-year-old Democrat from Hawaii said in a statement.
But he added, ''If it appears that my attendance in the second session of the 101st Congress does not show marked improvement over the record of the first session, I will reassess my present intention of fulfilling my term of office.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 20, 1990
LEAD:
Companies


Transactions
LEAD:
Baseball


Two Greats Collide
LEAD: I have a lot of trouble with the light-year.
For one thing I can never remember how far a piece of light travels per second.


The Boundaries of War
LEAD: Popular revolts and Communist change have, in weeks, redrawn Europe's political map.
In the West, the European Community debates opening its doors to the East.
In the East, nationality questions long frozen by totalitarian rule again glow hot.
With so much in flux, strategists, statesmen and bureaucrats grope for constants.


News Summary
LEAD:
International
3-9
Soviet troops fired on Azerbaijanis in Baku, pushing through street barricades with tanks toward the center of the city.
Some armed civilians were reportedly resisting.
Page 1
Kremlin abandons mobilization of troops
6
The White House watches helplessly as the turmoil unfolds in the Soviet Union, even as it has begun to take a more active, hands-on approach to the nations of Eastern Europe.

Study for Congress Calls Report on Nutrition Program Misleading
LEAD: A revision of an Agriculture Department study unjustifiably played down the benefits of a popular $1.9 billion nutrition program intended to help poor women and children, Congressional investigators said in a report made public today.


Duel With the Sun


Chronicle
LEAD: JAVIER PEREZ DE CUELLAR received a lot of long-distance calls yesterday.
On his 70th birthday the Secretary General of the United Nations received good wishes in a call from PRESIDENT BUSH, plus calls and messages from heads of state, foreign ministers and ambassadors of just about every nation.


Putting the Best Face on Bankruptcy
LEAD: It is not easy to make bankruptcy look like a positive development, but Bloomingdale's certainly tried this week.
The president of the famous retailer, Marvin S. Traub, appeared on the three big television networks with a message directed mainly at consumers: The stores are open for business; the worst is behind us; suppliers will continue to deliver goods, and a new period is beginning.

Protest Against English Cricketers Crushed by South African Police


Tomisaburo Hashimoto Dies at 88
LEAD: Tomisaburo Hashimoto, a powerful official who was convicted in the bribery scandal that swept the Government in the mid-1970's, died of pneumonia today, a hospital official said.
He was 88 years old.


Treasury Issues Post Best Gain of '90
LEAD: Treasury bond prices yesterday posted their best gain of 1990 in a rally that began overnight in Tokyo and continued in the London and New York markets.
Dealers said the recovery was sustained by domestic retail investors and professional traders who were covering short positions.


ISRAEL'S MOVE IRKS STATE DEPARTMENT
LEAD: On Wednesday, the State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, described as "not helpful" a statement by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, vowing to hold on to the West Bank and the Gaza Strip because "a big strong state of Israel" is needed to accommodate a wave of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union.

Corrections
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press on Thursday about Barbara Piasecka Johnson's offer to buy the Lenin ship-yard in Gdansk, Poland, misidentified the position of her late husband, J. Seward Johnson Sr., with Johnson &amp; Johnson.
He served on its board, but was never chairman.

LEAD: Tom O'Toole (Nick Nolte), a hotshot private investigator who is also something of a publicity hound, is called to the small New England city of Highbury to look into the murder conviction of a teen-age boy.
Tom's contact is Angela Crispini (Debra Winger), a young woman of no visible means of support and almost lunatic intensity.

BRIDGE
LEAD: A promising effort to teach bridge to the hearing impaired began on Tuesday at the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, at 71 West 23d Street in Manhattan.
But the organizers ran into some problems because they had underestimated the difficulty of teaching the game to nine tables of players with widely varying skill levels and differing degrees of impairment.

LEAD: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. turned over most of his duties to the city manager today after appearing before a Federal magistrate on a misdemeanor charge of using crack cocaine.

Savings Bank's Chief Resigns
LEAD: William E. Gibson resigned unexpectedly today as chairman, president, chief executive and a director of the American Federal Savings Bank.


Oil Barge Is Grounded On Housatonic Shoal
LEAD: A barge loaded with 42,000 barrels of heavy fuel oil ran aground yesterday on a shoal in the Housatonic River near Stratford, trapping it in the sandy area for more than eight hours, a Coast Guard spokesman said.


Upheval in the East;   State Dept. Team Finds Nations in Afghan Conflict Flexible on Future Rule
LEAD: A State Department delegation exploring ways to end the war in Afghanistan completed a weeklong visit to the region today, convinced that the nations involved in the conflict are more amenable to a compromise that would not leave one party or leader in a dominant position.


Records in Jeopardy
LEAD: Ben Johnson's records in the 100 meter and the indoor 50-and 60-meter dashes may be voided this weekend when the International Amateur Athletic Federation holds two days of council meetings in Tokyo.


AIDS Doctor Falters And Halts Testimony
LEAD: Dr.
Veronica Prego returned to the witness stand yesterday, but quickly said she could not continue, causing a recess in the trial of her $175 million lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.


Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;   A Worried Washington Is Keeping Its Distance
LEAD: Soviet experts in the Bush Administration were scrambling late today for information on the fighting in Baku between the Soviet Army and Azerbaijanis, which Administration experts said seemed the inevitable next step in the drama in the Caucasus.

Koch Adds a Job to His List
LEAD: Edward I. Koch has been hired as a director of William A. White/Grubb &amp; Ellis, a Manhattan-based real-estate concern, the company said yesterday.
The job is one of several that the former New York City Mayor has taken since leaving office Jan. 1, including joining a law firm, appearing on televsion and radio, writing a newspaper column and selling a diet aid.

Chronicle
LEAD: The investment banker, political adviser and economic soothsayer FELIX G. ROHATYN has a new concern: his shape.

1989 Surge in Anti-Semitic Acts Is Reported by B'nai B'rith
LEAD: Anti-Semitic incidents, ranging from desecration to murder, reached their highest level in 1989 since the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith began collecting statistics 11 years ago, the group said in its annual audit.

LEAD: Disaster is a timely teacher.
The oil spill that has raised havoc at the nature sanctuary around Pralls Island in the Arthur Kill presents a costly lesson in ways to prevent and deal with such destruction.
Beyond that it carries a lesson about ways to deal with nature - and the ways nature deals with itself.

A Fed Reappointment
LEAD: President Bush plans to reappoint Edward W. Kelley Jr. to a seat on the Federal Reserve Board, the White House said today.
Mr.
Kelley, who has served as a Fed governor since 1987, will be nominated for a 14-year term that begins Feb. 1.
Before his first appointment to the Fed, Mr.
Kelley was chairman of the board of Investors Advisors Inc.

LEAD: Officials of the United States Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that Exxon was negligent and irresponsible for failing for 12 years to fix the leak-detection system on a pipeline that ruptured Jan. 1, spilling several hundred thousand gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill.


Earth Fog Keeps Shuttle in Orbit
LEAD: The space shuttle Columbia was forced to stay in orbit an extra day today because of fog at its desert landing site this morning.
It is now scheduled to touch down early Saturday to end the longest shuttle mission yet.

Corrections
LEAD: A front-page illustration in Science Times on Jan 9. with an article about the Giant Keck Telescope in Hawaii depicted its mirror incorrectly.
As the article said, the mirror has 36 hexagonal segments, not 37.
The center hexagon is left empty to let a light beam pass through the mirror.

Using 2 Ways to Run One School System
LEAD: In the short time that Joseph A. Fernandez has been Chancellor of New York City's school system, he has both championed the notion of school-based management and wielded an unprecedented authority from his seat at the Board of Education headquarters.
In less than a month in office, Mr.
Fernandez has reached down into the heart of the city's decentralized system to bypass local school boards and remove one superintendent, block the appointment of another and dismiss principals.

Child Abuse - and Trial Abuse
LEAD: Correct or not, the verdict in the McMartin Preschool case comes appallingly late and at an astonishing price.
The jury delivered the best justice it could after a 30-month trial.
But the only justice a 30-month trial can render is medieval.
California, and other states, must find more sensible ways to deal with child molestation cases.


World Steel Output Up
LEAD: World crude steel output rose to a record of 783.5 million metric tons in 1989, up five-tenths of 1 percent from 1988, the International Iron and Steel Institute said this week.
The rise was led by developing countries, which increased output by 3.7 percent, to a record 100.9 million tons, from 97.3 million tons in 1988, the institute said.


Atwater Urges Softer Abortion Line
LEAD: Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, sent a powerful signal of his party's new approach to abortion today, declaring that there were no litmus tests in the party and that Republicans should support Republican candidates regardless of their stand on the issue.

UAL Up on Report Of New Proposal
LEAD: The stock of the UAL Corporation shot up yesterday after a report was published that Marvin Davis, the California investor who last August started a bidding contest for the airline company, planned a new offer around $5.6 billion.
UAL's shares rose $7.375 each, at $165.625, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.


PROSPECT GROUP BOARD BACKS SELLING ASSETS
LEAD: In a radical move intended to increase value for shareholders, the directors of the Prospect Group Inc. authorized a plan yesterday that would sell substantially all of its assets and distribute the proceeds to investors.

Review/Music;   Stravinsky's 'Oedipus Rex,' Without Attic Trappings
LEAD: ''Oedipus Rex,'' Stravinsky's ''opera-oratorio after Sophocles,'' was written in 1927 while the Russian composer lived as an exile in France.
In a gesture characteristic of his rootless artistry throughout a long career as a displaced person, he decided that a work by a Russian drawn from a Greek tragedy would be sung in a dead language, Ciceronian Latin, and narrated in the language of whatever country in which it was performed.

Jordache Assets
LEAD: Jean Philippe Fragrances Inc. said it had acquired the assets of Jordache Cosmetics and Fragrances, a unit of Jordache Enterprises.
The transaction is valued at about $6 million payable over the term of the license.
Jean Philippe acquired a 16-year exclusive license to sell Jordache fragrances in the United States and a license to sell them worldwide.


Upheaval in the East: Reporter's Notebook;   Beret Meets Gold Braid: Generals Out of the Cold
LEAD: It had neither the drama of the crumbling of the Berlin wall nor the setting of the maritime summit meeting in Malta.
But the cloakroom in the Hofburg Palace this week may well merit a place among images that chart the waning of the cold war.


Court in El Salvador Indicts 8 Soldiers in Jesuit Slayings
LEAD: A colonel, two lieutenants and five lower ranking military officials were charged today with the slayings of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and the housekeeper's daughter.


Noriega Was Close to Suicide, Aide Says
LEAD: Realizing that he had been cornered by the United States troops, Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega originally decided to commit suicide rather than surrender or risk being ''shot by some G.I.
Joe from Missouri,'' a close associate asserted today.

Review/Dance;   Exploring the Extremes of Looming and Oozing
LEAD: Several programs in the two-week Man-Made festival, which ends on Sunday at the Joyce Theater, have suggested that modern dance, at least in New York, has come into an age of elevated inconsequence.
Grand themes and choreographic visions seem to be out these days.
Exploration is in, but too often it is relatively superficial exploration of such concerns as the structuring of a dance or ways to push the human body to physical extremes.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in weekend yesterday about the WInter Antique Show misstated the price of a pair of andirons at the Gerald Kornblau booth.
They are $22,000.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
GOLF
Outdoing the Wind
Liselotte Neumann of Sweden tamed the wind yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the Jamaica Classic in Montego Bay, the season opener of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association.
Neumann toured the front 9 in three-under 31, then matched par-37 after the turn for a three-under-par 68.

Chronicle
LEAD: The first annual William J. Brennan Award is to be presented to - WILLIAM J. BRENNAN.
The New York State Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers will honor the Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court on Jan. 26 at its annual dinner at the Grand Hyatt hotel.

Rusty Hamer, Actor, 42
LEAD: Rusty Hamer, a child actor in the television series ''Make Room for Daddy'' in the 1950's and 60's, was found dead of a gunshot wound in his home on Thursday.
He was 42 years old.

Sony's New Recorder
LEAD: The Sony Corporation said today that it had developed an ultracompact digital memo recorder.
The recorder uses tapes the size of postage stamps that can record for up to two hours.
It will be commercially available later this year, a spokesman said.
No indication of price was given today.

A Top Palestinian Is Seized By Israel a Ally Of Revolt
LEAD: The Israeli. police arrested the West Bank's most prominent Palestinian nationalist today and charged him with helping an illegal organization involved in the uprising in the occupied territories.


A 'Thrilled' Carter Signs With Giants for a Year
LEAD: Gary Carter three-putted the 13th hole in the third round of the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic today, then announced: ''I'm very happy.
I'm very excited.
I'm thrilled to death.
I'm looking forward to it.''

Baghwan Shree Rajneesh, Indian Guru, Dies at 58
LEAD: Baghwan Shree Rajneesh, the Indian guru who attracted thousands of followers at his Oregon commune in the early 1980's before being deported from the United States, died yesterday of heart disease at his commune in Poona, in southern India, members of his entourage there told reporters.
He was 58 years old.

Soviet Bank in China
LEAD: The Soviet Union has opened a bank in the Chinese capital for the first time since relations between the two natons soured in the early 1960's, an official of the Soviet bank said today.
The Vneshtorgbank (Foreign Trade Bank) began business on Jan. 12.
The merchant bank still has no permanent offices in China and is operating in diplomatic quarters, the official said.

Continental Air Delays Merit Raises
LEAD: Continental Airlines has frozen merit raises for its managers in the latest of a series of cost cutbacks.
The airline's managers said they were told last week not to expect the raises, which are normally available every six months, until later this year. ''Merit increases are being postponed until sometime in the fall,'' a Continental spokesman, Art

Donold Lourie, 91, A Retired Chairman Of Quaker Oats Co.
LEAD: Donold B. Lourie, former chairman of the Quaker Oats Company, who served briefly as Under Secretary of State in the Eisenhower Administration, died of heart failure Monday in Longwood, Fla., where he lived in retirement.
He was 91 years old.

RENTING SKI GEAR
LEAD:
When renting ski equipment, take your time and be choosy.
You will be asked your skiing level: I, II, or III.
Beginners who ski slowly and prefer gentle slopes are Level I. Intermediate skiers, Level II, prefer a variety of terrain including, at times, the most difficult.
Advanced skiers, Level III, seek the steepest terrain.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of a transmission error, an article on Tuesday about reaction in Minnesota to the problems of Senator David Durenberger misidentified the Mayor of Minneapolis.
He is Don Fraser.


If Your Water Has a Bad Taste
LEAD: If you are unhappy with the taste of the water from your tap, do some research before buying a device to treat drinking water.
A unit can cost from $40 to $900, and the Federal Trade Commission says water that tastes unpleasant is not necessarily contaminated.

THE LEGAL VIEW OF N.F.L. DRAFT POLICY
LEAD: The National Football League policy against drafting underclassmen imposes unjustifiable injury on college athletes and is therefore legally insupportable.
It constitutes a conspiracy by all employers in this industry to bar from gainful employment a group that is ready, willing and able to work.

LEAD: A New York City police officer was suspended without pay yesterday after he was charged with driving while intoxicated in a fatal accident on Long Island, the police said.

Friday at the intersection of Hallock Road and Route 347 in Stony Brook, L.I., the police said.

BLUE MAX CAN DELIVER AN EARFUL
LEAD: Audio isn't just a matter of nuts, bolts and other assorted hardware.
Equally important to good sound reproduction is the study of psychoacoustics - a hybrid science straddling various borders between physics, music, engineering and biology.
Its aim is to understand the ways in which human beings perceive sound.

Johnson Loses Marks
LEAD: He may be the fastest sprinter the world has ever seen, but Ben Johnson is no longer a world-record holder.
Citing Johnson's admitted use of steroids over most of the last decade, track and field's international governing body voted yesterday to strip the 28-year-old Canadian runner of his three remaining records, in the 100-meter dash and the indoor 50- and 60-meter events.


FICTION
LEAD:
BALANCING ACTS: Contemporary Stories by Russian Women.
Edited by Helena Goscilo. (Indiana University, Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $17.50).
What do Russian women want?
Everything, apparently, that many other women do: the stable love of a good man and the mad passion of a lover, the security of home and hearth and the fulfillment of professional achievement, the gratitude of their children and freedom from the noose of motherhood.

Garment Steamers Recalled
LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company is recalling more than 1,000 electric garment steamers that present a possible hazard to users, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says.
Consumers reported that a locking mechanism on a steamer plug could be broken during use, releasing hot water and steam.

Batcheller has painted a lovely picture of a nature lover out for a quiet morning walk, not a picture of hunting at all.

KATHY MCINERNEY
Portland, Me.

LEAD: To almost everyone, Charles Stuart's story that a black gunman had killed his pregnant wife and then shot him in the stomach seemed so believable.

Stuart from the start.


In Paris, Lace and Luxe
LEAD: AT Sabbia Rosa, where silk robes spill from padded hangers in streams of coral and peach, customers eye delicate bras edged in lace.
The tiny Left Bank shop on the Rue des Saints-Peres has long been a magnet for those who appreciate fine lingerie and Miss Rosa's sweet tooth for color.
A vivacious woman with a froth of curly hair, she proudly shows off her guest book, with signatures from the actor Dustin Hoffman and the model Cindy Crawford.

Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
LEAD: There was not just one bet between Barkley and Jackson.
The first came during last season's playoffs.
Then there was a series of three during the Jan. 10 game, each coming before critical situations.
Betting can become infectious and contagious.
The $5,000 fines to players earning megabucks has little impact.

Airport Security: A Case in Point
LEAD: ISSUES of travel security make everyone uneasy.
The yes-no aspect of an airport is an example.
At departure, an airport is supposed to lure you in and cosset you into the wonders of travel; at the end of the flight, the arrival airport is supposed to welcome you to the new place and hint at its attractions.

Don't Fault Phil Simms
LEAD: To the Sports Editor In the midst of the recriminations thrown right and left about the Giants' overtime loss to the Rams, a couple of vital points have not been mentioned in any of the press reports I read.
Forget the disputed pass-interference penalty against Sheldon White in overtime.
That can be argued from now until doomsday without a resolution.

LEAD: MOST of the county's choirs gave their winter concerts last month and are now preparing their spring programs.
The Ossining Choral Society, on the other hand, has chosen to wait for the holiday bustle to fade before beginning its 53d season with a performance of Haydn's ''Creation.''


How Yonkers Has Held Off on Housing
LEAD: IT has been 10 years since the Justice Department, later joined by the N.A.A.C.P., brought suit against Yonkers, and five years since a Federal judge found the city guilty of intentional discrimination in housing and schools.
But after all the litigation, not one unit of housing has been built to remedy the discrimination and the fight is far from over.


Jerk, Jamaica's Fiery Barbecue
LEAD: SINCE dawn, Taylor Dudley of Boston Beach, Jamaica, has been at work turning a pig and plenty of hot peppers into jerk, the island's devilishly hot answer to barbecue.
At outdoor pits like Mr.
Dudley's, roadside stands and restaurants throughout Jamaica, pork, plus chicken, conch and native fish are given the distinctive jerk treatment.

POSTING: Brewhouse Conversion;   Orange Rentals
LEAD: An 1890's brewhouse in Middletown, N.Y., abandoned for more than half a century, is being redeveloped into 53 moderate and low-rent apartments.
The three-story structure at one time produced ''Orange County - The King of All Beers - The Cream of All Ales,'' popular in the area until the mid-30's.
Local historians have cited the brewhouse, a three-story brick building with an ornate facade, as a good example of a type of local brewery that flourished in the Hudson and Mohawk


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
Senior Bowl
North 41, South 0: Louisiana State's Tom Hodson passed for two first-quarter touchdowns and Penn State's Blair Thomas ran for 137 yards, leading the North to victory in the 41st Senior Bowl yesterday at Mobile, Ala.
It was the first shutout in Senior Bowl history and the victory cut the South's series lead to 20-18-3.


Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Indoors, start seed of long season annuals such as snapdragons, impatiens, petunias and geraniums.
Check house plants for mealybugs; examine jade plants, look under leaves of streptocarpus, African violets and other gesneriads, also check cactuses to be sure insects are not hiding near the bases of the spines.

Kudos Come When Actors Abandon Type
LEAD: Meryl Streep acts silly, Tom Cruise looks grungy and Danny DeVito is the voice of reason; this season's films have been a parade of big-name stars acting against type.
And while Ms.
Streep is hilarious as the husband-stealing romance writer draped in acres of pink satin in ''She-Devil,'' and Mr.
Cruise flawless as the paraplegic Vietnam veteran in ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' their performances are enhanced by an undeniable layer of surprise.

He says he has discovered new information that was unavailable to him before the election.

LEAD: Q. I own a year-round home in the mountains that has a 3-foot-high crawl space.
The floor of the crawl space is bare earth.
There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates.
One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air.

ALL ABOUT/DISK DRIVES
LEAD: Naming this area Silicon Valley, some say, was a mistake.
It should be called Ferrite Valley, after the magnetic materials used in disk drives even before the emergence of silicon-based semiconductors.
Dozens of disk-drive start-ups blossomed, much like the semiconductor companies, in the area of San Jose.


Barbara Stanwyck, Actress, Is Dead in California at 82
LEAD: Barbara Stanwyck, the luminous protagonist of such classic movies as ''Stella Dallas,'' ''The Lady Eve'' and ''Double Indemnity'' and the award-winning western television series ''The Big Valley'' in the 1960's, died of congestive heart failure yesterday in a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif.
She was 82 years old.

Casual Route
LEAD: To the Editor: I was very pleased to see Martha White's article (''Taking the Casual Route,'' Travel, Nov. 19), which described some of the lesser-known pleasures of traveling.
Over the summer my sister and I decided to take a car trip before returning to our respective colleges.
We arranged to take five days off from work, got the car tuned up and took off early on a Sunday morning before our parents knew what we were up to.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
FAMILY.
By Susan Hill. (Viking, $18.95.) At the center of this absorbing story of an English mother's struggle to have a second child is a baby named Imogen.
Born prematurely at 25 weeks in Oxford, Imogen lived for five weeks.
She was tiny: she weighed one and a half pounds, and her entire hand was only as large as the top joint of her mother's thumb.

Chicago
LEAD: To the Editor: The readout to the headline ''On the Lam in Old Chicago'' used the word gunsels for gunmen.
Some years ago I read that the first use of gunsel was attributed to Max Brand, a successful writer of Western stories and books.
After he used gunsel for gunslinger, hordes of pulp writers who had probably never been west of the Hudson, not to speak of the Mississippi, copied this seemingly authentic bit of the real West.

Reviews/Music;   A Clarinetist With Some Good Moves

Cold, in the Winter Years
LEAD: The golden years.
Senior citizenship.
These aren't necessarily euphemisms for age and infirmity.
Many Americans age gracefully, in good health, with sound finances and close to children and grandchildren.
A half-century of advances in medicine and Social Security has made retirement something to look forward to.


Those Awful Shuttle Fares
LEAD: On Wednesday morning, Jan. 3, weekday Shuttle passengers on the Washington-New York and New York-Boston routes received a nasty New Year's present from the glitzy self-promoter Donald J. Trump.
His Trump Shuttle raised its one-way weekday fares by an unprecedented 20 percent, to $119 from $99, thereby exacerbating the already excessive unrestricted air fare gouge that presently afflicts most of the nation's business (and many other) travelers.

He was 83 years old.

SOME KEEPSAKES
LEAD: They are ideas whose time has come.
Notions that once seemed far-fetched or just fanciful, they've found a lasting place in the fashion lexicon.

Wardrobe staples of earlier decades, they've emerged in new contexts as classics for the 1990's.

FLASHBACKS
LEAD: In their never-ending quest for inspiration, designers often rifle through the past.
Anything is fair game.
Done well, this delving into the archives results in new clothes with familiar, even classic connotations.
While these designs may be redolent of nostalgia, they are modern in line.
This season, for instance, the French house of Hermes dipped into its horsy heritage to come up with racy 1990's styles.

Currency;   Drawing Strength From the Fed
LEAD: It turned out to be an up week for the American dollar.
While it was buffeted by news of the jump in the November trade deficit, the dollar was pushed higher by the growing belief that the Federal Reserve, concerned about inflation, would not be lowering interest rates any time soon.
Firm interest rates tend to support the dollar.

There seem to be more spokespersons for our tourism industry than I care to count.

LEAD: THERE'S A SELFISH SIDE TO THE project, as even Gerry Holzman would admit. ''It's an opportunity to do just about anything that a woodcarver can do,'' he says.

LEAD: Rather than discussing what the next bet should be, Barkley and Jackson should concentrate on the game and ways to help their teams win.
A coach with any respect for his team would have benched and/or suspended the player for several weeks, unless, the word team really does have an ''I'' in it.

GOOD AND EVIL ON CANVAS
LEAD: Imagine receiving national acclaim as a painter at the tender age of 22, only to slip into the shadows of a fickle, mostly uncaring art world for the rest of one's long and prolific career.
Such has been the discouraging story for Jack Levine, one of the foremost Social Realists of his generation, a satirist whose gritty urban iconography and brassy style have often led to comparisons with Goya and Daumier.

World Beat Has Become An Industry
LEAD: Most movements in popular music arise without any clear understanding by participants or observers as to what is going on.
At some point, after audiences and styles establish themselves, spontaneity begins to give way to calculation, and self-consciously created modes vie for domination.
For example, by the time ''Saturday Night Fever'' played in movie theaters, disco was poised to catch on as a prepackaged way of life.

Review/Music;   Premiere Of Ashley's 'Brother'
LEAD: Whatever Robert Ashley does, it's extreme.
His compositions have always tested audience endurance, from the amplified shouting over roaring electronic distortion of his early ''Wolfman'' (1964), to the protracted television operas of the 1980's, with his own mumbling monologues, rockish percussion and vocal interjections and cocktail-jazzish piano filigrees.

QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Is Betting On the Super Bowl Excessive?
LEAD: The Times welcomes letters from readers.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I own a year-round home in the mountains that has a 3-foot-high crawl space.
The floor of the crawl space is bare earth.
There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates.
One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air.

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: Some money just goes up in smoke.
In Chinese communities around the world joss money does just that.
It's burned in honor of the dead so the deceased can make ends meet in the afterlife and at 50 cents for a hundred notes, joss money is a bargain.

Still Punching
LEAD: In a sport where 30 is old and 40 is ancient, George Foreman beat the odds -and Gerry Cooney - last week.
Foreman (above, delivering a punch), the oldest and heaviest of heavyweights, was so impressive as he knocked Cooney out in the second round that sportswriters, who had joked that the 253-pound Foreman would be ordering food between rounds, turned to speculating that the 41-year-old former champion might make a fit opponent for the current titleholder, 22-year-old Mike Tyson.

LEAD: Anybody want to buy a house?
Or a seat?
With share prices weakening last week as interest rates rose and housing starts hit a six-year low, the most depressing news at the New York Stock Exchange may have been the year's first sale of a seat in that august body.
The price: $390,000, the lowest tab since 1985.

How Outrage in U.S. Spurred Action in Jesuit Case
LEAD: Behind the arrests of eight military men in the killing of six Jesuit priests and two women in El Salvador lies an extraordinary campaign of pleas to the Bush Administration by church groups and of pressure on the Salvadoran Government by American officials demanding a full investigation.


POSTING: From the McAlpin;   Nautical Tiles, Anyone?
LEAD: A collection of colorful terra cotta wall panels designed by the late muralist Fred Dana Marsh that depict New York City's nautical heritage is looking for a new home.
For over 40 years the 24 panels were the backdrop for the 250-seat Marine Grill at the McAlpin Hotel on Herald Square, which opened in 1912 and between World Wars was one of the city's more fashionable restaurants.

LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government survived a Conservative Party mutiny on Thursday night over a plan to replace real-estate taxes levied by local governments with a ''community charge,'' or head tax, on every adult.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary by The Associated Press on Dec. 31 about Hermann Julius Oberth, a West German rocket scientist, misstated his birthplace.
He was born in Nagyszeben, in Transylvania, an area that is now part of Rumania.

The Plot Thickens for Plotless Dances
LEAD: Drama is dancing its way into choreographic abstractions.
A remarkable number of modern dancers are offering works which, because they are plotless, could be termed abstract; at the same time, they appear to concern changing human relationships.
Productions of this sort are not entirely new, and they are also devised by ballet choreographers.

Getting a Lift To Untracked Powder
LEAD: JUMP out of the helicopter and sink to your knees in snow.
Stay low and move slowly.
But the rat-a-tat-tat of the chopper and the pulse of your heartbeat make you want to sprint away.
The chopper lifts, glides sideways and hovers over space before gliding down the canyon and out of sight and sound.


Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
LEAD: Absolutely not.
As a matter of fact, it made both players' games better.
How many players, coaches, managers and most of all fans, bet on games off the books, and nothing happens to them?
As long as it doesn't get out of hand, and it gets players pumped up, I'm all for it.
RON RICHARDSON
Jersey

LEAD: The engagement of Colleen Ann Cooper and Joseph A. Reardon 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Reardon Jr. of Bloomfield, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
Raymond V. Cooper of Rockaway, N.J.
A fall wedding is planned.

LEAD: THE former owner of Breakaway in Fairfield has gone south, but not far.
East Coast, Marty Levine's new restaurant, is just over the town line, in Westport, in a building that once housed Beeksteak Charlie's.

LEAD: INTEREST has been so strong in a state plan to buy hundreds of condominiums to rent or sell to moderate- and low-income families that officials at the Department of Housing have had to add more sessions this week to explain details of the plan.


STREETSCAPES: The Saint Urban;   A New Roof in an Old - but Not the Old - Material
LEAD: AT the moment it is the brightest thing on the Central Park skyline - 6,000 square feet of Day-Glo orange.
No, it is not a new Christo wrap sculpture or a high-rise HoJo's; it is the protective tarpaulin around the great roof and tower of the 1906 Saint Urban apartment house at the southwest corner of 89th Street and Central Park


Making a Name One's Own
LEAD: THE other day I watched my 6-year-old son Eric slowly, painfully print out his full name at the top of a first-grade assignment.
It seemed like some important rite of passage, this unquestioning writing of our last name as if it naturally was his own.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I own a year-round home in the mountains that has a 3-foot-high crawl space.
The floor of the crawl space is bare earth.
There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates.
One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air.


HIS BUS CAME IN
LEAD: STORIES FROM THE STREETS ARE RICH WITH THE improbable.
Here, for instance, crossing Columbus Avenue and coming into view, is a man with a preposterous past.
When fortune attended, he ran a union; when it was wanting, he cracked safes.
At 35, he declared himself an actor.
Up to that point, he had emoted anonymously - into a microphone announcing bus routes.

Mr.
Derakhshani's ensemble includes players of the tar, santur (a hammered dulcimer), kamancheh (a fiddle) and daff (a drum).

Record Before Ruth
Q. Henry Aaron broke Babe Ruth's career home run record. Whose record did Ruth break?
A.
If you had picked up a major league baseball record book in April 1921, the listing under ''Most Home Runs in a Career by a Player Since 1900'' would have read: ''Gavvy Cravath, 119.

Honda to Make Chips
LEAD: The Honda Motor Company said Friday that it plans to make gallium arsenide semiconductors on an experimental basis at a plant it is building at a cost of two billion yen, or about $13.7 million, at its laboratory in Tochigi Prefecture near Tokyo.
It plans to produce prototypes of the heat-resistant chips by the end of this month and to mass-produce the semiconductors in the early 1990's for use in sensors and other electronic devices.

Review/Pop;   Booker T. and the MG's Recapture the Past
LEAD: Less is still more in the music of Booker T. and the MG's, who reunited last weekend at the Lone Star Roadhouse.
Booker T. Jones on organ, Steve Cropper on guitar and Donald (Duck) Dunn on bass were three-quarters of the Stax Records studio band from 1961 to 1971.
They backed up the top Memphis soul singers - including Eddie Floyd, who joined the group for part of the set - and, as the MG's (Memphis Group), put out classic soul instrumentals.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption in Business Day on Jan. 4 about Sematech, the Government-industry alliance formed to improve ways of making computer chips, referred imprecisely to Semi-Gas Systems Inc.
Despite the juxtaposition with a reference to other companies' troubles, Semi-Gas is profitable and currently has no long-term debt.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Jan. 3 about the Maytag Dairy Farm in Newton, Iowa, misidentified the university that isolated a mold spore used in the manufacture of the farm's blue cheese.
It was Iowa State University at Ames, not the University of Iowa at Iowa City.

LEAD: WHEN you play Denver, the key to your game is what you can do about No. 7.
Because John Elway is such a big-play performer, your best defense is to have your offense control and keep the ball so No. 7 stays on the sideline.
The 49ers are good at that.

Review/Music;   Outings of a Newly Ubiquitous Instrument
LEAD: The accordion, that lowly and often mocked instrument, has spent the last decade getting revenge.
Once the simple butt of jokes, it is now heard everywhere, from highbrow stages at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where accordionists play art music, to albums by quirky rock groups and clubs featuring hard-rocking regional dance bands.

Inflation Up in Britain
LEAD: The inflation rate in Britain rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December and was up 7.7 percent for the year, the Government said Friday.
The Central Statistical Office attributed the December rise in the retail price index to increases in food prices and housing costs.
The rate was better than the 7.8 percent rise that the financial markets had been expecting and was good news for the Government, which has been fighting inflation with 15 percent interest rates.

LEAD: One of the few glories of Beirut to survive 15 years of sectarian violence has been its lively press.

Billings for the new account, formerly at Albert Frank-Guenther Law, are projected at $1 million to $2 million.

LEAD: Kenny Turner, who had not scored since the first half, hit a 10-foot jump shot with 6 seconds to play in overtime today to give Virginia an 81-79 victory over Georgia Tech.

HORSE RACING

Dactique, ridden by Frank Lovato Jr. and carrying 113 pounds, got up in the final few strides to beat Grecian Flight.

THE ECONOMY
The market for Japanese Government bonds is playing a critical role in U.S. interest rates, for the first time since Japan became a financial superpower.
Because of the run-up in Japanese rates, fears are mounting that Japanese investors will lose their appetite for new U.S.
Treasury issues.

LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. continues to lead the worldwide market in work stations with a 28.7 percent share, up from 27 percent in 1988, according to a survey by the market research firm Dataquest.

LEAD: Along the coatrack-clogged sidewalks of Seventh Avenue in Manhattan, the garment industry took out its handkerchief and dabbed its sweaty brow and talked last week about Federated Stores Inc., the renamed American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation.


Portugal Investment Up
LEAD: Foreign investment in Portugal more than doubled last year, to $2.4 billion, the Government said Friday.
In 1988, direct foreign investment totaled more than $920 million.
The Trade and Tourism Minister, Joaquim Ferreira do Amaral, said Britain provided the most investment in Portugal, followed by France, Spain, the United States and Japan.

LEAD: Highland Springs, who won two stakes races and set a course record at Saratoga last summer, scored his first victory since then when he pulled away in the stretch to win the $100,000 Appleton Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

A Poor Way to Save
LEAD: President Bush's misguided urge to cut the tax on capital gains finds a dubious companion in his ''family savings plan.'' Floated during the 1988 campaign and now being readied for submission to Congress, it shares at least two faults with the gains tax: it is weak medicine for America's low savings rate, and it would create new budget problems for the future.

He was 100 years old.

Max Roach Takes 3-Night Look at His Music
LEAD: Often enough, a jazz musician's artistic life traces a predictable pattern: an explosive period of youthful creativity metamorphoses into a period of refinement.
The growing artist's desire for change is replaced by the classicist's concern for rules, a type of formalism that fits right in with the demands of the jazz audience, which usually wants its musical icons to defy time and stay the same.

When Your Ski Boots Become a Pain in the Ankle
LEAD: MIDWAY through the skiing season, many skiers find that the ski boots they once thought were comfortable have become sources of torture.
Ankles are rubbed raw.
Insteps are afflicted by cramps.
Shins are red and tender.
Many people try to solve the problem by stuffing foam rubber into their boots, putting pads under their heels, or pasting moleskin on their feet.

Iran Reports Series of Quakes
LEAD: Eight earthquakes measuring between 4.0 and 5.2 on the Richter scale hit areas of Iran near Firuzkuh, east of Teheran, in the past 24 hours, the Iranian press agency I.R.N.A. said today.
The agency, monitored in Nicosia, did not say if the earthquakes caused any casualties or damage.
It said two tremors registering 3.3 and 3.7 on the Richter scale also shook Birjand, 490 miles southeast of Tehran, today.

LEAD: The official Iranian radio said today that the Soviet Union had sealed its border with Iran in the Azerbaijan region, allowing Soviet Azerbaijanis who had gone to Iran to return but permitting no further travel across the border by Soviet citizens.

Upheaval in the East;   East Germany Discloses Serious Accident at Nuclear Plant in 1976
LEAD: The East German Government said today that a power plant on its Baltic coast had suffered the country's ''most serious and grave'' nuclear accident in 1976, and that a single pump might have prevented the reactor's radioactive core from melting down after a fire.


Naruhiko Higashikuni, 102, Dies; Led a Postwar Japanese Cabinet
LEAD: Naruhiko Higashikuni, a member of the Japanese imperial family who became the country's first Prime Minister after World War II, died Saturday.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Changes at Thompson
LEAD: The J. Walter Thompson Company has overhauled its upper management, creating a North America division to oversee Thompson U.S.A. and Thompson Canada.
The agency named James B. Patterson, formerly chief executive of Thompson U.S.A., chairman of the North America division.
Ronald S. Burns was named chief executive, while remaining chairman of Thompson Canada and director of the Goodyear and Kraft General Foods accounts worldwide.


In Search of lower Insurance Rates
LEAD: Major parts of Gov.
Jim Florio's plan to lower automobile insurance premiums in New Jersey, which now average more than $1,000 a year:
Eliminate the Joint Underwriting Association, the state-created agency intended to insure drivers with bad records.
The association insures more than half the drivers in the state and is $3.1 billion in debt.


The Marlin's Secret
LEAD: The powerful leaping abilities and the fighting movements of the great blue marlin are a result of its flexible structure, and not the spring-like property of its backbone, as scientists once theorized, a zoologist has found.

MCA Taking Loss In Sale of Toy Unit
LEAD: MCA Inc., the diversified entertainment company with interests in motion pictures, records and television, said it planned to sell its LJN Toys Ltd. subsidiary.
Analysts said the toy company, which MCA acquired in 1985 for $66 million, had been losing money for the last three years.
MCA said it will record a $53 million after-tax loss from discontinued operations for 1989 because of the decision to sell the company.

New A.T.&amp;T. Plan On Service Breaks
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that in the event of another serious service disruption to its long-distance network, its operators will tell customers how to place calls on other long-distance carriers.
When A.T.&amp; T.'s long-distance network suffered a computer failure last week that disrupted millions of telephone calls, its operators refused to tell subsribers how to reach competing carriers.

Galleries: Westward Ho to Santa Monica
LEAD: You can still be a pioneer by going west in this sprawling city, and three years ago the art dealer James Corcoran did just that.
He was the first major dealer to move his gallery from West Hollywood to Santa Monica, about 10 miles away, where he says the air is cleaner and the customers are closer.





The Story of Yugoslavia
LEAD:
1918: In the aftermath of World war I, the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes is proclaimed.
In 1929, it takes the name Yugoslavia.
The movements for unification led by Serbia had been a major cause of the war.
In 1914 only Serbia (including present-day Macedonia) and Montenegro were independent; Croatia, Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina were under the Austro-Hungarian monarchy.


49er Offense's Unknown Factor
LEAD: After William (Bubba) Paris left the University of Michigan as an all-America tackle in 1982 and became the first offensive lineman Bill Walsh used a first draft pick to select, the hoopla and optimism over Paris's career crumbled in one play.
In the San Francisco 49ers' last preseason game that year, Paris crushed his right knee so severely against the Seattle Seahawks that doctors said his career was probably finished.

Roman Vishniac, 92, a Biologist And Photographer of Jews, Dies
LEAD: Dr.
Roman Vishniac, a biologist whose brilliant talent for photography captured an extraordinary range of subjects, from Jewish life in Eastern Europe on the eve of the Holocaust to hitherto unseen life under the microscope, died of colon cancer yesterday morning at his apartment in Manhattan.
He was 92 years old.

Once Abortion Foe, State Senator Reverses Stand
LEAD: A Republican State Senator who had been a strong opponent of abortion reversed his position today, providing a further sign of the intense political pressure on abortion foes.
The move also bolstered predictions that abortion restrictions are unlikely to come up for a vote in the Legislature this year.

LEAD: INTEGRATED programs typically combine several applications in one package, including a word processor, a spreadsheet, a data base, a communication module, a program for creating charts, etc., and perhaps some other odds and ends, like a macro generator or a calendar or a grammar checker.

LEAD: The $2 billion Saturn project, which General Motors hopes will prove it can match the best from Japan on its own, will not begin production until June.

Tis Michelle, ridden by Jorge Chavez and carrying 115 pounds, took the lead moving to the far turn and held it the rest of the way.

LEAD: Keith Millard, the Minnesota Viking tackle recently selected as the National Football League's defensive player of the year, was arrested early yesterday in Bloomington, Minn., on charges of drunken driving and speeding.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation spent $1.3 billion on domestic advertising in 1988, the last year for which it disclosed the spending.

Philip Guarascio, executive director for advertising and strategic merchandising, discussed the company's plans.

LEAD: United States intelligence has picked up indications that Colombian drug traffickers may be planning to attack President Bush when he visits the city of Cartagena next month for a four-nation meeting on narcotics, Administration officials said tonight.


Bridge
LEAD: The idea of ''instant match points'' was a brilliant conception, and is gaining in popularity.
Immediately a deal is played, the players are made aware of their match-point scores, predetermined by the organizers on the basis of a past tournament and unrelated to the other tables in the same location.

Strategic Arms Talks Resume
LEAD: United States-Soviet talks on long-range nuclear weapons resumed today, and negotiators expressed confidence that they could meet the Malta summit goal of completing a treaty this year.
An agreement was signed allowing trial inspections of each side's nuclear warheads, with the goal of finding ways to insure that the number of warheads on each missile does not exceed the agreed limit.

Nuclear Winter Theorists Pull Back
LEAD: SINCE 1983, scientists have been bitterly divided over whether a nuclear war is likely to result in a catastrophic global chilling.
But the five scientists who introduced the term ''nuclear winter'' now acknowledge that they overestimated its severity, and their concession appears to have moderated the longstanding debate.

MARKETS

Bofors to Cut Jobs
LEAD: Bofors A.B., Sweden's largest weapons producer, will cut its work force by 500 because of falling orders from the Swedish military.
The decision, which is to take effect July 1, follows a reduction last October of 1,300 workers.
Bofors had counted on continued orders from India, but they were suspended amid allegations that Bofors paid bribes to secure a $1.3 billion artillery sale in 1986.

LEAD: Buoyed by strong gains in sales volume, Merck &amp; Company, the world's largest drug maker, said yesterday that net income rose 20 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 and 24 percent for the year.

Medication Misclassified On List With Steroids
LEAD: To the Editor:


A van Gogh Now at Met Is to be Auctioned
LEAD: Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr.
Gachet,'' completed six weeks before the artist's suicide in July 1890, is soon to be removed from the Metropolitan Museum of Art so that it can be auctioned on May 15 at Christie's in New York.
The auction house expects it to bring $40 million to $50 million.

Review/Television;   'Hallmark' vs. 'American Playhouse'
LEAD: Two of television's more prestigious purveyors of plays, the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' and ''American Playhouse,'' compete for the upscale audience tonight at 9, as Hallmark's ''Face to Face,'' on CBS, goes head to head with ''Sensibility and Sense,'' on PBS.


Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   COMMUNISTS DELAY A SHIFT IN PRAGUE
LEAD: Angry at the way their party has been steadily yielding power since the popular uprising last November, Communist members of the Czechoslovak Parliament balked briefly today at an agreement to give up their legislative majority.
Later, they approved the law requiring them to surrender 90 to 100 of the seats they have held.

SCENE: Sung Tieng restaurant in Greenwich Village.

LEAD: Anyone who doubts the ingenuity of Congress might consider the wrinkles it has built into new rules on the franking privilege, the right to send free mail.


Syria Agrees to Aid Lebanon in Ousting General
LEAD: Syria has agreed to give the Lebanese Government military aid to enable it put down a revolt by the Christian general who controls a chunk of central Lebanon, officials here said today.
