LEAD: The case of the Virginia McMartin Preschool began six years ago with lurid news reports of children being raped and sodomized, of dead rabbits, mutilated corpses and a horse killing, and of blood drinking, satanic rituals and the sacrifice of a live baby in a church.


Police in Egypt Fire on Protest by Militants
LEAD: Egyptian policemen opened fire to disperse Muslim fundamentalist demonstrators on Monday night, killing one person and arresting 12, security officials said.


Eating Well
LEAD: ANOTHER magic bullet has plowed into the dirt.
A study published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week said that oat bran may not lower cholesterol after all.
But then again it may.
Americans have just been treated to a behind-the-scenes look at what goes on in the world of science every day.


Owens Award Finalists
LEAD: Said Aouita of Morocco, Roger Kingdom of the United States and Javier Sotomayor of Cuba are the finalists for the 1990 Jesse Owens International Trophy Award.
The winner will be honored Feb. 6 at a dinner at the Waldorf Astoria.
The award is given to the athlete who best personifies excellence in athletic performance and promotes understanding among people of all nations.


Algeria Acts on Debt
LEAD: Algeria has taken a step toward lightening its crippling $24 billion foreign debt by ordering state companies to restrict short-term borrowing.
The central bank governor, Hadj Nasser, said in an interview that the move was part of a strategy to spread Algerian debt over a longer period, easing the immediate strain on the economy.

Woman in the News;   Putting a Rational Face on a Government in Turmoil
LEAD: ''Process'' was the watchword in Marion Barry's administration back in 1979.
The administration was new and full of promise, and Carol Thompson had just been hired in the city's housing department.
Process.
It meant: Figure out how to make a decision, get all the information, check all the bases, and know all the pitfalls.

LEAD: From Palermo to Turin, and on more than a dozen campuses in between, Italian universities are being rocked by student protests that had all but disappeared in the passive, self-absorbed 1980's.


Self-Defense Claim in Subway Death
LEAD: Saying he acted in self-defense to protect himself and his 3-year-old son, a 39-year-old Manhattan man pleaded not guilty yesterday to first-degree manslaughter charges in the death of a homeless man who had spat at him and punched him on a subway station platform.


Cautious Course Is Charted in Kashmir
LEAD: The new Governor of Jammu and Kashmir state, sent specially from New Delhi to deal with anti-Indian agitation by Kashmiri militants, said tonight that he will not allow Kashmir to slip away from India.


Electronic Teacher: A Mississippi Experiment
LEAD: Mississippi, where one of every three adults is functionally illiterate, is embarking on an ambitious experiment in electronic education: put an I.B.M. computer program in every kindergarten and first grade, and try to have every child reading and writing by the end of the first grade.


East German Weekly
LEAD: An East German publishing house said on Monday that next month it will start putting out Die Wirtschaft, a weekly business newspaper whose title means ''The Economy.'' Its predecessor of the same name was shut in 1983.
At the time, the Communist Government said a shortage of paper had forced the closing.


For Salvador, Democracy Before Peace
LEAD: The November military offensive by the Farabundo Marti Liberation Front guerrillas in my country has created a tragic paradox.
While it demonstrated that there is no military solution to the costly civil war, it has hardened the armed forces' opposition to serious negotiations and to the democratic forces that support this alternative.


Most Employers Coveting Frequent-Flier Bonus Miles
LEAD: Corporations are increasingly wrestling with their employees to claim frequent-flier bonuses from airlines as travel costs soar and the economy slows.


Johnny Mac, Darryl and Chemistry
LEAD: John McEnroe says that if he had known the rules, he would have controlled his temper, not have thrown his racquet, not have tried to intimidate a lines official, not have screamed at the chair umpire, not have issued a string of vile language at the head supervisor (the supervisor's quote), not have thrown his opponent off his game with his abusive deportment and nearly drilled him in the back with an angry whack of a ball, not have shouted to a mother in the stands to feed her squalling infant.

LEAD: When a forum on the environment ended in Moscow Friday, it was after sundown.
So RABBI ARTHUR SCHNEIER, the senior rabbi of Park East Synagogue in Manhattan, promptly conducted a sabbath service.
In a hallway in the Kremlin.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
N.B.A.
76ers Win Fifth Game in a Row
Charles Barkley had 32 points and 15 rebounds last night as the visiting Philadelphia 76ers won their fifth game in a row, beating Cleveland, 103-88, to deny Coach Lenny Wilkens of the Cavaliers his 700th National Basketball Association victory.
Barkley, who reached double figures in scoring and rebounding for the seventh time in eight games, had 14 points in the third quarter, including 7 during a 7-2 flurry that put the 76ers ahead by 72-55 midway through the period.

LEAD: AS a cadre of dignitaries looked on, ground was broken on Monday for a new 28-story office tower in Fort Lee, N.J.

Ulster Policeman Slain
LEAD: Gunmen killed a police officer as he was making a cup of coffee in his kitchen Monday night, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said today.
Inspector Derek Monteith, 35 years old, was hit in the head and died instantly at his home in Armagh, the police said.
No group claimed responsibility.
The gunmen fired at least five shots from the back yard of the house through a glass door, the police said.

LEAD: Share prices fell on the Tokyo Stock Exchange this morning as the United States dollar recovered slightly from its lows.

Francis H. Philp, 59, Investment Executive
LEAD: Francis Higginson Philp, a senior vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company International, died of a heart attack on Thursday at Presbyterian Hospital.

Strike Vote Taken At Ford in Britain
LEAD: Workers of the Ford Motor Company in Britain voted today on whether to accept an improved pay offer from the automaker or go on strike.
The results are not expected to be released until Thursday.
The 32,000 workers at Ford's 22 plants in Britain voted on a proposed pay increase of 10.2 percent in the first year, and 8 percent or a choice of the inflation rate plus 2.5 percent in the second year.


How to Pay for Social Security
LEAD: I thought I understood what Senator Moynihan had in mind with his proposal to cut the Social Security payroll tax.
He wants to stop using a tax that bears hardest on the poor to reduce the Federal deficit.
That sure sounds nice.
But if we reduce the payroll tax, won't benefits be threatened for people who retire in the future?

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Newark yesterday ordered Eddie Antar, the founding owner of the Crazy Eddie electronics stores, to repatriate more than $50 million that the Securities and Exchange Commission said Mr.
Antar had transferred to Israel.


Wine Talk
LEAD: In 1989, for the third year in a row, Americans drank less wine than the year before.
But as they have been doing regularly for more than a decade, they continued to drink more good wine: sales of premium wines, while they constitute only a tiny segment of the wine business, were up.

Corrections
LEAD: The Advertising column of Business Day on Jan. 17 about a new account for the Lowe Marschalk agency misstated the relationship between the Interpublic Group of Companies and the Lowe Group, the owner of Lowe Marschalk.
Interpublic owns 35.4 percent of the Lowe Group, not 29 percent.


Review/Jazz;   Half of Max Roach's Double Quartet
LEAD: The Uptown String Quartet embodies a wonderful idea - a string quartet that can not only handle European classical style but that can also swing and improvise, and that plays music steeped in black American traditions.
But in its enjoyable New York debut on Monday night at the 92d Street Y, the quartet - Diane Monroe and Lesa Terry on violins, Maxine Roach on viola and Eileen Folson on cello - ran up against its technical limitations.


Dining In the Capital: It's a New Deal
LEAD: An avid diner in this city once told a story about going to an Italian restaurant in the mid-1970's that was favored by Congressmen and legislative aides for its pasta with clam sauce.
It was a rough-edged place, with Formica tables, a dimly lighted bar and a disheveled chef.
On the menu was pasta with both red and white clam sauces.

LEAD: HOLLYWOOD has Daily Variety to report on the business and politics of entertainment.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 3 about the effect of Pentagon cutbacks on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut referred incorrectly to the status of Fort Dix, near Wrightstown, N.J.

LEAD: During a dim theatrical season, an actor in ''Forbidden Broadway'' announced a parody of the current hit shows - followed by a prolonged silence.

Bairnco Adopts A Reorganization
LEAD: Bairnco Inc., a holding company based in New York, said its board had adopted a strategy under which it would concentrate on developing its Arlon, Shielding Systems and Kasco units.
The company said it would spin off its Keene Corporation subsidiary to shareholders on the basis of one Keene share for each Bairnco share held.

In the Garden District
LEAD: IN the past 10 years, design books have been narrowing their focus, from countries to regions to cities.
In S. Frederick Starr's ''Southern Comfort: The Garden District of New Orleans, 1800 to 1900'' (M.I.T. Press, $35), the focus is even more specific: the historic area two miles up river from the French Quarter.


Flu Time: When the Sunspots Are Jumping?
LEAD: Sir Fred Hoyle, a British astrophysicist whose unorthodox theories frequently raise the hackles of scientific colleagues, has concluded that sunspots may cause flu outbreaks.

Subway Garble
LEAD: To the Editor:


Hewlett-Packard Retirement Plan
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would offer an enhanced early retirement program to about 2,400 longtime employees in the United States in a program to reduce its work force and slow the growth of expenses.


Profits Off At Chevron And Exxon
LEAD: Two giant oil companies, the Chevron Corporation and the Exxon Corporation, reported today that they had reduced their profits by a total of more than $1.7 billion in the fourth quarter, in large part to deal with their environmental problems.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Appointments At TV Guide
LEAD: Michael A. Lipton, a senior editor of TV Guide, will become executive editor of the magazine's national features section, Joe Robinowitz, the top editor at the magazine, announced this week.
Jack Curry, the deputy managing of USA Today, will become managing editor of the magazine, which is owned by Murdoch Magazines.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Fairness Complaints
LEAD: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus promises that by April 1 it will cut in half the time to decide claims of unfair advertising.
The advertising industry's self-regulatory group averages five to six months to resolve claims, said Mary-Jane Raphael, senior vice president of the National Advertising Division.


Santa Fe Pacific To Cut 2,700 Jobs
LEAD: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said it planned to reduce employment on its railroad by 2,700 jobs over five years.
The reductions would take place through job buyouts, attrition and possible layoffs, and would affect union and white-collar workers, said Robert Gerht, a spokesman for Chicago-based company.


British Ford Strike Averted
LEAD: Workers at the Ford Motor Company Ltd. voted by nearly 3 to 2 to accept a 10.2 percent pay increase, averting a nationwide strike, union leaders said today.

Farm Credit Issue Top Yield Is 8.2%
LEAD: A $3.145 billion financing by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation was priced at par yesterday.
The financing includes consolidated systemwide bonds with maturities of three months, six months and one year.


Chinese Paper Places Ideology Over Ability
LEAD: A revolutionary outlook, rather than education or competence, is the most important criterion in choosing and promoting Communist Party officials, the party declared today in what some experts saw as a reversal of its previous position.


Quake-Repair Bond Issue
LEAD: Officials will ask voters to approve the largest bond issue in San Francisco history, $334.4 million, for repairing buildings and pipelines damaged by the Oct. 17 earthquake.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 11 about van Gogh's ''Irises'' misattributed the news that the painting is on the market.

Risk of Hearing Loss Is Growing, Panel Says
LEAD: Millions of Americans are unwittingly suffering a hearing loss because of exposure to loud noises at home, on the job and during recreational activity, a Federal advisory panel said today.

LEAD: Harrods, regarded by many as London's finest store, will open its first North American outlet in Toronto International Airport's new terminal, set to open in September, the company said.
Harrods, which has in the past sold itself on being only one store, now has outlets at the Frankfurt airport in West Germany, on board the liners Queen Elizabeth 2 and Queen Mary and in the Mitsukoshi Ltd.

Azerbaijani Strife Expected to Lift Oil Prices Throughout the World
LEAD: Western experts say the ethnic strife in Azerbaijan has begun to disrupt production of oil in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer by far and a large exporter.
The resulting drop, which comes on top of a decline that began in mid-1987, is expected to contribute to tighter supplies and higher prices for oil around the world at a time when production is also falling in other regions.


Bristol-Myers Posts a Loss
LEAD: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company yesterday reported a net loss of $352.7 million for the fourth quarter of 1989.
The loss reflected the company's previously announced $855 million write-down to cover the costs of the Oct. 4 merger of the Bristol-Myers Company and the Squibb Corporation.

LEAD: A former Brooklyn man who severely disfigured his 6-year-old son seven years ago when he tried to burn the boy to death as a result of a custody dispute, was freed on parole today with $200 in his pocket and an ''electronic leash'' strapped to his body.

LEAD: As a star of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Judith Jamison commanded attention with her authoritative stage presence, dramatic intensity and concern for expressive details.

East Side Pickpocket Victim Is Held After Shooting Thief
LEAD: A Manhattan man whose pocket had been picked at an Upper East Side electronics store chased the suspected thief and shot him twice, the police said.
Both men were arrested.
Michael Friedman, 55 years old, of 320 West End Avenue, was in Concord Sound, at 228 East 86th Street, when he realized his wallet had been stolen.


Dr. Lucien Rubinstein Dies at 65; Expert on Nervous System Tumors
LEAD: Dr.
Lucien J. Rubinstein, a neuropathologist who was director of the division of neuropathology at the University of Virginia Health Sciences Center since 1981, died Monday after a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in Charlottesville, Va.
He was 65 years old.

The Talk of the South Fork;   Baymen Find No Warmth This Winter
LEAD: The bushel of steamers that Tom Lester harvested last week is still in his cellar, and it is starting to stink. ''I can't sell them,'' said Mr.
Lester, a burly 48-year-old baymen whose day's work normally fetches between $75 and $100. ''No one wants them at any price.''

Poll Finds U.S. Expects Peace Dividend
LEAD: Three out of four Americans say the warming of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union can open the way for cuts in military spending, and by a wide margin they want this ''peace dividend'' spent to fight problems here at home rather than to cut taxes or close the budget deficit.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Business Digest
LEAD:
The Economy


Review/Dance;   Don Cossacks Return For First Time Since 1976
LEAD: The Don Cossacks surged into the Neil Simon Theater on Tuesday night for a two-week run with music and dance guaranteed to charm the most jaded of audiences.
The performing lies somewhere between the simplicity and straightforwardness of the Red Army Chorus and the sophisticated professionalism of the Moiseyev Dance Company.


All the G.O.P. Needs Now Is a Candidate
LEAD: From his remodeled office, J. Patrick Barrett presides over New York State's Republican Party with the nervous readiness of a cook preparing dinner for company who may not show up.


Dollar Off in Hectic Trading; Gold Has a Substantial Gain
LEAD: The dollar finished lower yesterday against most major currencies.
It had dropped sharply and then bounced back as traders responded to the volatile stock market.


Lindsay in Stable Condition
LEAD: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, who was hospitalized after he had a dizzy spell at lunch Tuesday, was in stable condition yesterday, Linda Franklin, an administrator at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, said.
She said doctors were awaiting results of tests to determine whether he had experienced a mild heart attack.


U.S. Softens Its Stance on Return Of the Boat People in Hong Kong
LEAD: The United States has softened its opposition to the forced repatriation of Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong by indicating at an international meeting here that some boat people could be sent back after a one-year moratorium.
But the American insistence on the moratorium effectively prevented any consensus from being achieved at the meeting.

LEAD:
INTERNATIONAL
A3-14
Bills protecting Chinese students in the United States from deportation were overwhelmingly reaffirmed by the House.
The Senate is expected to vote on Thursday and the outcome is too close to predict.

Study of Teen-Agers Hints Gain for Those Having Abortions
LEAD: A federally financed study of unmarried, sexually active teen-age girls has found that those who obtained abortions did better economically and educationally and had fewer subsequent pregnancies than those who chose to bear children.
Those who had abortions even fared better than those who were not pregnant at the start of the research project.

LEAD: The civil war in the Sudan has flared anew in the last six weeks, and Western aid officials say the fighting and Government obstruction of relief efforts make another large-scale famine appear likely.

Wider Search Is Seen In Mail-Bombing Case
LEAD: A Federal investigation into mail bombings that killed a judge and a civil rights lawyer appeared today to be widening, with one law-enforcement official saying new agents had been assigned to this small town that has become the center of the case.


Results Plus
LEAD:
Lakers Make Riley an All-Star
Magic Johnson scored 26 of his 32 points in the second half last night, and Pat Riley clinched his eighth All-Star coaching berth with his 500th victory, a 120-111 triumph over the Indiana Pacers.
Riley became the 14th coach in National Basketball Association history to win 500 games, and he did it in 684 games, faster than any other coach.

Dr. Hugh E. Potts, 87, Biologist and Teacher
LEAD: Dr.
Hugh Eustis Potts, a biologist and an educator, died of heart disease on Jan. 16 at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital.
He was 87 years old and lived in Washington, Conn.


Reprieve From Execution
LEAD: A woman who was sentenced to death for the poisoning of her husband 19 years ago was granted a reprieve by the State Supreme Court today, less than 20 hours before she was to die in the electric chair.
The 46-year-old prisoner, Judi Buenoano, would be the second woman to be executed in the United States since the Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty 13 years ago.

Corrections
LEAD: A headline yesterday about a trial of two former employees of the Cincinnati Bell Telephone Company misstated the verdict.
As the article said, the former employees were found liable for having defamed the company and two managers by contending they had been ordered to perform illegal wiretaps.
There was no finding of guilt.

Splendid Season at Missouri
LEAD: When Norm Stewart returned to coaching basketball at Missouri this fall after seven months of recuperation from surgery for colon cancer, there was hope that the old coach would have mellowed as a result of his ordeal.
That hope was short-lived.
A few days into practice, the players realized that their coach may have lost 30 pounds, but was as cantankerous as ever.


A.T.&amp; T. Cutback
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said its New River Valley electronics plant, with 1,000 employees, would phase out its operations within 15 months.
Jay Walters, the plant's manufacturing director, said the shutdown resulted from excess capacity throughout A.T.&amp; T.'s microelectronics business.

250 Jobs to Be Cut By Perkin-Elmer
LEAD: Citing sagging sales, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation said it would cut 250 jobs within two weeks, most in its semiconductor business.
Edward Bloch, a company spokesman, said most of the layoffs would be at the company's optical lithography unit in Wilton.
He said skilled and unskilled jobs would be cut.


Bush Ready to Ask $1 Billion in Funds To Repair Panama
LEAD: President Bush is preparing to propose an aid program for Panama totaling more than $1 billion to help the country recover from recent warfare and long years of corrupt military rule, an Administration official said tonight.


Graf Plays Sluggishly But Moves Into Final
LEAD: Steffi Graf, suddenly looking vulnerable, escaped an upset today to reach the Australian Open final.
Mary Joe Fernandez, the calm and confident American teen-ager, also reached the final, which is scheduled for Saturday.

LEAD: Ulf Dahlen climbed into Tomas Sandstrom's car late Sunday afternoon for what would be a quiet ride to the Ranger practice arena in Rye, N.Y.

They were no longer teammates, though their hearts wished otherwise.

LEAD: Yves Saint Laurent followed his last model, 16-year-old Lucie de la Falaise, down the runway at the Inter-Continental Hotel shortly after noon today and the place exploded.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: A COMMON style of lavatory faucet is the double-handled type with valves for hot and cold water and a central spout.
Perhaps because of their simplicity, inexpensive, inferior models abound, and it is often necessary to replace them.
The job is usually easy, though awkward.


CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: SOMEONE has written to ask if I would speak at a local gathering, and suggests several possible subjects.
One of them is what my neighborhood, which is also the writer's and probably that of everyone at this gathering, means to me.
I'm not sure what it means to me.
All I know is that when I cross West 14th Street, I am crossing the border into another country.

LEAD: Jan Stephenson, the professional golfer, suffered two fractures in her left ring finger when she was attacked and robbed Tuesday night in Miami, The Phoenix Gazette reported.

No-Fault Faults for New Jersey
LEAD: New Jersey Governor Florio's auto insurance reform proposals, unveiled Monday, look more like cost-shifting than cost-cutting.
He says they'll reduce the average driver's premium by 22 percent, from $1,112 a year to $860.
But what the Governor calls the ''organized ripoff'' of New Jersey drivers won't end until the state perfects its no-fault system and mounts an attack on fraud in insurance claims and repairs.

Oil Find in Eastern Syria
LEAD: Petrofina, the Belgian oil company, said this week that an exploration well in which it has a share had struck oil in eastern Syria.
The Al Bishri test site is operated by Total Syria, of which France's Compagnie Francaise des Petroles has a 60 percent share.
Petrofina has 20 percent and London and Scottish Marine Oil has the rest.

Review/Cabaret;   Anecdotes Amid the Singing
LEAD: Arthur Siegel is one of perhaps a handful of people who know that a particular Jerome Kern melody was set with two lyrics, one by Otto Harbach in 1931 and the other by Dorothy Fields 20 years later.
The Harbach version, ''Don't Ask Me Not to Sing,'' is an amusing comic number dropped from the show ''The Cat and the Fiddle,'' while the Fields version, ''Opening Night,'' which presents a sardonically funny list of things that can go wrong at a show's Broadway opening, was written for the movie ''Lovely to Look


S.I. Man, 44 Stabbed Dead On His Beach
LEAD: A Vietnam War veteran suffering from emotional problems was hunted down and stabbed to death on a remote beach on Staten Island Monday night by two men because they thought he was a homosexual, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Washington's annual war of numbers commenced officially today, with the Congressional Budget Office telling lawmakers they will have to find $74 billion in spending cuts or new tax revenue to reduce the 1991 deficit to the level required by law.

Claire McGlinchee, Professor, 91
LEAD: Claire McGlinchee, emeritus professor of English at Hunter College, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 91 years old.
Dr.
McGlinchee, a graduate of Radcliffe College and a Shakespearean scholar, came to the college as an assistant instructor of English in 1924 and retired in 1969.

Battle Lines Are Shifting on Women in War
LEAD: Many of the women on this Army post in central Texas were baffled and a bit annoyed to see Capt.
Linda L. Bray lionized on television screens during the invasion of Panama.
When Captain Bray led a military police unit into combat while conducting her mission, they insist, she was just doing her job.


Baker Hughes Profit Up
LEAD: Baker Hughes Inc., an oil tool maker, posted a 45.9 percent gain in quarterly profits, despite a worldwide decrease in drilling activity, the company announced today.
Earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31, the company's first quarter, were $25.4 million, or 20 cents a share, on revenue of $578.9 million, compared with earnings of $17.4 million, or 13 cents a share, on revenue of $566.3 million a year earlier.

LEAD: An article on Friday about the seizure of Communist Party assets in Rumania included two incorrect figures provided by an interpreter for the new Government at a news conference.

LEAD: As one lunar year fades into another, the emblem of the holiday seems to be fish - live, frozen, bagged or wrapped in an old newspaper - and city dwellers carry packs of them on the fronts and backs of their bicycles, already weighed down by other bounty of the Chinese New Year.

LEAD: Try as it might, the CBS News team behind ''48 Hours'' cannot turn its coverage of Paul McCartney's current tour into an update of ''A Hard Day's Night.'' The 90-minute program, to be broadcast tonight at 8 on CBS, searches out some of the same ingredients as Richard Lester's 1964 film: eager fans, backstage drollery, limousines, applause.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Paint on the Carpet
Q.
I spilled latex flat paint on my acrylic carpet and cannot remove the stains.
I tried soap and water as recommended on the can, but it didn't work.
Can you help?
A.
Depending on how old the dried paint is, you may be able to soften it with a solution of hot water and detergent.


PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: A FEW months ago Eileen Seeley broke up with the man she had been dating.
Her 6-year-old daughter, Brianna, who had become quite attached to the man and his two young children, was very upset.

LEAD: Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalaby, pledged in remarks published Tuesday that Iraq was committed to its OPEC supply quota of 3.14 million barrels a day despite the expansion of its oil-shipping capacity.
He told The Baghdad Observer that Iraq's export capacity was about 5 million barrels a day.

Citicorp Floating Securities Are Backed by Credit Cards
LEAD: Citicorp yesterday priced the first-ever issue of floating-rate securities backed by credit card receivables.
The bank holding company, the largest issuer in the $20 billion, three-year-old market for credit-card-backed securities, is offering $700 million of the new floating issue through the Money Market Credit Card Trust 1989-1.


A New Bullock's
LEAD: R. H. Macy &amp; Company said it would open a 240,000-square-foot Bullock's department store in the Regional Shopping Center complex in Burbank, Calif.
The new Bullock's, the first in Burbank, will open in the fall of 1992.
Macy's said that the new store was part of a commitment to expand the Bullock's chain in Southern California and that it was among seven new stores Macy's plans to open in the next four years.


Cooney on New Track
LEAD: Gerry Cooney, who retired from boxing after being knocked out by George Foreman 11 days ago, has applied for a license to own race horses in New York State.

LEAD: At least 24 people have died, 32 are missing and thousands are homeless from flooding this week in Tunisia, the official press agency reported today.

NBC Marketing
LEAD: NBC-TV said yesterday that it was consolidating its varied marketing activities.
The effort will be headed by John Miller, who was promoted to executive vice president for marketing.
Mr.
Miller will retain responsibility for the advertising and promotion for the network's entertainment, news and sports divisions.

FLUORIDE HELD CLUE TO CANCER IN RATS
LEAD: Researchers have found preliminary evidence that fluoride causes cancer in male rats, Federal officials said today.
But they cautioned that the study did not suggest that the fluoride in water and toothpaste would cause cancer.

An epidemic of influenza, predominantly the strain A-Shanghai, has been identified in 35 states and is the most widespread outbreak since the winter of 1984-85.

Alabama Tornado Injures 24
LEAD: A tornado swept through a trailer park here early today, injuring 24 people.
Among them was a boy who witnesses said was freed by a man who managed to lift the corner of the mobile home that had pinned the child down.
No deaths were reported from the tornado, which hit about 5:30 A.M., when most people were sleeping in this community 40 miles south of Montgomery.

Accord in Sweatshop Inquiries
LEAD: The New York State Labor Department and the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration agreed yesterday to swap information on violations found in sweatshops.
When raiding illegal factories, the Labor Department frequently finds life-threatening conditions involving violations of building or fire codes.

LEAD: All along the quiet, rundown streets of Charleston, S.I., Michael Taylor and Phillip Sarlo have a reputation for being troublemakers, heavy beer drinkers who start fistfights.
One of their favorite targets of ridicule, neighbors say, was James Zappalorti, a 44-year-old emotionally disturbed man.
They harassed him, the residents say, because they believed he was gay.

Tickets are $5.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 490 money market mutual funds increased by $1.64 billion, to $383.07 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 149 institutional funds decreased by $294.2 million, to $92.41 billion.
The assets of the 243 general-purpose funds were up by $1.16 billion, to $128.08 billion.

Walter John Lee, Publisher, 83
LEAD: Walter John Lee, the owner and publisher of The Westfield (N.J.) Leader for 62 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Westfield after a long illness.
He was 83 years old.
Mr.
Lee took over The Westfield Leader, a weekly newspaper, from his father in 1928, shortly after graduating from Lehigh University.

Billings for the hosiery account were not disclosed.


TV Weekend;   'Image,' a Drama on Ethics Of Investigative Reporting
LEAD: For its first hour, ''The Image'' zips along as though it were on fast foward.
The dialogue is snappy, the pace frenetic and the performances by Albert Finney as a star television reporter and John Mahoney as his producer and pal leave them little time to draw breath.
New York is much in evidence, not only in the glimpses of Lincoln Center and Central Park West, of subway stations and stretch limos, but in the high-pressure drive of the television studio and those who run it and are run by it.

LEAD: South Africa is closer to rejoining the Olympics than at any other time since its expulsion 20 years ago, Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, said at a news conference yesterday while visiting the Commonwealth Games in New Zealand.
But he also said the Pretoria Government had a long way to go toward eliminating apartheid before the committee could consider letting the country back into the games.

Coke-Disney Pact
LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company and the Walt Disney Company signed a 15-year marketing agreement, extending an association that dates to 1942.

Coca-Cola will also have exclusive rights to use certain Disney characters in advertising.

Now the San Diego Chargers, under their new general manager, Bobby Beathard, are getting their house in order, and have dropped Joe Madden as special-teams coach.

Japan Still No. 1 in Cars
LEAD: Japan remained the world's largest auto maker in 1989, the country's leading automobile trade group said today.
Analysts predicted it would maintain the lead in 1990.
Japan's output in 1989 was 13.03 million vehicles, up 2.6 percent from 1988.
Output surpassed the 10.85 million vehicles produced in the United States in 1989, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said.

Review/Concert;   June Anderson, With Sinopoli, Tries a New Field
LEAD: It is always heartening when a musician with an established reputation in one area dares to sail out into uncharted seas.
June Anderson, who has made a major career as a specialist in bel canto opera, took such a voyage on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall when she appeared as the soprano soloist in Berlioz's ''Nuits d'Ete.


Georgia-Pacific Gains 21.7%
LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net ionome rose 21.7 percent, reflecting strong building-product sales and a share repurchase program.


40,000 Years of Treasures From a California Tar Pit
LEAD: About 40,000 years ago, oil oozing from the earth's bowels congealed into a cluster of tar lakes along what is now Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles.
Since then, the monster trap this created has been catching and preserving everything from mites to mammoths, and some of the tar's most interesting victims go on view at the American Museum of Natural History in

2 School Districts Told To Fix Bilingual Flaws
LEAD: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez ordered two Brooklyn school districts yesterday to submit plans to correct problems in their bilingual education programs by Feb. 2.
Failure to do so, he warned, would lead to his taking over the programs.

U.S. Health Agency Declares Flu Epidemic
LEAD: The Centers for Disease Control declared yesterday that a nationwide influenza epidemic exists and that it is the most widespread outbreak of the disease since 1984-85.


Falmer Journal;   When No Detail Is Too Trivial, Write It All Down
LEAD: The personal observations and quiet reflections of ordinary people leading ordinary lives are coming together here as a vivid collage of life.


The Last Domino
LEAD: The democratic tide in Eastern Europe finally laps against the sealed borders of Albania.
This hermetic Balkan enclave has for decades scorned every liberalizing current in the Communist world.
But now its Stalinist rulers are busy denying reports of a ruthless police crackdown against dissenters in northern cities.


Wet Field Irks Coach
LEAD: For the second straight day, the Denver Broncos slipped all over the Tulane University practice field today.
The distraction angered Coach Dan Reeves as he continued to prepare his team for the game Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers in Super Bowl XXIV.


First Victory in the Drug War
LEAD: Just as President Bush was announcing his updated national drug control strategy yesterday, Democratic Senator Joseph Biden was distributing a drug control plan devised by the Senate Judiciary Committee.
This was no quick rebuttal but a 236-page book based on a year of study and 24 hearings.


Israeli Warplanes Hit Guerrillas Near Sidon
LEAD: Israeli fighter jets destroyed a southern Lebanon base of a radical Palestinian guerrilla group today, in the second such air strike in a week, the police said.

LEAD: A headline about Poland yesterday referred incorrectly in some editions to the people occupying Communist Party buildings.
They were protesters, not members of Parliament.

LEAD: The Government said today that it planned to submit documents Friday in Federal District Court here to prove that Gen.

Intel Can't Meet Demand for Chips
LEAD: The Intel Corporation said it was not able to meet the demand for its popular 386 and 386SX microprocessors.
But the company said it expects to fulfill all orders by midyear.


Wide Abuse of Medical Students Found
LEAD: Abuse and mistreatment of medical students are widespread and often leave long-lasting emotional scars that may affect their care of patients as physicians, new studies being published today show.


Stock Split At Teledyne
LEAD: Teledyne Inc. said today that its directors had approved a 5-for-1 split of its common stock and a plan to spin off its insurance and finance units.

The Man Who Would Be Elway
LEAD: rrA sportswriter whispered to another yesterday morning that John Elway was not feeling so hot.
In fact, the source said from behind the back of his hand that the Denver star quarterback had lost 10 pounds in the last few days with some kind of mysterious virus, perhaps, or maybe it was something he ate.


Conner Growth Claim
LEAD: Conner Peripherals Inc., a manufacturer of hard disk drives for computer data storage, laid claim this week to being the fastest-growing manufacturing start-up company in American history.
The San Jose, Calif., company reported revenues of $704.9 million in 1989, its third full year of operations.

LEAD: Five weeks ago, a late package caused panic to sweep through Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan.
Yesterday, a late letter inspired celebration.

History, Justice and Heroism In the Films of John Ford
LEAD: IN John Ford's final film, a doctor in a cowboy hat rides a horse into town, battles a cholera epidemic and dies to save innocent people from a horde of marauding bandits - a scenario almost too typical to mention, except that the doctor is Anne Bancroft.
The female hero of ''Seven Women'' is as unusual for Ford as the film itself, a now-laughable 1965 melodrama about a gaggle of American missionaries in China in 1935.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of a production error, a caption in The Home Section yesterday, with a picture of two cartoon characters sold at auction, was erroneous in some copies.
The picture was a rare black and white celluloid from ''Orphan's Benefit,'' by Walt Disney.


Rep. Luken of Ohio to Retire
LEAD: Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio, who has served in Congress since 1976, announced Wednesday that he would retire when his term ends Jan. 1.
Mr.
Luken, 64 years old, a lawyer who is a former Cincinnati Mayor, said, ''I expect that this is my swan song in elective office.''

LEAD: R. Mark Palmer, the United States Ambassador here, is resigning from the State Department to manage a new consortium of North American financiers that today announced the purchase of half interest in a Hungarian bank, the first in what was projected as a series of ambitious investments in Eastern Europe.


Rachel Fitler, Socialite, 93
LEAD: Rachel Fitler, heiress to a rope-manufacturing fortune, died Wednesday at her home in Villanova, Pa.
She was 93 years old.

LEAD: At least 39 people were reported killed today as storm winds of 100 miles an hour, with even higher gusts and driving rains, swept Britain and surrounding seas.

Inquiry Finds Taxiway Takeoff
LEAD: Federal investigators said yesterday that evidence had confirmed that an Eastern Airlines jet took off from a taxiway, rather than from the runway parallel to it, on a flight from Philadelphia last week.
The pilots of the jet have consistently denied doing so.


Kenyan Leader to Visit U.S.
LEAD: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya will begin a three-day private visit to the United States on Monday, diplomatic sources said today.
Kenya is one of Washington's closest allies in Africa and the United States Navy has access to the base at the Kenyan port of Mombasa.
Mr.
Moi last visited the United States in March 1987.


Home Resales Off 4.6% in '89
LEAD: Sales of existing homes edged down in December, bringing the 1989 total to 3.43 million units, or 4.6 percent less than the previous year's sales, a real estate trade group said today.

Dance Bands Whose French Isn't Gallic
LEAD: Spanish, the saying goes, is the loving tongue, but French, increasingly, is the language the world dances to.
It's not the French of Maurice Chevalier or Edith Piaf; it's Creole-ized French from places where colonizers and emigrants ran into the African diaspora - in the Caribbean, in Africa and on the Louisiana bayou.


PRESIDENT UNVEILS NEW DRUG EFFORTS
LEAD: Declaring that the fight against drug abuse is the big test of his Administration, President Bush today unveiled a new narcotics program that immediately drew criticism for its continued emphasis on law enforcement and stopping drug shipments.

Sun Microsystems Stock Up Sharply
LEAD: The stock of Sun Microsystems Inc. rose 13.7 percent yesterday after the maker of computer work stations reported second-quarter earnings that were better than most analysts had expected.
Although the Mountain View, Calif., company reported earnings late Wednesday that were 31 percent below those of the 1989 quarter, there were increases in sales and orders.


Review/Film;   Toil And Trouble In Emerging Africa
LEAD: Francis Girod's 1978 film ''L'Etat Sauvage'' (''The Wild State''), based on Georges Conchon's 1964 Prix Goncourt novel, is a seriously half-baked movie that oversimplifies problems of genuine political and social interest.
The film opens today at the Public Theater.


Worst Loss Of Season For Knicks
LEAD: Maybe the Knicks will find happiness Saturday night in Denver against the Nuggets, the next stop in what shows signs of being a trip to nowhere.


LOBBYING EFFECTIVE
LEAD: The Senate voted by a narrow margin today to sustain the President's veto of a bill protecting Chinese students in the United States from deportation.
The outcome spared Mr.
Bush an embarrassing political defeat and left him relatively free to continue pursuing his own policy toward China.


Cummins Sues Large Holder
LEAD: The Cummins Engine Company filed a lawsuit yesterday against Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., contending that it had violated disclosure laws and the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act while acquiring 14.9 percent of the engine maker.


What of Ford's Is Showing When
LEAD: ''The Unknown John Ford,'' a five-week film series curated by Tag Gallagher and organized by Richard Koszarski, begins today and runs through March 2 at the American Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue and 36th Street, in Astoria, Queens (718-784-0077).
Screenings are included in museum admission: $5 ($4 for the elderly, $2.50 for students and children).


Large Secluded Houses And One Busy Road
LEAD: The neighborhood in Cove Neck, L.I., where the Avianca jetliner crashed is one of secluded estates, large homes on sizable wooded lots -and only one road.
Last night, that road was jammed with emergency vehicles and with onlookers hoping for a glimpse of the doomed plane.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the baseball labor negotiations referred incorrectly to a method of making revenue-sharing acceptable to the players.
The method was not offered by the owners, but was posed in a question to both sides by the reporter.


S.E.C. Halts Bolar's Stock
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading today in the stock of the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company for the next 10 days.
The move was in response to reports that the New York-based generic drug manufacturer had provided false test data to Government health officials about one of its products.


Try Again With Solo Police Cars
LEAD: The idea of using one-officer patrol cars has come and gone in New York City, and now it's back.
The new Police Commissioner, Lee Brown, is considering the idea, and a civic group, the Citizens Budget Commission, is energetically lobbying for it.
The police union objects, arguing that solo patrol isn't safe.


Good People Are Not Hard To Place
LEAD: ''DO you have a tie on today?'' asked Judy Wald. ''I'm used to talking to all these creatives who never wear ties, and I have to remind them that Laurent, the restaurant, requires a tie.''


Huntsman Move On Aristech Bid
LEAD: The Huntsman Holdings Corporation said the Aristech Chemical Corporation had agreed to provide it with confidential financial information on the company.
Aristech has rejected an offer of $25 a share, or $842 million, from Huntsman, the largest private chemical concern in the United States.
Huntsman, in turn, said it would raise its bid.


Diner's Journal
LEAD:
Middle Eastern Exotica


Chronicle
LEAD: After distributing a couple of million dollars in scholarships for minority students, OPRAH WINFREY has gone one step further.
She bought all the tickets for the first Broadway performance of AUGUST WILSON'S new play, ''The Piano Lesson.'' Then she gave them to A Better Chance, an organization in Boston that arranges for minority students to attend leading private schools.


F.D.A. and Heart Group Clash Over Labeling
LEAD: The Food and Drug Administration has announced opposition to a program of the American Heart Association in which foods deemed safe will be labeled, but the organization says it will go ahead anyway.


GE Aerospace To Cut 5,600 Jobs
LEAD: The General Electric Company's aerospace division said it would eliminate 5,600 jobs in the Eastern United States by 1991, citing tighter Pentagon budgets and mounting competition.
The cuts amount to nearly 14 percent of the work force at GE Aerospace, the nation's third-largest military contractor.


Dollar Declines Against Yen On Reports of Heavy Selling
LEAD: The dollar closed mostly lower yesterday as rumors heightened trader fears about foreign investment in the United States.
Gold prices were mixed.

New Partner Joins Stride Rite Bid
LEAD: Walsh, Greenwood &amp; Company and FS Champ Associates said Roger Holland had agreed to join them in their effort to acquire the Stride Rite Corporation.
The group has offered $32 a share for Stride Rite, a bid that values the shoe company at about $850 million.
Stride Rite's board is to review the offer next Monday.

Treasury Prices Move Downward
LEAD: A news service report about comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent shudders through the credit markets yesterday and pushed down prices of Treasury notes and bonds.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Advance Circuits Inc., Minnetonka, Minn., a manufacturer of printed circuit boards, named its president, Robert W. Heller, to the additional post of chief executive.
He replaces Thomas F. Leahy, who will remain chairman.

Eastern Sees More Losses Through First Half of Year
LEAD: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it expected to lose about $155 million in the first half of the year but would come closer to breaking even in the second half.
The prediction was made in a reorganization plan presented to the airline's unsecured creditors.

Our Towns;   Pitched Battle: Six Apartments For the Homeless
LEAD: It was five days before Christmas, and Marge Rogatz was delighted.
After 18 months of frustration and delay, she had just signed the closing papers on a six-unit apartment building that would be the very first permanent housing for the homeless in the whole of Nassau County.
It was also the first acquired by a private agency, Community Advocates


Bush in Panama: A Tragicomedy
LEAD: Vice President Quayle's projected Latin American trip to explain that we gringos are good guys after all is a farcical and fitting sequel to the Panama invasion.
Even more so, since it has been scaled down to a brief visit to our dependencies Honduras and Panama (with Jamaica thrown in).
Now Mr.
Quayle's audience is likely to laugh only behind his back, instead of in his face, when he relays President Bush's message to ''all of the countries of Latin America'' that we're still their ''friendly, supportive and respectful neighbor.


The Roll-Call On China
LEAD: Following is the 62-to-37 roll-call vote by which the Senate refused today to override President Bush's veto of a bill protecting Chinese students in the United States.
Although a majority voted to override, the vote was four short of the two-thirds necessary.
A yes vote was to override.
Voting yes were 54 Democrats and 8 Republicans.


MT.A. Proposes to $15 Billion Plan to Improve and Add Service
LEAD: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that up to $15 billion would be needed, starting in 1992, to continue improving service and to pay for the first major expansions of the region's subway and commuter rail systems since the early 1970's.

Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current.
Auntie Yuan


Chronicle
LEAD: Former Mayor JOHN V. LINDSAY of New York was released yesterday from New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where he had been taken Tuesday after he felt dizzy at lunch at the Century Club.
He had simply suffered a transient drop in blood pressure, said Diana Goldin, a hospital spokeswoman.


Upheaval in the East;   A Former K.G.B. Chief Champions Azerbaijanis
LEAD: When Geidar A. Aliyev passed through the Moscow office of the Azerbaijani republic this afternoon, a turbulent crowd fell silent and men were startled from their seats, nodding and muttering ''salaam aleikhem'' to the tall, trim figure in navy blue pinstripes.


UAL Net Plunges by 67%
LEAD: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, today reported a 67 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit.

No Quick Fixes For Drug Addicts
LEAD: Yesterday President Bush announced his 1990 National Drug Control Strategy, including $1.5 billion for support of drug treatment services.
The President's plan does not, however, endorse what has come to be known as treatment ''on demand.'' Here's why.


End Is Seen to Siege Decree in Haiti
LEAD: Haiti's military ruler indicated today that on Friday he would lift the state of siege that he imposed five days ago.


N.F.L.'s Drug-Testing Program Called Inconsistent and Unfair
LEAD: The pregame hype that usually fills the air at the Super Bowl was overshadowed today by a swirl of rumors and accusations involving the National Football League's drug testing of players.


Hooker Corp. Asks Aid on Real Estate
LEAD: A Federal Bankruptcy Court has given the L. J. Hooker Corporation permission to hire a real estate concern to help it sell five properties in four states.
The holdings are the Forest Fair Mall near Cincinnati; Richland Fashion Mall near Columbia, S.C.; Thornton Town Center Mall near Denver; the Gateway Mall site in Atlanta, and the almost-completed Ten Peachtree Office Center in


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:
THE ECONOMY
The Bush Administration has refined its new savings plan and other programs that it hopes will address the lagging rate of savings and investment.
The centerpiece is an account that it hopes will increase Americans' savings by granting tax-free interest on money left on deposit for at least seven years.


Nets Give Orlando A Rare Road Victory
LEAD: The Nets begin a six-game trip on Saturday, and this may be a good time for them to leave town.
If they continue playing the way they did tonight, they will have even less fan support at home than they do now.


McDonald's Net Up 13%
LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation today reported record fourth-quarter earnings of $171.1 million, or 46 cents a share.
That is an increase of 13 percent from $151.5 million, or 40 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter.
For the year, McDonald's, based in Oak Brook, Ill., earned $726.7 million, or $1.95 a share, up from $645.9 million, or $1.71 a share, in 1988.


On Stage
LEAD:
Musical About Mahalia Jackson


Chronicle
LEAD: Prime Ministers don't often have babies, so Pakistanis were understandably elated yesterday when BENAZIR BHUTTO gave birth to a girl.
Her personal bodyguard passed out candy after the baby was born, by Caesarean section, at Lady Dufferin Women's Hospital in Karachi.


Anna Hedgeman Is Dead at 90; Aide to Mayor Wagner in 1950's
LEAD: Anna Arnold Hedgeman, an educator, civil rights advocate and the first black woman to be a member of a mayoral cabinet in New York City, died Jan. 17 in Harlem Hospital.
She was 90 years old and had lived in Harlem for many years.


The U.N. Today
LEAD:
General Assembly
COMMITTEE ON THE ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.


Bonds in Illinois For Water Agency
LEAD: The Central Lake County Joint Water Agency of Lake County, Ill., is offering $50 million in tax-exempt water-revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company.
The bond issue offers a maximum yield of 7.35 percent for securities due in 2019 and 2020.
For other long maturities, the yield is 7.25 percent for an issue due in 2010.


Bush to Propose Savings Plan Providing Tax-Free Interest
LEAD: The Bush Administration has added the final details to a new savings plan and other programs that it hopes will address what many economists have identified as the nation's No. 1 economic problem, the lagging United States savings and investment rate.

MANDELA APPEAL CALLS ON PRETORIA FOR NEGOTIATIONS
LEAD: In his first major public pronouncement since he was imprisoned for life more than a quarter of a century ago, Nelson Mandela has appealed to South Africa's white rulers to move urgently toward negotiations for majority rule so as to save the country from ''civil strife and ruin.''

Corrections
LEAD: An article and a summary chart on Tuesday about automobile insurance in New Jersey misstated the percentage of drivers insured by the Joint Underwriting Association, a state agency established to cover high-risk drivers.
At its peak, the association insured half of the state's drivers; it now insures 40 percent.

Plane Crashes on L.I. With 149 Aboard;   At Least 9 Killed on a Boeing 707 From Colombia
LEAD: A Colombian jetliner carrying at least 149 people crashed in heavy fog last night in Cove Neck, L.I., while approaching Kennedy International Airport for a landing, the authorities said.


Sonic Guard Charged
LEAD: Dale Ellis, the guard who leads the SuperSonics in scoring, was charged in Seattle yesterday with drunken and reckless driving during a car accident on Jan. 12 in which Ellis suffered three broken ribs and a punctured lung.


Threat of Oil Shortage by '93 Seen
LEAD: The deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company predicted today that oil supply shortages could occur as early as 1993 or 1994 because of OPEC's inability to expand production.
A possible increase in demand for oil from Eastern Europe could add to the strain on supplies, he added.


British Ford Plant Remains on Strike
LEAD: One of the Ford Motor Company's main British plants remained closed today by an unofficial strike, even though the company's manual workers have accepted a pay increase.
About 550 maintenance craftsmen are on strike at the Halewood factory in northern England.
In response, Ford has laid off 8,000 manual workers there.


Traditions in Spanish Film: An 82-Year Retrospective
LEAD: The names of Luis Bunuel, Carlos Saura and Pedro Almodovar are familiar to many American filmgoers.
But there is a richer tradition of Spanish film making than even those names suggest, a tradition with provocative ties to the political and social ideologies that have long played an important part in Spanish life and thought.


Restaurants
LEAD: Dining in a busy hotel lobby on lime-green chairs under hot pinpoint lights and decorative sconces that look like truncated steers' horns might not be everybody's idea of elegance.
But when the food is as absorbing as that turned out by Jeffrey Zakarian, the chef at 44 in the Royalton Hotel, one's architectural sensibilities mellow quickly.


Valentino's Spring Breezes, Givenchy's Bouquets
LEAD: The main thrust of the spring and summer couture openings, which ended this morning, was on pretty clothes, not wild ones.
There was little to alarm or perplex.
Even the ultrashort hems that looked devastating on the runway will be somewhat modified when they are worn by real people in the real world, for these are, after all, made-to-measure clothes.

Carbon, Percussively


Review/Art;   Tina Barney and Scenes Of Her Life, at the Modern
LEAD: Looking at the photographic tableaux of Tina Barney at the Museum of Modern Art, there is a temptation to say: ''This is upper-middle-class American life.'' The roomy houses are surburban or rural.
The people are for the most part healthy, sensitive and decent, and they have grown up with the feeling that outdoor barbecues, big-screen televisions and pink bathrooms are as much God-given rights as air is.


Witness Backs Prego View of How She Got AIDS
LEAD: An AIDS researcher testified yesterday that he thought Dr.
Veronica Prego had contracted the disease as a result of puncturing her finger on a contaminated syringe needle in 1983.

Ewing Will Start In All-Star Game
LEAD: Patrick Ewing will be making his fourth trip in five seasons to the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, but this year the Knicks' center will be going as a starter for the first time.
The game will be played Feb. 11 in Miami.


Shaw's Self-Important Doctors and Their Totally Dubious Cures
LEAD: Although Shaw called ''The Doctor's Dilemma'' a tragedy, it is of course intended as a comedy, a fact that is not amply in evidence in Larry Carpenter's cumbersome revival of the play at the Roundabout Theater Company.


Upheaval in the East: Turkey;   Turks at Rally Assail Soviet Moves
LEAD: In the snow-clad lee of Mount Ararat, where legend lays Noah's ark to rest, thousands of Azeri Turks gathered here today for a demonstration of support for ethnic kinfolk in Soviet Azerbaijan.


The Lady in Red
LEAD: In the arrest of Mayor Marion Barry of Washington, the Department of Justice argues that a good end justifies bad means.
Wrong.


Large Gap Separates Owners and Players
LEAD: Two weeks before the day the owners will decide whether or not to begin spring training as scheduled, negotiators for the owners and the players are no closer to reaching an agreement on a new labor contract than when they began talking two months ago.


Elizabeth-Ann Knapp, A Former Architect, 76
LEAD: Elizabeth-Ann Campbell Knapp, a former architect and chairman of the Campbell Family Foundation, died of cancer on Sunday at her home in Princeton, N.J.
She was 76 years old.


Kiley Puzzles Over Meaning In Subway-Platform Slaying
LEAD: The head of New York City's transit system said yesterday that he understood how a subway rider might have felt a ''fatherly instinct'' to protect himself and his 3-year-old son when he responded with what prosecutors called deadly force to an attack by a homeless man.


Review/Film;   Britten's 'War Requiem,' To Images by Derek Jarman
LEAD: Taking Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem,'' composed for the opening of the new Coventry Cathedral in 1962, Derek Jarman has made a movie of epic irrelevance that, when it rises to the occasion, is merely redundant.
It opens today at the Quad.


Family Split Over French Publisher
LEAD: The latest episode in the bitter struggle for control of one of France's most prestigious publishing houses, Editions Gallimard, became public today as a Gallimard family member disputed the value of the privately owned empire.

LEAD: Following are excerpts from a statement drawn up by Nelson Mandela before his meeting last year with P. W. Botha, then President of South Africa, and delivered to Mr.
Botha before the meeting.
The full text was printed today by a Cape Town newspaper.

Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Kremlin Turns Conciliatory Toward Azerbaijani Group
LEAD: The Gorbachev Government took a more conciliatory tone today toward the Azerbaijani Popular Front, saying it undoubtedly included ''healthy forces'' with whom occupation authorities might negotiate.


Kill the Spotlight; The Party's Over
LEAD: When the Trumbull Little League All-Stars won the Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pa., last August, the young victors and their families expected a small hometown parade, a couple of plaques, a few local newspaper interviews and not much else, save for a lifetime's worth of memories.


43.46 Decline Leaves Dow At 2,561.04
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks plunged 43.46 points, to 2,561.04, yesterday, as upward pressure on interest rates and the flow of poor corporate profits kept many investors on the sidelines.


$500 Million Issue By Two Utilities
LEAD: The AEP Generating Company and the Indiana Michigan Power Company yesterday issued an equal amount of secured lease obligation bonds totaling $500 million through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.
Both utilities are units of the American Electric Power Company.


Illinois Awaits Inquiry
LEAD: The University of Illinois basketball program is bracing for a full National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into its recruiting practices. ''We believe the N.C.A.A. has sufficient information to warrant an official inquiry,'' the Illinois athletic director, John Mackovic, said Wednesday in Champaign.

Bush Names 2d Nominee to Rights Post
LEAD: President Bush announced today that he would nominate John R. Dunne, a New York lawyer and former State Senator, for the politically sensitive Justice Department post of Assistant Attorney General for civil rights.


Not Too Late for Flu Shots
LEAD: Experts on influenza say it is not too late to obtain immunization against the disease in the face of a nationwide epidemic declared yesterday by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.


Students Find U.S. Embassy a Barrier
LEAD: In his news conference on Wednesday, President Bush pleaded with Congress not to ease the visa rules for Chinese students now in the United States.
One of his arguments was that the action might lead China to cut back on future programs of study abroad, which he characterized as an important force for change in China.


Getting Mad, Getting Even
LEAD: In heading off what looked three days ago like a sure defeat on the China issue, President Bush proved today that a popular leader, if sufficiently aroused, can still change votes on Capitol Hill, even in this day of lax party discipline and constantly shifting coalitions.

G.N.P. Rate Up by 0.5% In Quarter
LEAD: The nation's economy grew at a rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the final three months of 1989, the Commerce Department estimated today.
It was the weakest economic performance since the spring of 1986.

Mortgage Rates Rise
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages surged back over 10 percent this week and are currently averaging 10.05 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
That rate was up from 9.90 percent last week.
On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.41 percent this week, up from 8.39 percent the week before.

Upheaval in the East;   Report on Ceausescus' Burial
LEAD: The bodies of the deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were taken to Bucharest and buried in secret after their execution on Dec. 25, Deputy Prime Minister Gelu Voican said in an inteview broadcast on French television today.
Other members of the ruling National Salvation Front had said they did not want to bury the couple in Rumania and were considering dumping the bodies in the Black Sea.

LEAD: A black cat in a diamond choker adds a touch of glamour to the opening credits of ''Strike It Rich,'' but this proves mostly to be wishful thinking.
And the specter of Cary Grant, summoned by both the Monte Carlo of 1956 (where most of this story is set) and the heroine who is named for him, has a similar effect.

LEAD: The introductory part of a President's budget message is usually a dryly written document.

Burmese Military Bars U.S. Observers for Vote
LEAD: The military Government, which has barred several top opposition leaders from running in the next election in Myanmar, formerly Burma, said today that American observers would not be allowed to monitor the balloting.

Plane's Debris Includes a Tangle of Relationships
LEAD: When the aluminum skin of the Avianca jetliner split open on a foggy Long Island hillside 15 miles short of Kennedy International Airport, it lay bare the complex web of relationships and commerce between Colombia and the United States.


Though Rare, a Jetliner's Running Out of Fuel Can Happen THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 52
LEAD: While it is uncertain what led to the crash of Avianca Flight 52 on Thursday night, one fact is becoming clear: the Boeing 707 burned much more fuel than the pilots had originally planned.

Patents;   Using Sound Waves To Break Stones in Body
LEAD: William S. Filler, a former research physicist with the Navy's Surface Warfare Center, has patented a system using sound waves to break up kidney stones and gallstones without surgery.

Buffton Corp.
LEAD: The Buffton Corporation, a holding company that owns avionic, electronic and plastic pipe manufacturing companies, said it was considering a restructuring to maximize investor value.
The Fort Worth-based company said it had hired Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. to develop a new strategic direction for the eight-year-old concern and to assist in evaluating the sale of certain assets.

LEAD: Vernon C. Myers, a magazine executive who was publisher and president of Look in the 1950's and 1960's, died on Thursday at St.
Joseph Medical Center in Stamford, Conn.
He was 78 years old and lived in Norwalk, Conn.

Cray in Buyback
LEAD: Cray Research Inc.'s board has authorized the repurchase of up to three million of the company's common stock, the supercomputer maker announced.
The Minneapolis company had more than 28.1 million common shares outstanding as of Dec. 31.
Shares in Cray rose 62.5 cents today, to $43.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: As people move toward retirement, they often reinvest their portfolios to provide greater income.

TV Broadcast Grisly Scenes, But Received No Complaints
LEAD: The first television images to come out of Cove Neck, L.I., after the crash of an Avianca Boeing 707 were unedited and graphic, as New York's six commercial stations rushed to get the story to viewers.
The stations broke into their programs just after 10 P.M. on Thursday with information, all of it sketchy and speculative, adding more as it became available.


Children's Fate Points Up Seating Concerns
LEAD: At least six children under the age of 5 survived the crash of Avianca Flight 52 and though it could not be determined yesterday whether any of them were saved by child-restraint seats, their fate points again to concerns about the safety of small children on airplanes.

Government by Default
LEAD: Mayor David Dinkins has surprised critics with some tough calls lately, but now he's in danger of reverting to indecision.
Many New York City agencies are drifting because he hasn't chosen people to run them.
He hasn't named commissioners of housing, sanitation, correction, finance, probation or the sprawling Human Resources Administration.

Patents;   A Device to Foil Radar
LEAD: The race car champion Bobby Unser has patented a new device to foil police radar.
The invention combines a radar detector, police scanner and citizens' band radio into one unit.
A single microprocessor can simultaneously control the scanning for signals from each source, in theory increasing the chances of detecting a police presence in the area.

Pain of AIDS Prompts Gifts To Neediest
LEAD: With The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's drive approaching its third month, homelessness continues to be the predominant issue in letters from donors, but the scourge of AIDS also troubles many contributors.
Some people specify that their donations go to homeless people with AIDS; other suggest that they help children with AIDS, other impose no limits beyond relevance to AIDS.

Pact in South African Strike
LEAD: Striking black rail workers and management have reached a tentative accord in a 12-week walkout that has claimed more than 30 lives and caused millions of dollars in property damage, a mediator said today.
The mediator, Charles Nupen, said the management of the state-owned South African Transport Services agreed to recognize the union representing 25,000 strikers.

LEAD:
N.B.A.
Sixers Pull Near Knicks
Charles Barkley had 37 points and 21 rebounds and Hersey Hawkins scored 28 points as Philadelphia beat the Chicago Bulls, 120-109, last night at the Spectrum for its seventh consecutive victory.
The 76ers moved into second place in the Atlantic Division, one game behind the Knicks.

Sister R. Mildred Barker, Shaker Leader, 92
LEAD: Sister R. Mildred Barker, the spiritual leader of Maine's Shaker community, died on Thursday after a long illness.
She was 92 years old.


A Respected Air Carrier Based in a Troubled Land
LEAD: Since its founding in 1919 by a group of former World War I flying aces from Germany, Avianca, the Colombian national airline, has been the object of international intrigue and a target of political violence.
But it has maintained a respectable safety record throughout, aviation experts said yesterday.


Roadblock for Random Drug Tests
LEAD: New regulations requiring random drug tests for three million truck drivers are stalled in a legal limbo after the Transportation Department ordered the program to begin even though there was skimpy evidence of widespread drug use in the trucking industry.

LEAD: The Bush Administration has notified Idaho lawmakers that it will not provide money in next year's budget to build a plutonium processing plant that was once the centerpiece of the Energy Department's plan to rebuild its deteriorating nuclear weapons industry.

LEAD: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who won the Jesse Owens International Trophy Award in 1988 and tested positive for an anabolic steroid seven months later at the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, has accepted an invitation to a banquet Feb. 6 to honor this year's award winner.

Japanese-Style Health Care for Patients Far From Home
LEAD: Entering the new office at New York Health Care in midtown Manhattan might be confusing - unless the patient speaks Japanese. ''Konichiwa,'' the receptionist says, greeting newcomers.
Then reaching for her ringing phone, she answers, ''Moshi, moshi.''


Bush Budget Sees Growing Revenue And Cut In Deficit
LEAD: President Bush is preparing to send Congress a $1.2 trillion budget that envisions a dramatic decline in the Federal deficit to roughly half its level in the current fiscal year.


Corrections
LEAD: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday about sources for nonfat foods gave an incorrect telephone number for Bacino's of Lincoln Park in Chicago, which sells stuffed pizza.
Its number is (312) 472-7400.

Sydney C. Davis, Professor, 77
LEAD: Dr.
Sydney C. Davis, professor emeritus of education at Adelphi University in Garden City, L.I., died of a heart attack on Wednesday at the Hollis Branch of the Queens Borough Public Library.
He was 77 years old.


Lothar Kahn, Professor, 67
LEAD: Dr.
Lothar Kahn, a retired professor of modern languages at Central Connecticut State University, died of acute leukemia on Tuesday at St.
Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he was vacationing.
He was 67 years old and lived in Kensington, Conn.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: DR.
STEVEN A. SCHROEDER, a professor of medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles, has been chosen as the next president of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.
The foundation, with headquarters in Princeton, N.J., is the largest in the nation dedicated to improving health and health care, awarding $100 million in grants annually.


Chiang Mai Journal;   Verdant Land Where Victoria Stares and Stares
LEAD: Amid the many gracious temples of Chiang Mai, still one of the most charming cities of booming Thailand, there is a bit of consecrated ground presided over not by the Buddha but by an equally plump representation of a more earthly suzerainty, Queen Victoria.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Price Anomalies
LEAD: One of the more reliable shopping maxims is that consumers get more for their money when they buy goods in large packages.
Usually the purchaser receives part of the saving from the reduced costs of factors like packaging, handling and storage.
That is basic economics.


Quisenberry Signs Two-Year Giants Pact
LEAD: Dan Quisenberry, once the best relief pitcher in the majors, joined the San Francisco Giants yesterday with a two-year guaranteed contract.


Madge Bellamy, 90, 1920's Film Actress
LEAD: Madge Bellamy, an actress who starred in silent films in the 1920's, died on Wednesday at San Antonio Community Hospital in Upland, Calif.
She was 90 years old and lived in Ontario, Calif.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''I had time to say a prayer.
I put my attache case over my knees because I didn't have a pillow.
I bent over in the crash position.
In about five seconds, we were crashing into the trees.''
- Jorge Lorano, a Bogota businessman. [1:1.]

A Strategy That Beats Shocking Fuel Bills
LEAD: Millions of homeowners who shivered through the record cold spell of December are shuddering in January at a related problem: December's fuel bill.
It is too late, of course, to do anything about the cost of heating last month, but future bills can be spread out or reduced, experts say.

Treatment for Player
LEAD: Tom Bill, the Penn State quarterback suspended by Coach Joe Paterno last Sept. 19 for violation of team rules after he was cited by the campus police for an alcohol-related incident, has withdrawn from classes and voluntarily admitted himself to an alcohol treatment program, Paterno announced yesterday.


Yes to Mandela's Way
LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk has led his Government to the verge of talks on ending apartheid in South Africa.
But now he balks at the very moment when the climate for negotiations with the black majority has never been better - and when it could easily get far worse.


Dollar Down Against Pound And Yen, but Up Elsewhere
LEAD: The dollar finished mixed yesterday, weakening against the British pound and Japanese yen but rising against many other currencies in heavy trading.


Review/Music;   Three Views of Orpheus
LEAD: Erich Leinsdorf, one of the canniest builders of orchestra programs among currently active symphony conductors, put together a particularly appetizing one for the New York Philharmonic's audience on Thursday evening.
The theme woven through his concert at Avery Fisher Hall was the Orpheus myth, as treated by three composers: Liszt, Stravinsky and Offenbach.

Where Executives Dress Up And Let Their Hair Down
LEAD: On most days they can be found running large corporations, banks and brokerage houses.
But once a year they attend a secretive, all-male dinner party at which new members sometimes dress in drag and perform silly skits.
They have been known to add even more levity by tossing rolls at each other.


Lewis Mumford Dies at 94; A Visionary Social Critic
LEAD: Lewis Mumford, a philosopher, literary critic, historian, city planner, cultural and political commentator, essayist and perspicacious writer on the subject of architecture, died yesterday at his home in Amenia, N.Y.
He was 94 years old.


Jesse C. Reese Jr., 60, Concert Hall Manager
LEAD: Jesse Creighton Reese Jr., a former director of Town Hall, a concert hall in Manhattan, died of heart disease on Jan. 17 at the Tulane Medical Center in New Orleans.
He was 60 years old and had lived in New Orleans since last fall.


Donald A. Stoddard, Banker, 79
LEAD: Donald A. Stoddard, a former senior vice president of the Morgan Guarantee Trust Company in Manhattan, died yesterday at his home in Bloomingdale, N.J., after a short illness.
He was 79 years old and had lived in Nutley until moving to Bloomingdale last year.

The Elephant Wars
LEAD: They burned rhino horns here Thursday, as they had burned elephant tusks last year.
The huge pyre, also piled with leopard, lion and zebra skins seized by anti-poaching squads, was worth $2.5 million.
Thick black smoke rolled up to the idyllic blue sky, splotched with idle cottony clouds.

The Price of Fudging on S &amp; L's
LEAD: The savings and loan troubles became a crisis because Washington dawdled.
Losses at just one thrift, California's big Lincoln Savings and Loan, topped $2 billion because regulators dawdled.
Even after President Bush proposed remedial legislation, hundreds of insolvent S &amp; L's bled needlessly last year while Congress dawdled some more.

New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: Now that it's become chic to not only shop in discount stores but admit it, to carry unprestigious shopping bags, and to own up to such things as eating frozen dinners and preferring inexpensive chocolate, certain other things follow.
For instance, little quirks like eating while watching television, managing very well for a week or more without dusting, and virtually living in the bedroom, all of which have been done for years, are now being talked about openly and even proudly.

Insuring Against A Canceled Trip
LEAD: ''STANDARD trip-cancellation insurance'' is like a standard sized window: there is no such creature.
If you are preparing for a major trip this year, and you are thinking about protecting yourself against losing your deposit money, or more, assume nothing.
Get a copy of the insurance brochure and read it.

LEAD: The ''Executive Computer'' column last Sunday, about multimedia computer techniques, misidentified a company that develops multimedia applications using the Audio Visual Connection made by the International Business Machines Corporation.
The company is Competitive Solutions Inc., of McLean, Va.
