Letters;   CONFIDENT AT 11, CONFUSED AT 16
LEAD: Yes, yes, yes!
Carol Gilligan's theories are valuable recognitions of our growing up.
My own 11th year has remained vivid throughout my life.
I remember telling myself these exact words, ''I'm 11 years old, in the 6th grade, and the world is beautiful.'' I had the confidence that I was a very smart girl, that I would know how to handle any situation and that I would create my own world.


Chastity Organization: Starting Over in Purity
LEAD: With her heart aching from a painful breakup, Mary Meyer placed an advertisement in a singles' column: ''Female wanting to meet a man who would like to marry.
Celibate before marriage only.'' More than 100 men responded.
Most of them thought it was splendid for a woman to be chaste.
But none were thrilled with the notion for themselves.


In Sitcoms, Cupid Is Often Only a Tease
LEAD: After half a decade of denying, deploring, hinting at, acknowledging and sheepishly celebrating their mutual sexual attraction, Tony Micelli and Angela Bower have agreed they don't know their feelings well enough to discuss the future.
Sam Malone, having spent five years getting together and breaking up with Diane Chambers, has been chasing Rebecca Howe for 28 months - to no avail.


FASHION: On the Street;   With Down Out, The Cloth Coat Grows in the Job
LEAD: In the last couple of years, the pouf seems to have gone out of the down coat, the overstuffed garment that wreaked winter havoc with coat-checkers and turned a lot of fashionable people into reasonable facsimiles of the Michelin Man.
Still very much around, however, is the cloth coat, adaptable as ever to the winds of change.


Hands and Hearts Across the Pacific
LEAD: THE grayness of a late January Sunday afternoon settles over our town.
I have just returned from a long walk, needed, somehow, to try to sort things out, to get reoriented to being a family of two again.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: The ''Your Own Account'' column last Sunday, discussing limited partnerships, misidentified the tax form required of investors.
It is a Schedule K-1, Form 1065, not a K-9.

Peter L. Wastrom of Stamford, Conn., and Richard A. Somerby of Hartsdale, N.Y.
A June wedding is planned.


When the Legislators Meet
LEAD: The Board of Legislators, under new leadership in 1990, has decided to forgo afternoon meetings in favor of morning and evening sessions.
To encourage attendance by the public, the Board has published a schedule of meetings (generally every other Monday) for the entire year.


PASTIMES: Coins
LEAD: When the mercantile nations of Europe sent ships around the world in the 15th and 16th centuries, they introduced the notion ofmoney to many people who had relied on barter forthousands of years.
Sometimes the results were strange.
Among some tribes of western Africa, an object shaped like a Celtic torque or bracelet was held in high esteem.

LEAD: The Federal grand jury investigation of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. is widening into a broader examination of official corruption and drug use, but deep-seated suspicions from Mr.
Barry's supporters about the prosecutors' motives continue to haunt the case.


Louella Luhrman Dies; Oldest Veteran, 108
LEAD: Louella Luhrman, an Army nurse in World War I who became the nation's oldest veteran, died Friday.
She was 108 years old.

Veteran Lawmaker Retiring
LEAD: Representative Augustus F. Hawkins, veteran chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee and the longest-serving black in Congress, said Friday that he would retire at the end of the year.
The 82-year-old Democrat has represented the primarily black and Hispanic Watts area of Los Angeles and surrounding Hispanic suburbs since January 1963.


NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Augusta, Me.;   State Shields Open Spaces
LEAD: TWO years after Maine voters approved the expenditure of $35 million to protect land from development, the state finds itself owning more than 6,600 acres, including 16 miles of unspoiled oceanfront, and has begun to turn its attention to inland properties.


YEARNING FOR AN IRON HAND
LEAD: THE REVOLUTION DAY PARADE IN THE western Siberian city of Tyumen has dwindled in recent years from a two-hour spectacle to a perfunctory 45-minute exercise, reflecting the collapse of the Communist faith.
Last Nov. 7 the Tyumen city fathers, desperate to boost their ratings, agreed to permit a small show of dissent.

TALKING: Unsold Units;   Low Prices Tempting Investors
LEAD: A NEW, controversial and high-risk market is evolving in occupied apartments in converted New York City cooperatives, with many of them being offered to investors at deeply discounted prices.
The big price breaks are a direct result of the troubles some conversion sponsors are experiencing in meeting maintenance and debt service charges on the apartments they still own in converted buildings.

UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   Azerbaijanis Offer Talks With Kremlin
LEAD: The leaders of the rebellion in Soviet Azerbaijan proposed peace negotiations with the Kremlin today, provided that the central Government first withdraws the troops who seized control of the capital in street battles a week ago, after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev declared emergency rule.

LEAD: At least five ethnic Albanians were killed in gun battles with the police today, the fifth day of riots in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo, the official press agency Tanyug said.

Additional titles of interest:


A Losing Temper
LEAD: Like a couple of his forehand shots, John McEnroe went over the line during the Australian Open in Melbourne last week.
After repeated displays of his well-known ill temper and foul mouth in a tough match against Mikael Pernfors, McEnroe was booted off the court, becoming the first player in 27 years to be disqualified from a Grand Slam event.


Campus Life: Clark;   Institutional Entrees Served With a Twist
LEAD: Most college students hate institutional food, and Clark University students are no exception.
But the university and its food service contractor, Daka, are putting their money where the students' mouths are.


Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about an Interstate 95 interchange in Mamaroneck misstated the village's population.
It is 17,616.


Currency;   Finally, Some Muscle for the Yen
LEAD: The Japanese yen, which has been chronically weak against the dollar, finally found some muscle last week.
Betting that the Japanese would raise interest rates after the Parliamentary election on Feb. 18, traders bought yen aggressively last week for the first time in months.
By the end of the week, the dollar had fallen to 142.85 yen, down from 146.00.

LEAD: Every 30 years or so, an expansive period of extraordinary dance activity seems to be suddenly on the wane.
Anyone looking for the end of the great dance boom that has marked American dance since the end of the 1960's might also consider the lessons of the past.

Numbers That Lied
LEAD: It now appears that in the far-reaching work that established him as the father of modern astronomy, Johannes Kepler was not above taking short cuts.
In a recent issue of The Journal of the History of Astronomy, William A. Donahue said that when Kepler presented his theory nearly 400 years ago that planets moved in elliptical rather than circular orbits, he falsely claimed that he had confirmed his insight through independent calculations.

LEAD: Someone else always goes to Disney World.


Another Perspective On Fuel Cooperatives
LEAD: I am writing in response to an article, ''Price of Heating Oil Prompts an Outcry'' that appeared Jan. 7 in the Westchester Weekly.
Overall the article was even-handed and among other things offered information on fuel co-operatives as an alternative to local fuel marketers.
Please allow me to offer some insight as to how a typical co-op works.

PASTIMES: Bridge
LEAD: New conventions are commonplace among tournament players, but seldom stand the test of time.
They are much rarer in rubber bridge or four-deal games played in club or private homes where partnerships change constantly and the emphasis is on simple bidding.


When the Weather's Cold, Try Braising
LEAD: BRAISING is a technique that deserves to be in every cook's repertory, especially in cold weather.
It is a slow cooking method, suitable for thick pieces of food.


The Coming Rebound - and Risk - in Municipal Bonds
LEAD: Four years after changes in the tax code knocked the wind out of municipal bonds, the market appears poised for a big turnaround.
For Wall Street, scrambling more than ever for new sources of income, a jump in market volume can't come soon enough.
For investors and issuers, however, the expected surge in activity may be fraught with risks.

It was the kind of fairy-tale event usually reserved for young couples.

BACH LOOKED AHEAD, OR WAS IT BACK?
LEAD: I am prepared to believe, after sifting through all the available scientific evidence, that (1) oat bran lowers cholesterol and that (2) it does not.
Meaning only that when confronted by the conflicting arguments of acknowledged experts, I tend to think both sides may be on to something.
In any event, argument is the essence of truth-seeking, whether medical or musical.

FICTION
LEAD:
GOOD INTENTIONS.
By Joy Fielding. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Joy Fielding's eighth novel introduces us to Lynn Schuster, a social worker, and Renee Bower, her divorce lawyer, as their seemingly perfect marriages are ending in sexual betrayal.
Resentful children, unloving parents, embittered clients and sabotaging male bosses are carefully interspersed throughout the plot to develop well-paced parallels between the two women's experiences.


El Salvador Hits Home
LEAD: IN one of those strange quirks of history, El Salvador has suddenly become one of the hottest political topics in Connecticut.
Newspapers that normally eschew foreign affairs are discussing it and Panama regularly.
Politicians whose eyes otherwise glaze over at anything more global than state patronage can't stop talking about it.

PUBLIC &amp; PRIVATE
LEAD: Art imitates life in the offices of the National Abortion Rights Action League and the National Right to Life Committee.
At Naral, the prints and posters are mainly renderings of women.
In the offices of Right to Life, the pictures are of babies.
The issue of abortion is framed, quite literally, on the walls of their Washington headquarters: which comes first, the woman or the fetus?

A Cuisine of Humble Origins.
LEAD: ''ONLY a Ligurian,'' writes one of Columbus's biographers, ''could have conceived of the idea of sailing West to reach East.'' Incongruous contrast, in fact, is one of the most striking characteristics of Genoa, the capital of Liguria, the birthplace of Columbus and a city of more than one puzzling paradox.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 10 about contacts between Baltic nationalists and the United Nations Secretariat misstated the United Nations' stand on the Soviet annexations of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania.
In response to inquiries from international lawyers, further checks by The Times - delayed through an oversight - have found no evidence that the General Assembly ever explicitly recognized the 1940 annexations.

Paris Pays Belated Respects To a True Bohemian
LEAD: Among the artists most responsible for the development of abstraction during the early decades of this century, probably none has received less credit than Frantisek Kupka.
Consult the standard histories and you are likely to find only a sentence of two about the Bohemian-born painter.
Kandinsky, Mondrian, Malevich, even Robert Delauney, have their own chapters in those histories, but Kupka, whose works at one time or another anticipated, echoed and paralleled the paintings of each of these artists, has, by comparison, been written off.


LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu;   Spicy Pork With an Oriental Flavor
LEAD: Buying pork that is already ground will not give you lean meat.
But if you buy a pork tenderloin, remove the small amount of excess fat and grind the meat in a food processor or an old-fashioned grinder, your final dish will not be swimming in fat.

Capacity Doubling at Drug Treatment Centers
LEAD: OVER the last decade, as drug and alcohol abuse soared on Long Island and across the country, almost no treatment centers were opened on the Island.
In the last few months, however, a spurt of construction will result in a doubling of treatment capacity to 400 beds on the Island.
About 150 more are in the planning stages.

Like the medieval monastery it resembles, this uptown branch of the Metropolitan Museum has many functions: a landmark to the traveler, a magnet to the aficionado of medieval art, an oasis to the seeker of calm.

Today the Broncos will take their Super Bowl XXIV test.

NONFICTION
LEAD:
UNFINISHED CONVERSATIONS: Mayas and Foreigners Between Two Wars.
By Paul Sullivan, (Knopf, $22.95.) In the annals of peasant and Indian uprisings, the Mayan Caste War of 1847 ranks as one of the most prolonged revolts against a postcolonial government.
For more than half a century, the oppressed Maya posed a serious threat to Mexican authority in the Yucatan Peninsula.

LEAD: To the Editor: Please thank Ruth Wolff for her delightful article on navigating a car (''Navigator to Pilot: We're Lost,'' Travel, Nov. 5).

It has brightened my day and will lighten the burden of navigating in the future.

LEAD: What makes Antoine Predock so much of an architect is exactly what makes him not so much of an international celebrity: his insistence on designing buildings that relate to the spirit of the place in which he is working.
Since nearly all Mr.
Predock's projects have been in the Southwest (his office is in Albuquerque, N.M.), his architecture has become a kind of contemporary expression of the traditional architectural language of the desert and the mountains.

Coming to Terms on Health Care
LEAD: Unlike the great industrial wars of America's past, the recent strikes against the Pittston Company and the Nynex Corporation were not over wages or even work conditions, but over health benefits.
Such disputes are becoming commonplace.
Union officials view health insurance as a basic necessity.
As one of the Nynex strikers' picket signs put it, ''Cutting Our Health Benefits Is Sick.

Genoa's Neighborhoods and Palaces
LEAD: ''THE most mysterious city in Italy,'' a British critic said to me, a man who knows Italy better than most Italians.
And, no matter how often I visit Genoa, I find it hard not to agree with him.
And yet the Genoese are hospitable and the city - especially in bright weather - lies deceptively open on its hills along the sea, exposed, inviting.

Another Small Step for Man
LEAD: THE IGOR I. SIKORSKY HUMAN-Powered Helicopter Competition, sponsored by the American Helicopter Society, offers a $20,000 award for the first non-engined rotor craft that hovers for 60 seconds and attains an altitude of 3 meters.
In 10 years, no one has claimed the prize, but last November a team of students at California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo managed, momentarily, to get off the ground - a first.


The Executive Computer;   Bringing Microsoft's 'Windows' to Critical Mass
LEAD: The recent arrival of the Microsoft Corporation's Word for Windows signals more than just a new entrant in the overcrowded word processing category.
Word for Windows (which lists for $495 and is intended for high-end I.B.M. PC and PS/2 compatibles that use the DOS operating system) is the first program that combines advanced ''what you see is what you get'' word processing, desktop publishing features, an easy-to-use graphical command structure and powerful tools for customization.

Review/Dance;   Love, Robots and Nuptials, by Reka
LEAD: Reka Feketekuty is one of the best storytellers working today in New York modern dance.
She has a knack for subtly suggesting atmosphere, usually dark, and her stories are resonant with extra meanings.
But a program presented by Reka and Company Dance Theater on Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center suggested that she may be better at telling stories than at enunciating great themes.

Raccoons Are Gone From the Attic but Not From My Heart
LEAD: THE creaking noises became noticeable in midsummer, late one evening when I was reading a ghost story.
The house is settling, I thought.
The trees are scraping the windows.
A squirrel must be running across the roof.
I shivered.
Within a week, however, I became accustomed to a still-occasional creaking sound in the attic.


Koussevitzky Treasures Through a Sonic Mire
LEAD: Serge Koussevitzky was one of the musical giants of the 20th century.
As a publisher in his native Russia he brought out the early works of Stravinsky.
For his Concerts Kousevitzky in Paris in the early 1920's he commissioned Maurice Ravel to create his orchestration of Modest Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition.


The Process That Ate Washington
LEAD: Arrival of the President's budget on Capitol Hill creates what is charitably known as the Congressional budget process.
In truth it is less a process than a Rube Goldberg nightmare of unrealistic deadlines, overlapping jurisdictions and competing mandates involving every committee in Congress.
The numbers, contradictory and ever changing, will be irrelevant by September, when the decisions that matter are made.

Others maintained that the stunning concert hall took Dallas another step in becoming a cultural center of international importance.

Where Lewis and Clark Wintered
LEAD: AS a hopelessly provincial Easterner I had always thought of Astoria as (a) the last name of a well-known New York hotel, (b) the only name of an area of New York City or (c) the title of a half-forgotten travel book by Washington Irving.
Recently, however, I visited (d) the real thing - a handsome and historic city situated where the mighty Columbia River meets Oregon's thundering Pacific coast.

LEAD: Publicity gimmicks have a long and occasionally worthy tradition in classical-music history, and this one was both elaborate and effective.
In an acknowledged bid for attention for the Carnegie Hall concert of the Illinois Chamber Orchestra on Thursday evening, the group's first New York appearance since a little-heralded Alice Tully Hall event in 1987, its music director, Kenneth Kiesler, devised an unusual project that captured the imagination of several veteran musicians.

LEAD: An article on Jan. 7 about Oakland, Calif., referred incorrectly to the Oakland Symphony and the Paramount Theater's relation to it.

Now the companies that attracted the traffic in the first place are considering getting involved in transportation management themselves, to help solve the problem.

Small Quake Jolts Indiana
LEAD: An earthquake measuring 3.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion jolted southern Indiana and northern Kentucky today, the United States Geological Survey said.
No injuries or damage was reported.
An agency spokeswoman said the epicenter of the quake, which struck about 9:06 A.M., was in Harrison County, Ind., about 30 miles west of Louisville, Ky., and was an aftershock to a temblor that registered 3.8 in the same area on Wednesday.

LEAD: For This Week: If the weather outdoors suits, dormant trees can be pruned especially large shade trees that are overgrown and ornamentals whose lower limbs block drive and path views.
Keep the planting medium of annual and vegetable seed started indoors moist, but do not allow it to become soggy.
If gift plants from the holidays are dropping leaves and yellowing, discard them.

FICTION
LEAD:
THE VOYAGE OF MAEL DUIN'S CURRAGH.
By Patricia Aakhus. (Story Line Press, Paper, $12.95.) While the story elements central to Greek mythology have remained relatively stable, the oral tradition of Irish storytelling has frequently produced legends that have subtly shifted over time.
Such is the case with the tale of Mael Duin, an ancient story of a questing son who sets out in a skin-covered boat called a curragh with a crew of 16 men in order to avenge his father's death.

LEAD: ''Clever'' may be the most feared compliment in rock.
A band can labor for a year over a set of songs, agonizing over every syllable and note and reverberation; it can rack its brains over the cover art and lie awake nights remembering whom to thank in the fine print.
But let anyone suggest that the results are clever, and the party might be over.

Review/Theater;   Bonding With the Land In Cather's 'O Pioneers!'
LEAD: For Willa Cather, ''O Pioneers!'' was the novel in which she spoke for the first time in her own voice, free of influence and literary tradition.
In it, she said, she had hit ''the home pasture,'' and the book was to set her off on her creative journey.
Written in 1913, ''O Pioneers!'' remains one of the enduring works of American literature.


A Story of Love or a Tale of Deceit?
LEAD: ON THE MORNING OF SEPT. 16, 1986, George Gardner picked up Patricia Nicely at a nursing home in Roanoke, Va.
Only a year earlier, Nicely, a wealthy woman of 58, had been a high-level official at the National Science Foundation.
Now, apparently in the grip of Alzheimer's disease, she had grown so incapacitated that a local judge had made Gardner, a 65-year-old lawyer and friend of Nicely's, her legal guardian.

LEAD: Elizabeth Meyers, director of college activities at Barnard before she retired in 1972, died of cancer on Wednesday at Sentara Leigh Memorial Hospital in Norfolk, Va., while visiting a son in Virginia Beach.
She was 83 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

LEAD: It was Shadow's coming out party, her initiation into the Tiny Diablas girls' gang in the Watts district, and she was dressed in the height of gang fashion: narrow corduroy pants, a sweatshirt in the gang color purple, extravagantly teased hair and exaggerated black-red makeup.

Mr.
Frisardi is an Italian in his early 30's, and was educated in his own country and in Austria.


Arabs Warning Against Influx of Soviet Jews
LEAD: In many parts of the Arab and Muslim world, a clamor is building against a projected influx of Soviet Jews into Israel, reflecting fears that the emigres will displace Palestinians from the occupied territories and thwart the faltering diplomacy of peace.


More Sidewalks of New York Are Becoming Streets of Stars
LEAD: Hardly a day passes that one does not come upon another photograph of another Hollywood star at home in New York.
Stars are seen running in their sweat suits through Central Park, dining at restaurants bankrolled by other stars, sweeping into benefits for the South American rain forests, curled up on the couches of their newly decorated duplexes and talking about their projects.

LEAD: On the night of Friday, Sept. 10, 1971, a nervous group of civilian ''observers'' entered D-Yard at the Attica State Correction Facility in upstate New York, where more than a thousand rebelling inmates were holding 35 hostages.


VOTE IS MOVED UP BY EAST GERMANS; COALITION WIDENED
LEAD: Meeting late into the night, the Government and all major political groups in East Germany agreed today to hold the country's first democratic elections on March 18 instead of in May, and to form a coalition government until then.


East German Venture Decree
LEAD: East Germany's coalition Government has approved a decree that allows foreign companies with fewer than 500 employees to have a majority stake in a joint venture with an East German company.

LEAD: The walls didn't come tumbling down as they had seemed to do the previous week, when six of the country's seven top-ranked teams were upset, but there was some significant shaking going on in college basketball over the weekend.


Battery-Operated Ski-Boot Warmers
LEAD: A new warmer for ski boots is designed with its heat source mounted on the outside of each boot.
The heater comes with a recharger, which allows you to plug the boots' battery packs into a wall socket each night.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''There's a fine line between having an angle, having a strategy, and being improperly devious.
Some of those who think there's deviousness here don't like him because it's so hard to second-guess him, to outwit him, to outplan him, and maybe it's very hard for some to risk sitting down with him to negotiate.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Bozell French Move
LEAD: A partnership between Bozell and Eurocom in France has ended.
Bozell said Friday that it had traded its share of their jointly owned Synergie Bozell for Eurocom's majority interest in another French agency, Iceberg.
Bozell is taking several clients from Synergie to Iceberg, including the Chrysler Corporation and Texas Instruments Inc.


Avalanche Closes Ski Resort
LEAD: An avalanche prompted officials to close the Jackson Hole Ski Resort today, but no one was injured, officials said.
The resort was closed for the day after the avalanche at 1:10 P.M. in an area called the Headwall, said Mike McCollister, director of operations.
About 50 searchers with tracking dogs sifted through the snow for three hours and determined no one had been trapped.

Boston Technology Inc., Cambridge, Mass., is offering 2.8 million common shares at $6.5 each through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Saatchi Wins Mylanta
LEAD: Saatchi &amp; Saatchi Advertising has won the account for Mylanta antacid, which the agency said is the first product assignment from the Johnson &amp; Johnson/Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Company.
The joint venture acquired the product earlier this month when it bought the over-the-counter pharmaceutical business of Imperial Chemical Industries of London.


Warning by Big Oil;   Larger Bites From Profits Expected Because of Environmental Standards
LEAD: The charges against earnings taken by some oil companies in the most recent quarter to deal with environmental problems are a warning that pollution standards will be increasingly costly to meet and that more such charges are likely.


Jack Iams, Novelist, Editor of Magazine And TV Critic, 79
LEAD: Jack Iams, a journalist, a novelist and an editor, died of a stroke on Saturday.
At the time of his death, he and his wife, Joan Walker Wenning Iams, were en route to New York City from London.
Mr.
Iams, whose journalistic career spanned more than half a century, was 79 years old.

LEAD: John Silber, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, has come under attack for separate statements that in one case have been called too lenient toward alcoholism and in another have been termed racist.
The Silber camp has denied both charges.

LEAD: In Iowa, where they covet convertibles, loathe telephone-answering machines, keep an eye out for extraterrestrials and pine for more affectionate goldfish, the poll people are at it again.

Cafferty makes a hard-driving engineer.


Business Scene;   Exporters Shrug At Dollar's Drop
LEAD: THE dollar just might be on the verge of a big drop in value.
It is already off 15 percent against the West German mark since mid-September, and Japan is taking steps to strengthen the yen and weaken the dollar.
That should be wonderful news for the nation's exporters, the main beneficiaries of a cheaper dollar, but surprisingly, many greet the prospect with a shrug.

LEAD: The New York debut recital of the New England String Quartet in Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening may have been a bit premature.

India Tells of Foiling Uprising in Kashmir
LEAD: Officials in Srinagar, the Kashmiri capital, said today that separatists had planned to declare independence from India on Friday and send thousands of supporters into the streets in a show of force timed to coincide with India's independence day.

Poland's Communists Vote to Dissolve Party
LEAD: Poland's Communist Party, after ruling the country for 45 years, voted to dissolve itself.
Party delegates had decided to create a new democratic, left-of-center party in the hope of winning public support, but a group of about 100 dissidents broke off to form a competing Social Democratic Party.

LEAD: Robert L. Riddell, executive director of the U.S.O. in New York City for more than 30 years, died of heart failure on Saturday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in Queens.
He was 65 years old and lived in Flushing.

LEAD: Thousands of people in the Northeast reported seeing a strange blue-green light in the sky Saturday night.

LEAD: Robert Rivera, a 17-year-old from the Bronx, has been in New York City's foster care system since he was 12.
Only in the last year, however, has he found a place that feels like home: the Glen Mills Schools in Concordville, Pa.


Treasury to Sell Bills Today
LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week is confined to today's auction of three- and six-month bills.
Late on Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.68 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.63 percent.
This week, the Treasury is expected to announce the size of the quarterly refunding, including 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities.

LEAD: In a court battle over the future of Peach Lake, two suburban imperatives are colliding in this remote corner of Westchester County: the need for affordable housing and the yearning for open spaces.

LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers, capturing the National Football League title for the fourth time in a decade, enhanced their status as one of the great sports franchises with a record-breaking 55-10 trouncing of the Denver Broncos yesterday in Super Bowl XXIV.


Ethnic Albanian Protesters Battle With Yugoslav Police
LEAD: Thousands of ethnic Albanians fought with the police today in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo in demonstrations demanding that the Communist authorities lift a state of emergency and allow free elections.
A man was reported killed and four injured.

LEAD: Most first-time visitors to this famous vantage point on the Panama Canal, eight miles from the Pacific, come away dazzled by the majesty of the 51.2-mile waterway and the near-miraculous ingenuity and sacrifice that went into its construction more than 75 years ago.

LEAD: Leading molecular biologists say a technique promoted by the nation's top law-enforcement agency for identifying suspects in criminal trials through the analysis of genetic material is too unreliable to be used in court.

Tribe Gets Free Use of Library
LEAD: People living on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation will have free use of the Ledyard library, after an agreement between town officials and tribal leaders.
Although tribal lands are within town boundaries, town officials had required residents of the reservation to pay $19 for library cards, the same fee paid by out-of-town residents.

LEAD: Israeli and East German officials are to begin preliminary talks on Monday aimed at establishing the first diplomatic ties between the two nations, the Foreign Ministry said today.
But first the two sides must resolve longstanding disagreements over the Nazi genocide.

LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Nicaraguan Government had reversed its position and would allow American Congressmen to observe the February elections.

LEAD: The Los Angeles Philharmonic announced yesterday that it will be in residence at the Salzburg Festival in August of 1992.

Francois d'Assise'' in a new production.

LEAD: A long-awaited study of malpractice in New York hospitals, perhaps the most comprehensive ever conducted in the United States, concludes that thousands of hospital deaths and tens of thousands of injuries are tied to negligence each year but that relatively few victims seek recourse in the courts.

The Milanese public was predisposed against the work, he wrote; but it was such a triumph that ''scarcely a moment passed without the entire audience rising to its feet as one man to shower Rossini with applause.

Pilot Guilty in Cocaine Plot
LEAD: A Colombian pilot accused of flying cocaine for the Medellin drug organization pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiring to import cocaine into the United States.
The pilot, Jorge de la Cuesta, faces a maximum sentence of life and a $4 million fine.
He was accused of flying cocaine for Carlos Lehder Rivas, who has been convicted of smuggling drugs.

LEAD: Israel will apply to join the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the proposed bank to help Eastern Europe, Bank of Israel sources said Sunday.
France is the driving force in the plan to establish the new bank, which will serve the private sector in Eastern Europe.
The 12 European Community countries, 14 other developed nations and 8 East European states are involved.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day on Friday about the bankruptcy proceedings of Federated Stores Inc. misstated the effect on discounts for retired employees.
The discounts were ended on Jan. 15 as the company filed its petition.
But along with that filing, it petitioned the judge to approve a restoration of the discounts.

LEAD:
MARKETS

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Higher Heights
Q. Are people getting taller?
A. ''It depends on what people you're talking about,'' said Tim Sullivan at the Center for Human Growth and Development in Ann Arbor, Mich., which studies the health factors involved in height.
In a given population, physical anthropologists and public health experts believe, the trend could go either way.

LEAD: Air-traffic controllers in Islip, L.I., directing Avianca Flight 52 transferred authority for the Boeing 707 jet to their colleagues in Garden City, L.I., in a routine procedure that they might perform as many as 50 times an hour.
But somehow information about Flight 52's critical fuel problem was never relayed.

By Design;   The Pastels of Summer
LEAD: Conjure up a beautiful summer day in the French countryside, white clouds gliding across piercingly blue skies, gardens of dazzling pink roses, fields of blazing sunflowers.

What was new was seeing these full-bodied pastels for day as well as for evening.

LEAD: The body of a kidnapped 12-year-old boy whose finger was cut off and sent to his family in December to pressure them into sending ransom money was found Sunday afternoon wrapped in plastic bags off the Hutchinson River Parkway in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

Our Towns;   Promised Land Of Milk, Honey And High Price
LEAD: Thirty-four-year-old Barbara McDermott buys two gallons of milk a week for herself, her husband and her 12-year-old son, so she was delighted when Mike Gabriele, who runs the neighborhood deli, cut his prices by 30 or 40 cents a gallon.
But she didn't know he was breaking the law to do it.

LEAD: A major terrorism trial opened here today when a tribunal began examining a case involving the 20-person terrorist network allegedly organized by Fouad Ali Saleh, who is said to have belonged to the Beirut-based Party of God, a pro-Iranian militia.

LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney outlined his long-term plans for reshaping the military today, proposing the elimination of five of the Army's 28 active-duty and reserve divisions and making new investments in costly long-range nuclear programs through the mid-1990's.

Reviews/Music;   5-Part Series on the Songs Of Cole Porter Opens at Y
LEAD: In a letter to Cole Porter early in 1933, Irving Berlin congratulated the songwriter on ''Night and Day,'' calling it his ''best spot.'' A slide showing the actual letter that Berlin sent to Porter was one of the fascinating visual tidbits in the opening program of the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday as it began its 20th season.


Mrs. Fields Agrees To Marriott Link
LEAD: Mrs.
Fields Inc., the world's largest producer and retailer of cookies, agreed to license the Marriott Corporation to produce and sell Mrs.
Fields products in stores owned and operated by Marriott.
Under the agreement Marriott will finance and build a minimum of 60 Mrs.
Fields cookie stores in the next five years.


Business and Health;   Cutting the Cost Of Medicaid Drugs
LEAD: THE pharmaceutical industry is fighting growing pressure to reduce the prices of prescription drugs used by low-income Americans in the financially pressed Federal-state Medicaid programs.
Medicaid officials said spending on prescription drugs rose last year by 12 percent, to $3.87 billion, from $3.45 billion in 1988.


On Ho Chi Minh Trail, New Villages and Old Bombs
LEAD: This paltry cluster of small houses on stilts, a shabby clinic, a modest Government office and a new covered market was once the strategic center of the Ho Chi Minh trail - or so American and South Vietnamese military briefers used to recite during the war that ended in 1975.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
COLLEGE BASKETBALL
Defense Helps Louisville Triumph
Tony Kimbro scored 9 of his 17 points in a 19-6 first-half run last night to lead Louisville past Southern Mississippi, 105-88.
Louisville, playing at home, is 15-3 over all and 5-1 in the Metro Conference.
Southern Mississippi is 11-7 and 2-3.(AP)

LEAD: The Coast Guard is opposing a plan to build an 18,000-seat amphitheater at the Metrozoo, saying it could interfere with the war on drugs.


Carter Applauds Nicaraguans On Election-Monitoring Plan
LEAD: Strongly praising Government preparations for the Feb. 25 national elections, former President Jimmy Carter left Managua on Sunday night after mediating between Sandinista and opposition leaders on concerns ranging from reported police intimidation to restrictions on campaign funds.

Careers;   Management School Shifts With Times
LEAD: FEW graduate schools of business can keep current with world economic and political trends just by analyzing their student rosters, but the Management Education Institute Inc. in Cambridge, Mass., can do just that.
The reason: more than 95 percent of its students come from abroad to study for a master of science degree in management, which is earned over 11 months.


Chrysler Says Most Rebates Will Continue
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would extend most of its current rebate program through the end of February to maintain rising sales momentum.


Driver Charged With Murder
LEAD: A Colorado man was charged with murder in a hit-and-run case in which witnesses said he made a U-turn across a road divider to kill a pedestrian.
The driver, George T. Kohoutek, a 38-year-old resident of Aspen, Colo., was being held without bail.
Mr.
Kahoutek was arrested Sunday after the police said his Jeep was the car used to kill Rafael Caracheo, 26, on a Dallas street Saturday morning.

LEAD: If the overnight ratings for Super Bowl XXIV are any indication, the game may prove to be the lowest-rated game in two decades.

Europe Inflation Up
LEAD: The inflation rate in the European Community reached 5.4 percent in December, up from 4.4 percent at the end of 1988, the bloc's statistics office, Eurostat, said today.
For December, consumer prices in the 12-nation economic bloc were three-tenths of 1 percent higher than in November.
All European Community members had higher inflation last year except Portugal, where the December rate of 11.6 percent was down from the 11.7 percent recorded a year earlier.


Upheaval in the East;   Hungarians Protest Prices
LEAD: More than 20,000 demonstrators chanting ''We're fed up!'' rallied in front of Parliament today to demand pay raises and to protest increases in prices for food and transportation. ''We do not want to use our final weapon, the general strike, but we are not ruling it out either,'' said Sandor Nagy, general secretary of the official trade union federation, which helped organize the rally.

Chicago Receives Gift From Bulls
LEAD: The Chicago Bulls, hoping to give disadvantaged youths an alternative to drugs and gangs, are donating $1 million to the city's Park District to renovate more than 100 aging basketball courts, about half of them outdoors.


For Bitter Newspaper Rivals, an Uneasy Alliance
LEAD: For decades this city was the site of one of the most impassioned newspaper wars in the country: two bitterly competitive papers, neck-and-neck in circulation, trying to drive each other out of business.
The brawl left them with zealous readers who took sides as if the papers were football teams, but also with annual losses in the tens of millions of dollars.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about daily trading in the stock markets referred incorrectly in some editions to the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average since the beginning of the year.
Through the market's close on Monday, the drop in the Dow had been 199.82 points.
The article also misstated the day's change in the stock price for Apple Computer Inc.

Economic Scene;   Does Japan Play Fair?
LEAD: THE Japanese do not mean to offend, say the new breed of Japan-watchers, whose revisionist views on international trade and finance have become fashionable from Capitol Hill to the Commerce Department.
But the Japanese hardly understand what is meant by free markets and are not about to be converted by the Heritage Foundation.

The Handicapped-Parking Enforcers
LEAD: For years people with disabilities have seethed as they watched others illegally take their reserved parking spaces.
But now many suburbs are beginning to do something about it, sending out volunteers to catch violators where they are parked.

LEAD: Hope Sweetser Dean, a founder and former president of the Foundation for Children's Books, which sponsors teacher workshops and seminars to encourage children's reading, died Jan. 24 at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston.
She was 72 years old and lived in Marion, Mass.

LEAD: NOT the least of the charms of the food that Caprial Pence makes is its simplicity.
Often when a professional's food is described as simple, it does not mean that the amateur cook can whip it up at home.


19 Feared Lost in Channel
LEAD: A Greek-registered cargo ship disappeared during a storm in the English Channel and all 19 crew members were feared dead, the British Coast Guard said today.
Two bodies, one identified as that of a Greek member of the crew, washed ashore on the south coast of England with a lifeboat bearing the ship's name, Flag Theofano.

LEAD: Masaru Ogawa, former editor of The Japan Times, Japan's largest English-language newspaper and one of the country's most prominent journalists, died on Sunday of heart failure at his home in Tokyo.

60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: THE traditional French and American way to cook flatfish like sole and flounder is sauteing.
Delicate species like these can be broiled, but they tend to dry out quickly if not watched carefully.
A third method I have used successfully for years is high-temperature roasting.

LEAD: Hal Draper, a scholar and writer on Marxism and socialism for 50 years, died of pneumonia Friday at his home in Berkeley, Calif.
He was 75 years old.

Crane Plans to Bid For Milton Roy
LEAD: The Crane Company said its board of directors had authorized a $21-a-share offer for the Milton Roy Company.
Stock in Milton Roy, a St.
Petersburg, Fla., maker of measuring instruments, rose $1 today, to $17.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Crane slipped 62.5 cents, to $22.25.
Crane, which sells building products, said it was ready to make the offer but needed the cooperation of Milton Roy's board to insure its shareholder rights plan did not prevent the offer from proceeding.

Metropolitan Diary
LEAD:
ORANGE CRUSH
Two gray cloud fingers
squeeze the cold orange sun
spilling cascades of Vitamin C
into the Hudson.
Crushed, the sun slips down
and disappears in New Jersey.
ARLENE L. MANDELL

Newark Cathedral Worth Visit From Manhattan
LEAD: To the Editor:


In Bordeaux, Wine's Still King But Food Is Gaining Attention
LEAD: AT wineries in Bordeaux, the question of what food to serve with the wine is easily answered.
Chances are it will be roast lamb, roast veal or roast filet of beef, regardless of whether the wine planned for dinner is a Leoville-Las-Cases 1970, a Ducru-Beaucaillou 1971 or a Gruaud-Larose 1980. ''In Bordeaux, we're not too serious about matching food and wine,'' Jean-Eugene Borie, owner of Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou and several other properties in the Medoc, said at a recent dinner at the winery.

Coral Potter, 49, Dies; An Actor and Manager
LEAD: Coral S. Potter, an actor with the Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater for 17 years, died of lung cancer on Thursday at St.
Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 49 years old.
Mr.
Potter had been a member of the Cocteau's resident acting company since its second season in 1972.
His many credits included ''The Golem,'' ''The Duchess of Malfi,'' ''Waiting for Godot,'' ''The Cenci,'' ''Hamlet,'' ''Ghosts,'' ''Twelfth Night,'' ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' ''Rhinoceros'' and ''Volpone.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a summary article yesterday about President Bush's budget proposals for domestic programs misstated the proposed budget for the Environmental Protection Agency.
It is $5.8 billion.


Ban the Boom
LEAD: Ever since there have been radios, adolescents have turned up the volume to annoy adults.
Portable radios, and later ''boom boxes,'' some the size of large suitcases, made it possible to carry the annoyance out of the house.
Now ''boom cars'' - automobiles fitted with high-powered sound systems - are driving annoyance across town.

Miniature Golf, the New City Game
LEAD: Outside, a bitter wind is slicing off Lake Michigan, and the sidewalks are glazed with ice.
But on the third floor of a refurbished warehouse on the North Side, where an open area has been rearranged as an 18-hole miniature golf course, the little fairways are as crowded as Pebble Beach on a Sunday morning.

In the end, he dies from a drug-induced heart-attack.

Review/Television;   Confessions About Women By an Earnest 18-Year-Old
LEAD: Much of ''Women and Wallace'' can sound like the intensely earnest confession of an 18-year-old.
Why not?
It is.
Jonathan Marc Sherman was just that age when he wrote the play, which went on to become a 1988 winner in the Young Playwrights Festival in New York.
Tonight at 10 on Channel 13, the ''American Playhouse'' series is presenting ''Women and Wallace'' in an adaptation of a version originally done for Playwrights Horizons Off Broadway.

Campbell Soup
LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said it plans to sell its Juice Bowl Products Inc. subsidiary and close a foreign plant.

The Camden-based company said that Juice Bowl, based in Lakeland, Fla., was no longer needed.

LEAD: Donald J. Newman, a criminologist and former dean of the School of Criminal Justice at the State University of New York at Albany, died of a stroke on Friday at the Albany Medical Center.
He was 65 years old and lived in the Albany suburb of Slingerlands.


A Chance to Expand Democracy
LEAD: Why don't Americans vote?
While other parts of the world edge closer to democracy, America's democracy is shrinking.
Reflecting a steady decline in participation, barely half the voting-age population took part in the 1988 Presidential election - the worst turnout in 64 years.
The uninspiring campaign surely didn't help.

Review/Film;   A Wizard Who's Hexed by Hollywood
LEAD: Has any film maker ever worked harder to win his audience's affections than Mike Jittlov, the writer, director, co-producer and star of ''The Wizard of Speed and Time''?
On the evidence of Mr.
Jittlov's world-class home movie, it hardly seems possible that anyone has.
Mr.
Jittlov, for whom this is clearly a labor of love as well as a Herculean effort, attempts every conceivable trick in the special-effects book in order to wow his viewers, and at times the results are literally dizzying.

Review/Music;   More From Schoenberg and Colleagues
LEAD: Though the Juilliard School's series called Focus 1990, the World of Arnold Schoenberg, might appear to be another crash course in 20th-century musical history, its real goals may lie beyond the scope of a thumbnail survey.
The necessarily disjointed programs assembled by Joel Sachs can serve a purpose if they stimulate listeners not only to examine this often murky subject through the lens of one composer's development but also to think afresh about the social and political climate in which 20th-century music grew.

Year-ago quarter included a pretax loss of $27,685,000 on corporate restructuring.


City Opera Pact Ratified
LEAD: The singers, dancers, choristers and stage managers of the New York City Opera voted yesterday to ratify a five-year contract between their union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, and the opera company.
For most members of the company, the agreement calls for a salary increase of $50 a week in the first three years and in the fifth year, with a $25 increase in the fourth year.

Hugo Cohn, Engineer And Consultant, 102
LEAD: Hugo Cohn, an electrical engineer who helped develop radio beacons for distinguishing between friendly and enemy aircraft, died on Monday at St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan.
He was 102 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Gifts to the Neediest Are Often Prompted By a Second Motive
LEAD: Katsumi Tashiro of Harrison, N.Y., had an unusual motive for sending a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a desire to alter the perceptions that some New Yorkers have about Japanese people.


American Brands Shifts Directors
LEAD: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that five inside members of its board had resigned, prompting speculation on Wall Street that some of the company's managers were preparing a buyout bid.
But the company said it was making the board's structure more like that of other large corporations, in which the outside directors are a majority.

LEAD: If you think Ivy League colleges de-emphasize football, please don't mention that while the Joel E. Smilow '54 Coach of Football at Yale University is interviewing a hot prospect.

LEAD: A ruling on the argument by Gen.

Thinking Machines Seen in Japan Deal
LEAD: The Thinking Machines Corporation, a maker of parallel supercomputers, will announce this week that it has sold its first machine in Japan.
The Japanese organization, Auditory and Visual Perception Research Laboratories, is associated with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company.
The group said it was buying the supercomputer, known as a CM-2 Connection

Ford Loses Patent Suit On Wipers
LEAD: A former engineering professor who says he invented the intermittent windshield wiper now used by most major car and truck manufacturers has won a bellwether patent-infringement case against the Ford Motor Company.


Stephenson Is Mending
LEAD: Jan Stephenson, who underwent surgery last week for a double fracture of her left ring finger, said yesterday that she had started rehabilitation and hoped to rejoin the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour soon.

Mitterrand Is Said to Agree to Free Hunger Striker
LEAD: President Francois Mitterrand has promised to release a convicted pro-Iranian terrorist in exchange for his agreement to end a four-month hunger strike, published reports said today.


Small Quakes Jolt California
LEAD: Five earthquakes, none of them higher than 2.9 on the Richter scale, struck the Southern California desert within two hours today, seismologists reported.
The epicenter was 25 miles north of El Centro, near the Salton Sea, according to the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena.
The quake times and readings were: 6:01 A.M., 2.8; 6:02 A.M., 2.8; 6:04 A.M., 2.9; 6:16 A.M., 2.7, and 7:54 A.M., 2.5.

Woman, 93, Saved From Fire
LEAD: A 93-year-old woman who was trapped by a fire in her apartment above the White Horse Tavern, a Greenwich Village landmark, was rescued yesterday by three police officers, officials said.
The woman, Katherine Fitzgibbons, was removed from her smoke-filled apartment at 561 Hudson Street by the police at 8:30 A.M.


BULGARIAN LEADER COURTS OPPOSITION
LEAD: The Bulgarian Communist leader, Petar Mladenov, invited the political opposition today to join a government of national unity to run the country until free elections in May.

Bond Prices Up After Hectic Day
LEAD: A rumor from Moscow overtook news reports from Washington in the credit markets yesterday and prices of Treasury securities closed higher after a volatile session.


Brand-Name Lean Beef: Is It Really Better?
LEAD: FOR years when shoppers brought home a sirloin steak or a chuck roast, it was surrounded by at least an inch of fat and was generally graded choice.
It was sold under the supermarket's name, and consumers had no idea who produced it.


EXECUTIVE CHANGES
LEAD: *
Burlington Northern Railroad Co., Fort Worth, a unit of Burlington Northern Inc., named William E. Greenwood chief operating officer.
John Anderson will succeed Mr.
Greenwood as executive vice president for marketing and sales.


Nancy Gruver, Leader In Bridge, Is Dead at 58
LEAD: Nancy Gruver, one of the nation's leading contract bridge players, died of a heart attack Sunday at Howard County General Hospital in Maryland.
She was 58 years old and lived in Ellicott City, Md.


Pipe Bomb Explodes in Houston Church
LEAD: A pipe bomb apparently mailed to one of Houston's largest churches exploded this morning, injuring the pastor's daughter, the police said.

The Royal Shakespeare: Ready to Move On
LEAD: The artistic director and chief executive of the Royal Shakespeare Company, the ''embattled Terry Hands,'' as he is so often described in the British press, sat dressed in black in his white-walled London office the other day and stated for what might have been the thousandth time that his 29-year-old theater company was embattled, yes, but not yet ready for embalming.
